\lx -a
\sf 
\sn 1
\ps case
\ge LOC
\de this ending marks where something is located, for example at, on, in
\sd Y Word Endings
\dk langa, la
\re on
\re in
\re at
\sy -da, -gula, -ja, -ga, -a, -ngga
\xv Warri na ngajig-barni na mamunggul-a nyila Warri nyila Barrjirda.
\xe He stopped for good at Warri, a sacred place that one, that Barrjirda.
\xv Wavehill-a-ma-wula garrinya, wanyji-ma.
\xe The two of them were at Wavehill station then, alive.
\rf CJcorpus:Yarralin:KJ:Ngayiny_ngaji_story:3/6/95
\xv Ngaja-n wan.gu wilmurr-a.

\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx baba
\sf baba_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge older.brother
\de brother. Opposite sex siblings cannot call each other's names after a brother goes through ceremony. They also cannot share the same shade and a brother cannot eat food prepared by his sister.
\sd B People
\dk baba
\re brother (older)
\va
\sy ngaba
\gg papa, ngapa
\gr baba, ngaba
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\nt Note that this may actually be a Kriol form, or perhaps a babytalk form of 'ngaba' which made its way into Kriol.
\dt 19/Mar/2008

\lx bagarli
\sf bagarli_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge river.paperbark
\de river paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark (river)
\re river paperbark
\re Melaleuca leucadendra
\sc Melaleuca leucadendra
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg pakarli
\xv Garu-walija yana-lu bardardaj bagarli-ngga Banganygu-ngga
\xe All of the kids climb the paperbark tree at Banganygu.
\rf I. Hector. 2006. Nimarra Banganygu-ngga gudij garra darugab. Produced by L. Campbell for DAC.
\so 050317ih, 050330ih, 060222ih
\pc bagarli.jpg
\ee This paperbark is used in bush medicine. To prepare bagarli, you boil the leaves and wash in it to help alleviate cold and flu symptoms. You can also use the bark to make shelters, blankets and to cover meat in ground ovens. The swellings in the tree are potential water sources. You can cut them open and drink the water found inside.
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge book
\de book
\sd D Things
\dk buk
\re book
\va
\sy
\gr bagarli
\gg pakarli
\xv
\xe
\rf
\nt
\sn 3
\ps n
\ge paper
\de paper
\sd D Things
\dk
\re paper
\va
\sy
\gr bagarli
\gg pakarli
\xv
\xe
\rf
\nt
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx bagayawung
\sf bagayawung_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge echidna
\de echidna, porcupine
\sd H Mammals
\re echidna
\re porcupine
\re Tachyglossus aculeatus
\va
\sy jungguwurru
\sy nginyiwurda
\sc Tachyglossus aculeatus
\gr junggurru, jungguwurru, bagayawung
\gg jungkuwurru
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_05ih:(1:35, 1:40, 3:15, 3:50)
\pc echidna.jpg
\nt many to be found near Top Springs and Montejinni station; this is Ivy's Dreaming from her dad.
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so Ethnobiology draft 200
\ee Jungguwurru often live in rocky country, where they hide in crevasses and cracks. They can be pulled out with wire hooks or hooked branches. They are much more commonly seen at night when they walk around looking for food. They are most active during full moon periods in the cold weather of the dry season. When they walk they leave a little track where the prickles drag along the ground. When they are approached, they roll into a tight ball to protect themselves. Their favourite foods are ants called 'bingi' and termites called 'mun.gurd' which they eat with their tongue called 'jalany'. They are often found near termite mounds called 'mardumardu'. During the hot weather of the build-up they can be found in cool areas near rivers called 'lamarn', where they look for wet ground that is cool to sleep on. The name 'jungguwurru' is derived from Jaminjung (junggu=point of elbow plus -wurru=having). Porcupines or echidnas are also often called baga-yawung (having spikes). You can roast the flesh and eat it. The meat is sweet like pork. It has a lot of tasty white coloured fat. You need to chop off the spines and feet prior to cooking the whole body in a ground oven. You can soften the spines by placing them on hot coals for a short time or by placing them in a bucket of very hot water. The flesh cannot be eaten by young boys and mothers during initiation ceremonies. Pregnant women called 'ngardurr' cannot eat them because the spikes might poke the baby and it will be born a cripple. Jungguwurru has a Dreaming story about how he got his prickles. Jungguwurru got mad when he found out that the other animals weren't giving him the good meat. He took all of the shade trees away, so the other animals speared him, giving him his prickles.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\sf bagibagi_CA.mp3

\lx Baladmawu
\sf Baladmawu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de Poison Creek Yard. A spring and standing stone
\sd O Place Names
\re Poison Creek Yard
\xv
\xe
\rf

\nt Confirmed by Horace Warlman and Kathleen Juduwurr
\dt 14/Aug/2008

\lx baladmawu
\sf baladmawu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bandicoot
\de bandicoot
\sd H Mammals
\re bandicoot
\re Isoodon macrourus
\va
\sy
\sc Isoodon macrourus
\gr balawudmawu (rock rat, kangaroo rat, "rabbit", 10-12cm long mouse-like creature)
\gg palatmawu
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_05ih:(12:20-13:00, 15:45, 16:55, 18:10-18:20)
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(15:05, 23:05)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(21:15-21:45, 23:15-25:05)
\pc northern_brown_bandicoot.jpg
\cf bunybuny
\cf ngamarlu
\nt Ivy gave this term with picture of a bandicoot on 050913.  050921 says its "little bit
big one"; eliciited with long-tailed planigale and northern brown bandicoot, later with
bilby; pic of bandicoot also got bunybuny 
\nt 060124 picture of rock ringtail possum.  People used to hunt it with a stick or stone.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC-previously glossed as 'kangaroo rat'. Glenn is unsure of species, but some type of bandicoot.
\ee Baladmawu is like a large rat with a long pointy nose. It is a ground dweller which digs little holes looking for food. During the day it hides in grassy areas where it makes a small camp in thick grass. It has not been seen in recent times but in the past it was common sometimes and then would not be seen for a while. Following good wet seasons and lots of rain, they would be seen in large numbers, especially near rivers called 'lamarn'. The meat is very tasty and tender. When bandicoots were common, they were hunted often. They are more common in northern areas.
\dt 28/Apr/2008

\lx Balarrgi
\sf Balarrgi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge Police.Hole
\de Police Hole, a waterhole on Gordon Creek
\sd O Place Names
\re Police Hole
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050608ih,bb, 050706ih
\so AAPA: Aboriginal sacred sites within large vicinity of Pigeon Hole Outstation
\so NLC: Bilinara (Coolibah-Wavehill Stock Route) Land Claim. May 1989. (Anzac Munganyi, Old Jimmy Manngayarri)
\gp 709800E, 8151800N
\ee There used to be a police station here in the 1880-90s. Constable W. H. Willshire was posted there then. He was a brutal policeman who killed many Bilinarra people.

\lx balngawun
\sf balngawun_SH.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge green.frog
\de green tree frog
\sd K Water Animals
\sd I Reptiles
\re frog (green)
\re green frog
\re Litoria caerulea
\va
\sy
\sc Litoria caerulea
\gr
\gg pangawurn
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(22:10)
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_05ih:(2:20 - 2:25, 5:45 - 5:50)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(27:00-27:20, 28:00-28:30)
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc green_tree_frog.jpg
\nt Ivy mentioned on 051123 that when the green frog sings out it's making the rain,
confirmed 060124
\nt 060124 Dreaming for Alberta, Cedrina, Fiota, Nyalb
\ee This large green frog often lives around bathrooms and laundries and any other wet area. They are good to use as bait to catch large barramundi called 'yinarrwa' and catfish called 'jalarlga' or 'warrag'. When this frog calls out at night it brings more rain. The rain stops when it stops calling.
\sn 2
\ge frog
\de giant burrowing frog
\sd K Water Animals
\sd I Reptiles
\re giant burrowing frog
\re frog (giant burrowing)
\re Litoria australis
\sy
\sc Litoria australis
\ee This frog calls loudly in the wet season. It is considered to be similar to the green tree frog.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx bamarr
\sf bamarr_SH.mp3
\sn 1
\ps n
\ge stone
\de stone, rock
\sd G Environment
\re stone
\re rock

\lx bamarrngarna
\sf bamarrngarna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge rock.kangaroo
\de rock kangaroo (lit: associated with stone)
\sd H Mammals
\re rock kangaroo
\re hill kangaroo
\re kangaroo (hill)
\re kangaroo (rock)
\re Macropus robustus
\va
\sy minawud
\sy wumarangarna
\sy bunggiyid
\sc Macropus robustus
\ee These kangaroos are often seen in hilly areas. They often have longish hair and can range in colour from dark grey to light grey to a bit reddish. The word 'bamarrngarna' or 'wumarangarna' refers to their preferred habitat in rocky areas. These kangaroos are cooked in ground ovens and eaten. The tendons, called 'gambun', from the tails are used to attach spear heads called 'yirlga' or axe heads called 'gurrwa' to shafts, and hooks called 'narra' to spear-throwers called 'warlmaya'. 
\so 050910ih
\pc euro.jpg
\cf bamarr
\nt
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx bambilyi
\sf bambilyi_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge split-jack
\de split-jack
\sd M Plants
\re split-jack
\re Capparis lasiantha
\va
\sy
\sc Capparis lasiantha
\gr
\gg pampilyi
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc bambilyi.jpg
\ee This plant has small sharp thorns and usually grows up the trunks of trees, particularly conkerberry trees called 'ngamanburru' and bauhinias called 'wanyarri'. The fruit can be eaten. They ripen when the rain season starts. They turn yellow-orange, split open and have a pleasant fruity smell. The fruit are very sweet. 
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx bangarra

\ps n
\ge corella
\de corella
\sd J Birds
\re corella
\re Cacatua sanguinea
\va
\sy
\sc Cacatua sanguinea
\gr
\gg takutpari
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_02ih:(20:00-25:35)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(19:10-21:10)
\pc Little_Corella.jpg
\ee You can train these birds to talk. The feathers are used in some ceremonies. In the past people used to hunt them with a boomerang or stone and cook them on hot coals.
\nt 051123: elicited at first with picture of little corella, then Ivy changed when she saw
picture of sulphur-crested white cockatoo  People used to get this and other cockatoos
for meat in olden times, and people used to (060209 and still) get baby ones and keep
them as pets and teach them to speak English and language.  Catch them with
boomerang or stone, feathers used in ceremony (check which feathers, yellow, white,
or both: 060209 white ones).  Song is different from little corella: dagudbari says
"yagagag yagagag".
\nt 060124 picture of sulphur-crested white cockatoo, calls out yagagag-yagagag.  Ivy
gave alternate name "yarrgan.gu(r)na" as well here.

\lx bardigi
\sf bardigi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge nut.tree
\de nut tree, nuts (from the bardigi tree, or other European-style nuts such as peanuts)
\sd M Plants
\sd E Food and Cooking
\re nut tree
\re peanut
\re Terminalia arostrata
\va
\sy
\sc Terminalia arostrata
\gr bardigi
\gg partiki
\xv Wurruja yuga gambala-lu garu-walija-lu burdujburduj bardigi-mayin.
\xe The kids are burning off the dry grass, around the nut trees.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.12aud: 2003
\sfx bardigi_IH_eg1_wurruja.mp3
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_06ih:(5:20-5:50)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc bardigi.jpg
\nt LC-'grandiflora' is considered to be a young 'arostrata'
\ee The hard dark fruit are called 'janybarlg', although they are often just called 'bardigi'. When they are ripe, they are broken open and the seed inside is eaten. In the old days the fruit were cracked open with the back of a spear-thrower called a 'warlmayi'. Now an axe or hammer is often used. The seed is similar to a peanut and is pleasant tasting. The leaves are boiled in water and the liquid is used as a wash to treat itchy skin or scabies. This tree is also used in conjunction with 'wariyili' to treat skin sores called 'marndara' and boils called 'garlaba'. The leaves are boiled until the mix goes green, then the sores and boils are bathed in it. The mixture helps draw the pus out. It is also good for toothaches and can be used as shampoo which makes hair dark and healthy. The timber is good firewood and it is common to find sugarbag called 'namawurru' or 'ngarlu' in the trunk. The outer bark produces fine black soot called 'wuyu' when it is burnt. This can be used as colour during ceremonies. In the past it was rubbed onto the skin of light-skinned babies so that the welfare officers would not take them away. At Nitjpurru (Pigeon Hole) there are bardigi trees that have special significance for Bilinarra people. These trees form part of a Dreaming line for the Nangangari women. If they are cut down, the community will get sick.
\sn 2
\ge nut.tree
\de nut tree, nuts (from the bardigi tree, or other European-style nuts such as peanuts)
\sd M Plants
\sd E Food and Cooking
\re Terminalia grandiflora
\va
\sc Terminalia grandiflora
\gr bardigi
\gg partiki
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC-'grandiflora' is considered to be a young 'arostrata'
\ee This plant is considered to be a young version of Terminalia arostrata.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx bardigibanu
\sf bardigibanu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge eel-tail.catfish
\de eel-tail catfish, Hyrtl's Tandan
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (eel-tailed)
\re flat-tailed catfish
\re eel-tail catfish
\re Hyrtl's Tandan
\re Neosilurus hyrtlii
\re Neosilurus ater
\re Neosilurus hyrtlii
\re Neosilurus ater
\sy marnba
\va
\sc Neosilurus hyrtlii
\sc Neosilurus ater
\sc Neosilurus hyrtlii
\sc Neosilurus ater
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(9:05)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc flat-tailed_catfish.jpg
\ee Eel-tail catfish are generally caught with a spear or a spinifex bundle used as a fish net. They generally do not take bait on hand-lines. The larger ones can be roasted and eaten. The flesh is tasty. The smaller ones are used as bait to catch larger fish such as barramundi called 'yinarrwa'. These eel-tail catfish have dangerous spines that must be carefully avoided. These fish often eat small stones that look like the fruit of 'bardigi' trees hence their name.
\nt CHECK - JS - might be bardigibanuwu
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx Barinbarin
\sf Barinbarin_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename

\lx -barla
\sf 
\ps suf
\ge FOC
\de focus marker. It is used to draw attention to something in the sentence or contrast it with something else. It is also used to mean to link two events which happen one after the other. It translates as 'then' in these cases.
\sd Y Word Endings
\re now
\re then
\sy -warla
\sy na
\gr
\gg -parla
\xv Nyila-ma diwuwaji-la-warla-n yan.gu walilig-barla.
\xe You will be going around in a plane.

\lx barlngarrawuny
\sf barlngarrawuny_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge poisonous.fish
\de type of poisonous fish
\sd K Water Animals
\re fish (poisonous)
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg palngarawuny
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee
\nt LC-from ethno: This is a fish that has poisonous spines, it is yellow, orange in colour. It is used in sorcery to kill people. 
It could be a baby groper, that has traveled inland a long way, or a juvenile skinnyfish or a weird catfish. 
Scats also have spines that hurt but they are not poisonous. It occurs in shallow water and can be caught with a net.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx barnad
\sf barnad_CA.mp3

\de emu apple
\sd M Plants
\re emu apple
\re Owenia vernicosa
\sy
\sc Owenia vernicosa
\gr
\gg parnat
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc barnad.jpg
\ee The hard wood is used to make fighting-sticks or 'guduru'. This plant is considered to be poisonous. The fruit are eaten by emus called 'yibarrardu', turkeys called 'jamud' and rock kangaroos, but not by people.  The crushed nuts can be mixed with bark and spinifex to make fish poison.

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee When the fruit ripen, they turn purple to black. That's when they are eaten. They are sweet and tasty and highly regarded as a food source. They are collected during the hot weather of the build-up.

\gr barrarraj

\ee When the fruit ripen, they turn green and are soft to touch. That's when they are eaten. They are produced at the beginning or early in the wet season and are very tasty.

\lx barrawi
\ps n
\sf barrawi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge soap.tree
\de soap tree
\sd M Plants
\re soap tree
\re Acacia holosericea
\va
\sy
\sc Acacia holosericea
\gr barrawi
\gg parrawi
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050427bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc barrawi.jpg
\nt Rub the seed pods in water to create soap.
\ee You can use the stems of young straight trees to make spear shafts. 
If you rub the leaves with a little water you can make a soapy lather which is good for washing with. The timber can also be used to make the hook of a spear-thrower  or 'warlmayi'. The hook is called a 'narra'.
\sn 2
\ge elephant.ear.wattle
\de elephant ear wattle
\sd M Plants
\re elephant ear wattle
\re wattle (elephant ear)
\re Acacia dunnii
\va
\sy

\gr barrawi
\gg parrawi
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050427bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This plant has large grey leaves and grows on high country. 
You can use the stems from young straight plants to make spear shafts.

\lx barrjirda
\sf barrjirda_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge quoll
\de native cat, quoll
\sd H Mammals
\re quoll
\re Dasyurus hallucatus
\sc Dasyurus hallucatus
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- still some confusion over this one. IH used to say long ears like a rabbit. Also sometimes described as a quoll
\nt This was identified with LC as a brush-tailed possum but this is not right. FM replaced with quoll info. Ivy used to call this a rabbit and it is the Arrente word for quoll. They just haven't been seen for a while in that area.
\pc northern_quoll.jpg
\ee This animal has white spots on its back and used to be found in Bilinarra country but has not been seen for a long time. It is sometimes referred to as a rabbit. There is a line of Dreaming sites for Barrjirda on Bilinarra country. He started off at Langanggarni. Then he went to Banbidi and from there he looked towards Narlawi. He wanted to go north, but he continued east. He went east, down to the waterhole, Gurlba. He continued east, climbing up the hill called Warri. From Warri he went east to Rawurra. From Rawurra he went down to Widibi. From Widibi he went to Guyanba and then Garlarlami, until he came back to Langan.garni. That's where he stopped for good.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx bigurda
\sf bigurda_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.potato
\de bush potato
\sd M Plants
\re bush potato
\re potato (bush)
\re Ipomoea costata
\va
\sy yangununggu
\sc Ipomoea costata
\gr
\gg pikurta, yangunungku
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc bigurda.jpg
\ee Bush potatoes have pink flowers and grow in the red plain country. The actual potato is found quite far from the plant. The roots below the surface make the ground above them crack. The potato is located by following the cracks and tapping the ground. The ground makes a hollow sound where the potato is.

\lx binambalij
\sf binambalij_SH.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge plant.sp
\de type of plant with a pretty pink flower
\sd M Plants
\re Abutilon hannii
\gr binambalij
\gg pinampalij, Kulparramparra
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so I. Hector. 2002. Bilinarra Bush Medicine. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\sc Abutilon hannii
\ee This plant is used in bush medicine. The leaves and stems are boiled in water. You then use the water to treat skin sores called 'marndara', itchy skin and scabies called 'garangaji'. It is especially good for children and old people. If you rub the leaves on tired legs it also makes them feel stronger. It is also drunk to treat diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. 
\nt LC- check if used for boomerangs too.
\sn 2
\ge desert.rose
\de desert rose
\sd M Plants
\re desert rose
\gr binambalij
\gg pinampalij, Kulparramparra
\re Gossypium australe
\sc Gossypium australe
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc binambalij.jpg
\ee This plant is also used in bush medicine. You boil the leaves in water and use the wash to treat skin sores called 'marndara' and scabies called 'garangaji'. It is especially good for children. The leaves can also be rubbed onto the legs of someone who is tired from walking a long way and this makes the legs feel strong again.
\sn 3
\ge plant.sp
\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\re Triumfetta sp
\sc Triumfetta sp
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This plant is also used in bush medicine. You boil the leaves and use the liquid treat skin sores called 'marndara' and boils called 'garlaba'.
\nt
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\va
\sy
\sc
\gr
\gg pingi
\xv
\xe
\rf

\nt CHECK synonym 060123 elicited with pictures of termites and ants.  Ivy also called a small red mantid
that imitates an ant "ants", but I don't think she actually uses the term "bingi" for this in

\lx binybiny
\sf binybiny_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge finch
\de finch, like the red-backed wren
\sd J Birds
\re finch
\re red-backed wren
\re wren (red-backed)
\re Malurus melanocephalus
\va
\sy
\sc Malurus melanocephalus
\gr
\gg piny-piny
\xv
\xe
\pc crimson_finch.jpg
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_02ih:(4:20-5:30)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_03ih:(00:05-00:45, 2:45-3:00, 6:25-6:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(12:55-13:05)
\ee The word 'binybiny' is a general word for small, colourful birds. They live in grassy areas near rivers and creeks. In dry areas they can lead you to water called 'ngawa'. The red-backed wren is often found in pandanus areas. Small children call it the 'devil devil bird' and they are told stories about how it used to be a man. 
\dt 21/Jan/2008

\lx binyinyib
\sf binyinyib_CA.mp3
\ps cv
\ge rub.firesticks
\de rub fire sticks between two hands to make a fire
\sd P Moving
\re rub firesticks
\re
\re
\va
\sy
\gr binyinyib
\gg pinyinyip luwanana, pinyinyip manana
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf gunggarla
\ee There is a stone with an indent in it near Guliba which people used in the old days for lighting fires. They took a firestick between their hands and put some tinder (for example small leaves, grass or 'gura') in the indent.
Then they rubbed the stick between their hands and blew gently to start the fire.
\nt
\se binyinyib mana
\xv Binyinyinyib man.gu ngundi-wu
\xe He will rub the sticks together to make a light.
\rf FM:PigeonHole:BB,MH,CA:FM08_a096:3Jul08
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx birlbiji
\sf birlbiji_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge grasshopper
\de any type of grasshopper
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re grasshopper
\sy
\va bilbiga
\re Orthoptera
\re Caelifera
\sc Orthoptera
\sc Caelifera
\gr bilbijing
\gg pirlpirlji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_05ih:(13:40-14:40, 15:55-16:45)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(00:25-2:45, 8:00-8:25)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc grasshopper.jpg
\cf
\ee There are many types of grasshoppers. They can be used for fishing bait and goannas called 'girrawa' like to eat them. In the past swarms of small ones were caught and eaten after lightly roasting in flames or hot ashes.  There is a Dreaming place for grasshoppers near New Wave Hill Station or Jamanggu.
\nt 050427 : Barbara calls bilbiga "Big grasshopper", used as bait
\nt 060123: Most tokens from Ivy clearly "birlbiji"
\nt 060124 Ivy says this is big grasshopper or locust, later elicited with picture of
Leichardt grasshopper.  Green long-legged grasshopper Ivy forgets name but that
grasshopper makes bush yams (wayida).  Tokens sometimes sound like they have
some sort of -l or -rl before the -ji.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx birlgina
\sf birlgina_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge little.egret
\de little egret
\sd J Birds
\re little egret
\re egret (little)

and Mildred said it.  
\nt 051123 stimulus picture of little egret, not eaten  Checked with Ivy and Scottrina and
the br- is there sometimes, other times more clearly birl-

\so 060124 ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc little_red_flying_fox.jpg
\ee The flesh can be roasted and eaten. It has a strong distinctive smell and taste. This flying-fox is not very common and is smaller than the black flying-fox. They are generally found in desert country.

\lx birrbun
\sf birrbun_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\va
\re Verticordia cunninghamii
\sc Verticordia cunninghamii
\gr
\gg murlurrmi (turpentine bush, Acacia lysiphloia, Acacia monticola)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc birrbung.jpg
\ee This tree is used in bush medicine. The leaves and twigs are boiled in water. The cooled liquid is used as a medicinal wash to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' and itchy skin. The timber also makes good firewood.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx birrg
\sf birrg_CA.mp3
\ps cv
\ge take
\de take, pull off, snatch
\sd U Holding and Taking
\re take from
\re pull out
\re snatch
\va
\sy
\gr birrg
\gg pirrk

\de pull off

\lx birrgirli
\sf birrgirli_SH.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge river.paperbark
\de river paperbark or grey paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re river paperbark
\re grey paperbark
\re paperbark (grey)
\re paperbark (river)
\re Melaleuca argentea
\va
\sy
\sc Melaleuca argentea
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\pc birrgirli2.jpg
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This tree has grey coloured leaves and is generally found on river banks. It is often called 'river bagarli'. It produces very sweet smelling flowers that are like perfume. Flying-foxes called 'warrbawurru' and native bees called 'nama' or 'lanu' visit the flowers to get nectar and pollen. The papery bark can be used to make blankets called 'balginy' and shelters for the wet season. Children also used to make dolls called 'garugirligirlaj' from the bark in the old days. When a flying-fox colony roosts in these trees overhanging rivers, there are often crocodiles called 'warrija' under them and it can be a dangerous place to fish or camp.
\sn 2
\ge bush.paperbark
\de bush paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re bush paperbark
\re paperbark (bush)
\re Melaleuca nervosa
\va
\sy
\sc Melaleuca nervosa
\pc MelaleucaNervosa.jpg
\ee The papery bark can be used to light fires, though it is hard to pull off the trunk. The timber is good firewood. Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree.
\sn 3
\ge paperbark
\de paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark
\re Melaleuca viridiflora
\va
\sy
\sc Melaleuca viridiflora
\ee The timber is durable and can be used as fence posts, railings and for building shelters. Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx birrililg
\sf birrililg_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge lorikeet
\de red-collared lorikeet
\sd J Birds
\re lorikeet
\va
\so 050607bb,mh
\re Trichoglossus haematodes rubritorquis
\sc Trichoglossus haematodes rubritorquis
\gr birrililg
\gg pirrirlirlk
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_03ih:(2:30-3:40, 5:30-9:00, 9:15-9:45, 10:20-10:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(15:50, 16:40-18:20)
\cf milnginymilnginy
\pc Red_Collared_Lorikeet.jpg
\nt 051123:used for bait in old days for fishing
\nt 060124 picture of red-collared lorrikeet
\ee These birds like to eat flowers called 'yirna' from various trees and are sometimes seen in large flocks. In the past they were used as fishing bait.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx buliny
\sf buliny_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bony.bream
\de bony bream, bubble fish and tarpon or ox-eye herring
\sd K Water Animals
\re bony bream
\re bubble fish
\re tarpon
\re ox-eye herring
\re
\va
\sy
\re Nematalosa erebi
\re Megalops cyprinoides
\sc Nematalosa erebi
\sc Megalops cyprinoides
\gr buliny
\gg puliny, kunartu, jamanangmanang (rainbow fish)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(1:40, 1:45, 1:50, 2:05, 2:30, 7:55, 8:10, 8:15)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Bony_Bream.jpg
\ee The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals and ashes, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'. There are a lot of bones in the meat, though the tarpon or ox-eye herring has fewer bones. They can also be used as live bait to catch bigger fish such as barramundi called 'yinarrwa'. This fish blows out bubbles as it swims, and it is often called a bubble fish.
\nt
\sn 2
\ge rainbow.fish
\de rainbow fish
\sd K Water Animals
\re rainbow fish
\re Melanotaenia spp
\va
\sy
\sc Melanotaenia spp
\gr buliny
\gg puliny, kunartu, jamanangmanang (rainbow fish)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(1:40, 1:45, 1:50, 2:05, 2:30, 7:55, 8:10, 8:15)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee These small pretty fish are good to use as bait to catch larger fish. They are too small to eat. They often have a conspicuous stripe on the side.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx buljuny
\sf buljuny_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge death.adder
\de death adder
\sd I Reptiles
\re death adder
\re snake (death adder)
\re Acanthophis praelongus
\va
\sy bulyguwuny
\sy yurlurriny
\sc Acanthophis praelongus
\gr burrul, bulyguwung
\gg puljuny, yulurriny
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\pc death_adder.jpg
\ee This is a small snake that is very dangerous or 'guliyan'. It has a short prickle in the end of its tail. If it bites someone, they will be dead in a very short time. It lives in rocky areas, especially in caves called 'jarriny'. There is a song which stops the poison, and songs which clear the snakes away from camping areas. When they are killed they need to be chopped into pieces and burnt on a fire until they turn to ash, otherwise they can sing themselves back to health and kill you.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx bulugura
\sf bulugura_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge whistling.kite
\de whistling kite
\sd J Birds
\re whistling kite
\va
\sy
\gr bulugura (kestrel-type bird)
\gg pulukura
\re Milvus sphenurus
\sc Milvus sphenurus
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_02ih:(3:10-3:20)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_04ih:(17:50-18:20, 19:20)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_05ih:(9:30-10:30)
\pc Whistling_Kite.jpg
\nt triangular tail, whitish stripe on wing, very common around Katherine.  051123: 
elicited with stimulus picture of black kite, also black falcon. Not eaten (but maybe in
old days?).  Might also be whistling kite based on call in JS051123BIL.KAT_02ih
3:00-3:20 and discussion in JS051123BIL.KAT_05ih 10:00-10:30.
\ee These birds whistle as they fly. They have the Jangari skin and can spread fire by carry burning sticks.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx bulumanu
\sf bulumanu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge cattle
\de cattle or bullock
\sd H Mammals
\dk buligi
\re cattle
\re bullock
\re Bos taurus
\va
\sy
\sc Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\sc Bos indicus
\gr
\gg purluman, muwukaji
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common, before the 1980s there were not many brahmans and it was mainly shorthorns. The horns are called 'wirndurru' which is the same word for 'tree roots'. In the past the first settlers had very hairy cattle or woolly bullocks and these were called marrarnbarla. They no longer are seen in the area but are depicted in cave paintings.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx bulumarnda
\sf bulumarnda_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge long.tom
\de freshwater long tom
\sd K Water Animals
\re long tom
\re Strongylura krefftii
\va bunumarnda
\sy diwurru
\sy jurrgunduj
\sy jidjijuwal
\sc Strongylura krefftii
\gr diwurru, jurrgunduj
\gg tiwurru, jidjijuwal, punumarnta
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so
\so bulu- 050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(16:20 - 17:20, 19:35-19:40)
\so bulu -JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(32:40-33:15, 33:50-34:55)
\so bunu -FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc longtom.jpg
\nt 060124 called "long nose", not sure if picture prompt in first sequence is gar or long
tom (probably the latter).  In second sequence Ivy says this is same as jurrgu(r)nduj
and isn't sure whether diwurru applies as well (but thinks diwurru might be different
fish)
\ee The flesh from larger fish can be roasted and eaten. It is tasty but has a lot of bones. The smaller fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. This fish is recognised for its long pointy nose, as recognised in the name jidji-juwal (nose-long).
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\gr gajarrang-gajarrang

\lx bulurrd

\ps cv
\ge rub
\de rub something, paint, husking seed
\sd U Holding and Taking
\re rub
\va
\so MCCONVELL_P08-014876
\nt
\se bulurrud mana
\de rub, paint

\lx bulyguwuny
\sf bulyguwuny_CA.mp3
\ps 
\ge death.adder
\de death adder
\sd I Reptiles
\re death adder
\re snake (death adder)
\re Acanthophis praelongus
\sy buljuny
\sy yurlurriny
\sc Acanthophis praelongus
\so RJ: MCCONVELL_P08-014878
\pc death_adder.jpg
\ee This is a small snake that is very dangerous or 'guliyan'. It has a short prickle in the end of its tail. If it bites someone, they will be dead in a very short time. It lives in rocky areas, especially in caves called 'jarriny'. There is a song which stops the poison, and songs which clear the snakes away from camping areas. When they are killed they need to be chopped into pieces and burnt on a fire until they turn to ash, otherwise they can sing themselves back to health and kill you.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2008
\dt 14/Oct/2009

\lx buna
\sf buna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge ashes
\de ashes for tobacco
\sd E Food and Cooking
\dk ajij
\re ashes (for tobacco)
\va
\sy gawurn
\gr buna
\gg kawurn, puna, jani
\xv Durlwan mana Nanagu-lu buna-wu.
\xe Barbara is getting the bark for ashes.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.01aud: 2003
\sfx buna_IH_eg1_durlwan.mp3
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\pc
\cf ngunyjung
\cf warlayarra
\ee The bark from the walarri tree (ghost gum) makes the best ashes.
You collect dry bark from the tree or cut wet bark and leave it to dry in the sun. You burn the bark and use the whitest ashes for tobacco. You put the tobacco in your mouth to soften it up, then take it out and roll it in the tobacco. The ashes give the tobacco extra flavour and makes the nicotine stronger. 
\nt Buna is the proper Bilinarra word, and gawurn is the Gurindji word.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx Bunanggarni
\sf Bunanggarni_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge Vic.River.crossing 
\de Nangangari Dreaming place on the Victoria River crossing (near Pigeon Hole). The Nangangari danced here and made the parallel indentations in the rocky river bed. They also left their red ochre and ashes here, hence the name
\sd O Place Names
\re Victoria River crossing
\sy Jurrjurrarralarni
\so MCCONVELL_P08-014877
\pc 
\gp 736997E, 8140935N
\nt

\lx bungayarri
\sf bungayarri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bull
\de bull
\sd H Mammals
\re bull
\re Bos taurus
\re Bos indicus
\va
\sy
\sc Bos taurus
\sc Bos indicus
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\ee The meat is very good to eat after roasting. In recent times brahmans have become very common, before the 1980s there were not many brahmans and it was mainly shorthorns. The horns are called 'wirndurru' which is the same word for 'tree roots'. In the past the first settlers had very hairy cattle or woolly bullocks and these were called marrarnbarla. They no longer are seen in the area but are depicted in cave paintings.
\nt CHECK form
\dt 17/Jan/2008

\lx bunggiyid
\sf bunggiyid_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge euro
\de female rock or hill kangaroo, euro
\sd H Mammals
\re rock kangaroo
\re hill kangaroo
\re kangaroo (hill)
\re kangaroo (rock)
\re euro
\re Macropus robustus
\va
\sy
\sc Macropus robustus
\gr ngalijirri (antilopine), bunggayin (hill kangaroo)
\gg kumpang, pungkiyin
\so Ethnobiology LC080605BIL.PHmhbbca ~40:00
\pc euro.jpg
\ee These kangaroos are often seen in hilly areas and are good to roast and eat. They often have longish hair and can range in colour from dark grey to light grey to a bit reddish. This kangaroo is sometimes also called 'wumarangarna', which means rock-dweller and refers to its preferred habitat in rocky areas. The tendons, called 'gambun', from the tails are used to attach spear heads called 'yirlga' or axe heads called 'gurrwa' to shafts, and hooks called 'narra' to spear-throwers called 'warlmaya'. 
\dt 04/Jul/2008

\lx burijburij
\sf burijburij_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bendee
\de bendee
\sd M Plants
\re bendee
\re Terminalia bursarina
\va
\sy
\gr birijbirij
\gg pirijpirij
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050728bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\sc Terminalia bursarina
\pc burijburij.jpg
\ee This tree grows in creeks and riverbeds. You can eat the gum that is found on the stems and branches. It is called 'marnda'. It tastes like toffee and lasts for a long time. Chewing it makes your mouth froth and you get thirsty after you eat it. If the gum is very hard, you can place in the hot ashes of a fire for a few minutes. This softens the gum which can then be flattened with a stone or stick into small edible johnnycakes. The hard wood from larger trees can be used to make boomerangs called 'gurrubardu', fighting-sticks called 'guduru' and shields called 'mirda'. The timber is also good firewood.
\cf marnda
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv Yani-rnalu gan.garra wuyurrun.garra nganayirla-yirri Burlu-nggurra.
\xe We went upstream to Burlu to go fishing.
\rf CJ:Yarralin:KJ:Guwarlambarla:29July98
\so NLC: Bilinara (Coolibah-Wavehill Stock Route land Claim). May 1989. (Old Jimmy Manngayarri, Hector Wanayarri, Barry Young)
\so AAPA: Aboriginal Scared Sites within large vicinity of Pigeon Hole Outstation, 2003.
\gp 702500E, 8123400N
\nt CHECK. Turtle and echidna Dreaming? Confirmed by Horace Warlman and Kathleen Juduwurr.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx burrgarl
\sf burrgarl_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black.plum
\de black plum
\sd M Plants
\re black plum
\re Vitex glabrata
\va
\sy marralung
\sy muying
\sc Vitex glabrata
\gr muying
\gg muying, purrkarl
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc muying.jpg
\nt LC- this form hasn't been cited elsewhere, maybe check for currency...
\ee The black fruit are eaten when they are ripe. They are very sweet and tasty. Traditionally they are collected off the ground because picking fruit from the tree was said to cause eye disease. The fruit can also be pounded on a flat rock and made into small dampers, which are lightly roasted and are highly regarded as a food source. In the old days the dry sweet fruit was washed then cooked in bark or a coolamon with small hot flat rocks. The ripe juicy fruit was also washed then pounded on rocks before being eaten, particularly by people with bad teeth. The fruit are generally produced around the early wet season, but sometimes are available later in the year. When the firefly begins blinking its light, it indicates the fruit are ripe and ready to eat. The straight dry stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches. They are used to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method called 'binyinyib'. 
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx burrgi
\sf burrgi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge tree.goanna
\de tree goanna
\sd I Reptiles
\re tree goanna
\re goanna (tree)
\va
\sy bardi
\gr burrgi
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\re Varanus tristis
\sc Varanus tristis
\ee
\so 051130jk
\nt Found at Barrardarda (river gum Dreaming off Yarralin Road) on 051130, spotted in a
walarri tree eating ants.  If you kill this kind of goanna, you bleed from your nose. 
Speaker here was a woman visiting from Ligara, probably Jessie Kinyayi; this is
probably a Ngarinyman word, need to check if it is Bilinarra as well.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx burridijin
\sf burridijin_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge hornet
\de hornet or mudwasp
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re hornet
\re mudwasp
\re Hymenoptera spp
\sy burrmirimiri
\sc Hymenoptera spp
\re Vespidae spp
\re Delta spp
\sc Vespidae spp
\sc Delta spp
\pc Wasp.jpg
\ee These large black and yellow wasps make nests from mud collected from the edge of puddles, creeks and waterholes. They are 'cheeky' or 'guliyan' and can sting you. They sing when they find sugarbag (native bee-hives) called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' which contain honey.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx burrju
\sf burrju_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge march.fly
\de march fly
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re march fly
\re fly (march)
\re Diptera
\va
\sy
\sc Diptera
\re Tabanidae
\sc Tabanidae
\gr
\gg purrju
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(18:15-18:55, 19:20-19:25, 22:30-22:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(15:50-17:50)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc MarchFly.jpg
\nt 060123: elicited with picture of march fly; should compare form dinmirrimirri
collected before (probably NG form).
\nt 060124: you see these a lot when turtles and crocodiles are laying their eggs.
\ee These large flies can give a painful sting particularly around the lower leg called 'wulu' and ankles called 'dari', often when you are fishing. They are slow moving and easy to kill. When they bite, it indicates that crocodile and turtle eggs called 'gambij' are ready to collect and eat. When they stop biting it indicates the baby crocodiles called 'laging' are ready to hatch.
\sn 2
\ge sand.fly
\de sand fly
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sand fly
\re fly (sand)
\re Diptera spp
\va
\sy
\sc Diptera spp
\re Ceratopogonidae spp
\re Culicoides spp
\sc Ceratopogonidae spp
\sc Culicoides spp
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\ee These tiny insects are common around mangroves and saltwater areas and can cause bad itching at dawn, dusk and during the night. They are not known from inland areas.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx burrmirimiri
\sf burrmirimiri_SH.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge dragonfly
\de dragonfly
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re dragonfly
\re Odonata
\sy burrmiimii
\sc Odonata
\re Anisoptera
\sc Anisoptera
\gr bulmirimiri
\gg purrmiimii
\xv
\xe
\so Ethbobiology draft 2007
\nt LC-gurindji also used this word for helicopter.
\pc Dragonflies.jpg
\ee These insects look a little like helicopters and in the past helicopters often were given the same name. They are most commonly seen in the wet season and near springs called 'winyji'. Sometimes children use them for bait for fishing, but this can cause a headache. 
\nt LC- also given tentatively for mud wasp, needs checking with kj. Gur: purrtijin.
\sn 2
\ge hornet
\de hornet or mudwasp
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re hornet
\re mudwasp
\re Hymenoptera spp
\re Vespidae spp
\re Delta spp
\sy burridijin
\sc Hymenoptera spp
\sc Vespidae spp
\sc Delta spp
\pc Wasp.jpg
\ee These large black and yellow wasps make a nest from mud collected from the edge of puddles, creeks and waterholes. They are 'cheeky' or 'guliyan' and can sting you. They sing when they find sugarbag (native bee-hives) called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' which contain honey.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx burrngun
\sf burrngun_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge sugarleaf
\de sugarleaf from river red gum or 'dimarlan'
\sd E Food and Cooking
\sd M Plants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarleaf (river red gum)
\re river red gum sugarleaf
\re lerps
\re Hemiptera
\re Psyllidae
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Psyllidae
\so 050728bb,mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Lerps.jpg
\nt LC- formerly glossed as being from bloodwood (which is nangjarrna)
\cf nanyjarrnga
\cf malngana
\cf dimarlarn
\ee These small white scale-like insect-coverings are collected off the leaves of a river red gum called 'dimarlarn' during the early part of the dry season, when the first smoke or 'gabarru' is in the air. They are very sweet and tasty. The branches and twigs are broken off and left to dry over a calico sheet called a 'balginy'. The lerps are knocked off the leaves with a stick and then collected and shaped into small johnnycakes or biscuits and eaten. These can also be stored in cake-tins for weeks and months.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx dagudbari
\sf dagudbari_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge sulphur-crested.cockatoo
\de sulphur-crested cockatoo
\sd J Birds
\re sulphur-crested cockatoo
\re cockatoo (sulphur-crested)
\re Cacatua galerita
\va
\sy yarrgan.gurna
\sc Cacatua galerita
\gr barangarra, laba, ngarnalang
\gg ngarnarlang
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_02ih:(22:40-25:35)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(18:25-21:10)
\pc Sulphur_Crested_Cocky.jpg
\nt Earlier sessions on the ethnobiology proj had this as white cockatoo. bb and mh 080606 gave this as sulphur-crested cockatoo.
\nt LC- after several sessions on Bil and Gur birds these birds are still mixed up and people differ in opinions. Gur are now saying takutpari is Pink Cockatoo.
\ee In the past people used to eat them. They were hunted
with a boomerang called 'gurrubardu' or stone called 'wumara', and were cooked on hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'. The feathers are used in some women's ceremonies. This bird calls out 'yagga yagga yagga yagga'. These birds are also sometimes called 'bangarra'.
\dt 03/Jul/2008

\lx Daguragu

\va

\xe They are coming here from Daguragu.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (4:49)

\lx dalwag
\sf dalwag_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge rock.cod
\de rock cod, sleepy cod
\sd K Water Animals
\re rock cod
\re sleepy cod
\re Oxyeleotris lineolata
\re Oxyeleotris selheimi
\sc Oxyeleotris lineolata
\sc Oxyeleotris selheimi
\gr dalwag
\gg talwak
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(00:35-00:50)
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(9:30-10:30, 13:15-13:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(29:15-30:10)
\pc sleepy_cod1.jpg
\nt 060124 elicited with picture of rock cod.  Put on babies' heads to make them sleep.
\ee These slow moving fish live in the deep waterholes. They sleep all day on the bottom or under rock ledges. The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals, however, it is not really tasty. Sometimes they can be caught in large numbers and they can get quite big. These fish can be placed in a coolamon called a 'gawarla' under babies that are having trouble sleeping, and it will make them sleep better.
\dt 28/Apr/2008

\lx damarra
\sf damarra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge antbed
\de antbed, termite mound
\sd G Environment
\re antbed
\re termite mound
\va
\sy mardumardu
\gr damarra
\gg tamarra
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc Antbed.jpg
\ee Termite mounds are used in bush medicine. The fine soil from inside the ant hill is used to treat diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. The inner soil is heated on a fire and then added to water. This is allowed the grass bits settle out before it is drunk. This drink also promotes milk for nursing mothers. It is also used when 'cooking' babies to strengthen their body. Newborns are slathered in a mix of wet antbed and 'mirndiwirri' to close their fontanelle. The 'mirndiwirri' is burnt down and mixed with the crushed and heated antbed. Around the age of one, mothers 'cook'  babies' lower backs and legs in the same mixture to help them start walking. Antbed is also placed over a fire with water and the baby is held in the smoke and steam. This makes the baby physically strong in later life. Antbed is also used in conjunction with other bush medicines including 'warrwa'. 'Warrwa' is added to the wet slurry after the antbed has been heated up. This is a dryer mixture. Ground sugarbag called 'nanggalij' is often found in termite mounds, especially the large rounded mounds. In the past the larger mounds were hollowed out in the centre and you could sit in them during heavy rain periods and stay dry. Porcupines (echidnas) called 'jungguwurru' are sometimes found camped in the holes in termite mounds. They like to eat the termites inside.
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_05ih:(2:55-7:30)
\nt This name is more commonly used in Gurindji. 'mardumardu' is the more commonly used word in Bilinarra.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx danyan
\sf danyan_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spangled.perch
\de spangled perch, usually bait fish.
\sd K Water Animals
\re spangled perch
\re perch (spangled)
\re bait fish
\re Leiopotherapon unicolor
\va
\sy dawujban
\sc Leiopotherapon unicolor
\gr danyan
\gg tanyan
\xv Nalyirri-nggu wuyurrun.garra nyila-ma danyan-gu yuwarra-rla.
\xe Nalyirri is fishing for bait fish.
\rf I. Hector. 2002. Wuyurrun.garra. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(19:20 - 19:35, 20:40, 21:35)
\so 050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(00:00 - 00:15, 1:05 - 1:10, 3:25, 12:45-12:55)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(33:20-33:50)
\pc danyan.jpg
\ee This fish is common in waterholes on rivers or 'lamarn' and creeks called 'bin.ga' and in springs or 'winyji'. It is often quite small and used as bait to catch bigger fish, especially barramundi called 'yinarrwa'. The larger ones can be roasted on hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra', and the meat is very tasty. Sometimes the flesh contains small worms, especially when the fish are in small waterholes. They need to be well cooked to kill the worms. They are often found in milky or muddy water areas.
\nt 060124 elicited with picture of spangled perch
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx darrmard
\sf darrmard_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge freshwater.crocodile
\de freshwater crocodile
\sd I Reptiles
\re crocodile (freshwater)
\re freshwater crocodile
\re Crocodylus johnstoni
\va
\sy gangarndayawung
\sy warrija
\sc Crocodylus johnstoni
\gr warrija
\gg warrija, kangarntayawung, lirrayawung, nakakany, purruyurl (large ones)
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc freshwater_croc.jpg
\ee They are often caught on hand-lines or 'wuyurrun', and they can be hit over the head with a crowbar to kill them. In the past the men used to hunt them with spears with stone points, and they were eaten more commonly than they are now. The tail meat is the tastiest part and is eaten in preference to the rest of the meat. To cook it, the stomach is opened by cutting from under the front leg, down the side and under the stomach and the intestines are removed from the gut cavity. This is then filled with heated rocks and the body and tail are then roasted in hot coals and ashes in a cooking process called 'wubgarra' or cooked in a ground oven called 'durdurl'. The meat is skinned before eating. The small hatchlings are called 'laging'. The mother crocodile sometimes takes these babies from the nest in the sand to the water by carrying them in her mouth. The eggs are also eaten after boiling in water or cooking in hot sand. The tracks of the mother are followed to the nest and the sand dug out and the eggs collected. The eggs are ready to be collected during the hot weather time when the jangarla tree produces its large white flowers. Another indication that the eggs are ready to be collected are when the march flies or 'burrju' start biting. Another way to tell the eggs are ready is when there is a cloudy look about the Southern Cross stars. The name 'gangarndayawung' refers to their big teeth.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx darrng
\sf darrng_CA.mp3
\ps cv
\ge trip.over
\de trip over
\sd P Moving
\re trip over
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg nanpurrng
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FM:PigeonHole:BB,MH,CA:FM094_a095:3Jul08
\nt
\se darrng waninya
\de trip over
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx darru
\sf darru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spider
\de spider
\so 050517ih
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re spider
\re Arachnida
\sy yumbu
\sy garrada
\sc Arachnida
\re Araneae
\sc Araneae
\gr darru, garra, marawun
\gg tarru, yumpu
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_07ih:(19:15-21:05, 22:00-23:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_03ih:(00:05-1:25)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc spider.jpg
\ee All spiders have the same name though many different types of spider are recognised and some are dangerous. Some of the larger spiders live in burrows in the ground. Others live in webs. Spider webs are used in certain ceremonies and have important Dreamtime stories associated with them. In Bilinarra country there is a place called Wuna where you can see flat river rocks with red striations. These striations were left by a 'darru' who dragged its web across the rock. This is the same place where the husbands of the Nangangari women made 'wirrgala' (hairstring belts).
\nt CHECK RN has darruja. Dreaming site at Wuna.  Spider made the hairbelt (wirrgala) used in initiation ceremony for young men.
\nt LC- darru is the most common of the synonyms.
\dt 30/Apr/2008

\lx dawirrjib
\sf dawirrjib_CA.mp3
\ps cv
\ge throw.stone
\de throw stones, pelt
\sd T Impact
\sd U Holding and Taking
\dk jakim
\re throw stone
\re pelt
\re stone (throw)
\re rock (throw)
\re hit (with stones)
\va
\sy
\gr dawujib
\gg tawirrjip, tawirr
\so FM:PigeonHole:BB,MH:FM07_a064:25Jan08
\pc throw_stone.jpg
\nt
\se dawirrjib barra
\de hit with stones
\xv Gudini, barru-rna nyila warlagu dawirrjib.
\xe Hang on, I'll pelt that dog with a stone.
\rf IH: RN90-014a: 10:37min
\sfx dawirrjib_IH_eg1_gudini.mp3
\xv Nyila-ma-rnayina dawirrjib-barla bani gula-yilu gurru nyanya.
\xe I threw stones at them [because] they didn't listen to me.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (6-7)
\se dawirrjib yuwarra
\de throw stones, pelt
\xv Wumara yuwarra dawirrjib.
\xe He's throwing stones.
\rf IH: RN90-010b: 06:24min
\sfx dawirrjib_IH_eg3_wumara.mp3
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx dawujban
\sf dawujban_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spangled.perch
\de spangled perch
\sd K Water Animals
\re bait fish
\re spangled perch
\re perch (spangled)
\va
\sy danyan
\gr dawujban, danyan, danding
\gg danyan
\xv
\xe
\rf
\re Leiopotherapon unicolor
\sc Leiopotherapon unicolor
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\pc danyan.jpg
\ee This fish is common in waterholes on rivers or 'lamarn' and creeks called 'bin.ga' and in springs or 'winyji'. It is often quite small and used as bait to catch bigger fish, especially barramundi called 'yinarrwa'. The larger ones can be roasted on hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra', and the meat is very tasty. Sometimes the flesh contains small worms, especially when the fish are in small waterholes. They need to be well cooked to kill the worms. They are often found in milky or muddy water areas.
\nt LC- not in ethno work, check if same as or similar to danyan (spangled perch)
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx dibirl

\sd M Plants
\re hill black currant

\va
\sy
\sc Antidesma parviflora

\gg wutpul
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 051130bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf marnambarran
\nt grows around Birliwabgarri, also found around Katherine
\ee This small tree grows on rocky areas and stony slopes. It has small leaves. The fruit are eaten when they turn dark red to purple. They are sweet and stain your tongue and lips purple. 
\sn 2
\ge bush.plum
\de bush plum
\sd M Plants
\re bush plum
\re plum (bush)
\re Grewia retusifolia
\va
\sy
\sc Grewia retusifolia
\pc dibirl.jpg
\ee The brown shiny fruit taste are eaten by humans, bush turkeys called 'jamud' and emus called 'yibarrardu'. The leaves are used in bush medicine. They are boiled and the liquid is used as a medicinal wash to treat skin sores called 'marndara'.

\lx dijuna
\sf dijuna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black.flying.fox
\de black flying fox
\sd H Mammals
\re flying fox (black)
\re black flying fox
\re Pteropus alecto
\va
\sy
\sc Pteropus alecto
\gr garrabula, warrba
\gg tijuna, warrpawurru
\xv
\xe
\cf warrbawurru
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(6:00-7:15, 9:55, 10:05)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(16:50-17:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(4:35-5:20)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\dg black flying-fox, {Pteropus alecto?}, cf. warrpawurru
\nt Mildred says this is the real Bilinarra word for bat/flying fox--some school program
materials had this as 'warrbayang', which she said means 'clothes' (warrba at least
does).  Ivy says this one lives in river country.
\nt 060209 Ivy says flesh used to be used for fishing.
\nt LC- warrbawurru is generic for bats.
\pc Black_flying_fox.jpg
\ee Dijuna live in river country areas and are more common in the northern areas. They like to eat flowers called 'yirna', especially from bagarli. They also like the fruit of 'nambula' (cluster fig) and 'nyimili' (Leichardt tree). In the past they were killed by throwing hunting sticks into the roosting colonies. The flesh was roasted and eaten. It had a strong distinctive smell and taste. Crocodiles called 'warrija' eat them when they roost in paperbark trees hanging over rivers called 'lamarn' and billabongs called 'langgarna'. This is also a good place to fish as there are many fish under the colonies.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\sy

\de play a didgeridoo

\lx dilji
\sf dilji_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge swamp.lignum
\de swamp lignum
\sd M Plants
\re swamp lignum
\re Muehlenbeckia florulenta
\va
\sy
\sc Muehlenbeckia florulenta
\gr
\gg tilji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee Flowering indicates a good time to hunt for long-necked turtle called 'wayiwarrang' as they will be fat. The flowers are also eaten by ducks.
\sn 1
\ge spring.grass
\de spring grass
\sd M Plants
\re spring grass
\re Cyperus vaginatus
\va
\sy
\sc Cyperus vaginatus
\ee This plant grows in spring country often in shady areas. In the past it was used as a medicinal wash for treating congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' but it has not been used for a long time. Plants such as 'dimarlarn', 'jumunyjumuny', 'manyanyi' and 'gubuwubu' are now used.

\lx dimarlarn
\sf dimarlarn_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge river.red.gum
\de river red gum
\sd M Plants
\re river red gum
\re gum (river red)
\re Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\va
\sy marlarn
\sc Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\gr dimalarn
\gg malarn
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so CJcorpus:Yarralin:KJ:Garndi_names:8/5/95
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(21:45)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt 051123: Also used in making a ground oven (either on the bottom of the hole, or on
top of the meat before adding ground?)
\pc dimarlarn.jpg
\ee The leaves are used in bush medicine. You boil the new leaves until the water goes cloudy. The liquid is used as a wash to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya', skin problems and coughs called 'gulyurrg'. A small amount may also be drunk to treat coughing. This liquid has a good smell like Vicks. The leaves may also be placed on a burnt down fire to produce smoke. The patient is then rubbed with fat and wafted with the smoke. This heals the person by passing the smell of the tree over them. Babies and small children are held over the smoking leaves. The leaves can be used as fish poison. Small branches and twigs are thrown onto small waterholes, or the branches are dragged through the water. The fish become 'drunk' and float to the surface, where they can be easily collected, cooked and eaten. The leaves can also be added to any meat being cooked in a ground oven. They keep the meat moist and they give the meat a good flavour. Bush turkeys called 'jamud' can be stuffed with the leaves prior to cooking. Small leafy branches can also be spread on the ground to keep meat clean while it is being prepared and after it is cooked. Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. The wood also makes good firewood. Witchetty grubs called 'lamawurd' can also be found in the lower trunk of this tree. The sugar-leaf, a sweet edible insect, collected from this tree is called 'burrngun'.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\ps n

\sd M Plants

\lx dirnung
\sf dirnung_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge sap
\de sap from bloodwood tree
\sd M Plants
\re sap from bloodwood
\va
\sy nganyiwan
\sc
\gr
\gg tirnung

\xe
\rf
\so 060124ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt CHECK form 060124 makes a good medicine for sores
\ee This sap is used in bush medicine. You can place the red sap directly onto an aching tooth and it stops the pain. You can also boil it in water and use the liquid to wash skin sores.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx dirrag
\sf dirrag_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black.cockatoo
\de red-tailed black cockatoo
\sd J Birds
\re black cockatoo (red-tailed)
\re cockatoo (red-tailed black)
\re Calyptorhynchus banksii
\va
\sy walugbin
\sc Calyptorhynchus banksii
\gr
\gg tirrak, warlukpiny, tinkana 
\so 060209ih
\pc red_tailed_black_cockatoo.jpg
\ee The red feathers from the tails of the male birds are used in some ceremonies. These cockatoos like to eat the fruit from 'marndayag' and 'bardigi'. They have very strong beaks, sometimes they are kept as pets. They call out 'dirrag ... dirrag' and one of their names is based on this sound.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx diwurru
\sf diwurru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge long.tom
\de long tom
\sd K Water Animals
\re long tom
\re Strongylura krefftii
\sy jurrgurnduj
\sy bunumarnda
\sy jidjijuwal
\sc Strongylura krefftii
\gr diwurru, jurrgunduj
\gg tiwurru, jidjijuwal, punumarnta
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(12:30, 13:15 - 13:25)
\so 050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(1:35 - 1:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(34:40-35:05)
\ee The flesh from larger fish can be roasted and eaten. It is tasty but has a lot of bones. The smaller fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. This fish is recognised for its long pointy nose, as recognised in the name jidji-juwal (nose-long).
\nt 050922 Ivy says same as jurrgunduj (long tom), elicited with pix of both long tom
and mullet
\nt 060124 Ivy isn't sure that it's the same as jurrgunduj, this latter she says is the same as
bunumarnda (bulumarnda), thinks diwurru might be different.  This was probably
with stimulus picture of long tom.

\lx dugu
\sf dugu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge mussel
\de freshwater mussel from billabongs
\sd E Food and Cooking
\sd K Water Animals
\re mussel (billabong)
\re Velesunio wilsonii
\va
\sy wijalngarniny
\sy naribu
\sc Velesunio wilsonii
\gr daga, narubu
\gg tuku, murrunkirn, narupu, turta, wijalngarniny
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_04ih:(00:50)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(27:25-30:45)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc mussel.jpg
\ee This short, solid mussel is found in the mud at the edges of billabongs called 'langgarna'. They are roasted on hot coals and eaten. Mussels cannot be eaten by boys; men can only eat them after they have been initiated. The meat can also be boiled in water with a little salt and made into soup called 'yingalg' and this can be drunk to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' and diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. The juice from mussels can also be used to treat ear aches and infections. It is dripped straight into the ear.
\cf jiwirrirri
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx durdurl
\sf durdurl_SH.mp3
\ps cv
\ge bake
\de bake, cook in the earth
\sd E Food and Cooking
\re bake
\re cook (in ground)
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg rturturl
\rf FM:PigeonHole:IH:BIL05aud:04/12/03
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_02ih:(22:55)
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_05ih:(1:25, 3:10)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_02ih:(07:54, 08:57 - 09:02)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(21:10-22:00)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(28:10)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(4:00-4:50)
\pc
\cf
\ee This style of cooking involves digging a hole and making a fire in the hole. When the fire dies down, you put meat in the hole and cover it with hot stones and paperbark. You can cook potatoes and onions in with the meat. You can also put hot stones inside the animal while it is cooking.
For small animals, stones are not needed. Ashes and the hot ground will cook them.
\nt 051123: Excellent description of this process JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih 21:10-22:00.
\se durdurl gambala
\de bake
\xv Wurruja mirndiwirri, mana-wula garu-wu, birrga man.gu-wula buba, jurrbara-lu-ma gambawu-yinangulu durdurl garu-ma, mirndiwirri-du-ma.
\xe Those two get the dry mirndiwirri wood for the kids, and they will make a fire to cook them in the mix of hot earth and mirndiwirri ashes.
\se durdurdul
\de bake many things
\se durdurdularra
\de baking many things or many times
\xv Marluga-lu-ma jawurd gird barra durdurdularra-wu
\xe The man breaks the tail off for cooking in the coals.
\rf FM:PigeonHole:BB,MH:FM08_a094:2Jul08
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx gagawirli
\sf gagawirli_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge long.yam
\de long yam
\sd M Plants
\re long yam
\re yam (long)
\re Dioscorea transversa
\va
\sy
\sc Dioscorea transversa
\gr gagawurli
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\so MCCONVELL_P08-014876
\pc discorea_transversa.jpg
\ee This is a Ngarinyman word. The long yam can be dug up and then lightly roasted before eating. These yams can get up to about 30 cm long and the flesh is very tasty and pleasant to eat. They are common around Timber Creek and Bulla areas, but are not known from more southern areas.

\lx gajguru
\sf gajguru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge pandanus
\de river pandanus
\sd M Plants
\re pandanus (river)
\re river pandanus
\re Pandanus aquaticus
\va
\sy jangawa
\sc Pandanus aquaticus
\gr jangawa
\gg jangawa, kajkuru
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc pandanus.jpg
\nt LC- child medicine, roots and stums are put on the fire till hot and formed into a bed with warm sand and water. it makes the baby strong.
\ee The fruit are eaten by black bream called 'jamanmaya' and turtles called 'guwarlambarla' when they break into small pieces and fall into the water. You can use the roots and stems of this plant as medicine. The roots and dried stems are put on the fire until they are hot. They are then formed into a bed with warm sand and water and a small baby is placed on it. This makes the baby strong and healthy.
\cf jangambala
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx gajiwa
\sf gajiwa_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge corkwood
\de corkwood
\sd M Plants
\re corkwood
\re Erythrina vespertilio
\va
\sy
\sc Erythrina vespertilio
\gr
\gg kajiwa
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This tree grows by the river. The flowers indicate that freshwater crocodiles or 'warrija' are laying eggs and that they will be ready to collect and eat soon. You can use the pale light weight timber to make spear-thrower shafts called 'warlmayi' and coolamons called 'gawarla'. You can also rub the soot from the burnt bark onto the skin to make it look darker. People often rubbed this soot onto the light-skinned children in the old days to prevent them from being taken away. The red seeds can be used to make necklaces. 
\sn 2
\ge tree.sp
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Albizia canescens
\sc Albizia canescens
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee The pale, light weight timber can be used to make spear-thrower shafts called 'warlmayi' and coolamons called 'gawarla'.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\re kite (whistling)
\re Milvus sphenurus
\sc Milvus sphenurus
\gr galbun, garlban, gulugurra
\gg kalpun
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc Whistling_Kite.jpg
\ee Hawks whistle when they see something. They are often seen hunting near grass fires. They are able to pick up burning sticks and drop them in grassy areas to start and spread fires, so that there are more fires to hunt near. 
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx gamanggirr
\sf gamanggirr_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge cane.grass
\de cane grass or little bamboo
\sd M Plants
\re cane grass
\re little bamboo
\re Phragmites karka
\va
\sy
\sc Phragmites karka
\gr ngalnangga
\gg kamangkirr, rawurru
\xv
\xe
\pc pharagmites_vallatoria.jpg
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee The stems are used as shafts for three-pronged spears called 'rawurru'. These spears are used for hunting fish called 'yawu' and small game such as ducks. A spear-head of hard wood is added to the light shaft.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx gamanyji
\sf gamanyji_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bullwaddi
\de bullwaddi tree
\sd M Plants
\re bullwaddi
\re Macropteranthes kekwickii
\va
\sy
\sc Macropteranthes kekwickii
\gr
\gg kamanyji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\nt tree found at Windigunya and maybe one other place near PH community. 
Considered Dreaming tree (at least the one at Windigunya), can't cut it.  Common on
Buntine Hwy on way north to Vic Hwy.  
\ee The wood of this tree is hard and strong. It can be used to make boomerangs called 'gurrubardu', shields called 'mirda' and fighting sticks called 'guduru'. The timber makes excellent firewood. The bark can be burnt to make tobacco ashes called 'buna'. There is a group of bulwaddi trees at Windigunya which are Nangangari Dreaming trees. They left some 'jirri' (love potion) here and then went underground emerging in Mudbura country.
\cf Windigunya
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx gamara
\sf gamara_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge long.yam
\de blacksoil long yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (blacksoil)
\re long yam
\re blacksoil yam
\re Ipomoea diamantinensis
\va
\sy
\sc Ipomoea diamantinensis
\gr gamara
\gg kamara
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc gamara.jpg
\nt LC- check for name of the young sweet ones. ('julu' in GUR)
\ee They grow in blacksoil and are best dug up soon after the wet season. They are roasted in hot coals and eaten. In the old days, the small sweet and tasty yams were called 'julu' which also refers to navels. These days the young yams are called 'bilyily', which is a more general word for anything young. These are like baby carrots and are probably the first year tubers that are tender. They are attached to the trailing branches of the vine.
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx gambangayi
\sf gambangayi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge firefly
\de firefly
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re firefly
\re Coleoptera
\re Lampyridae
\re Luciola
\sc Coleoptera
\sc Lampyridae
\sc Luciola
\gr
\gg kampangayi, pinyjiwunarra 
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Firefly.jpg
\ee This small insect can be seen at night. It has a blinking light in its body. When they blink at night it indicates that conkerberries called 'ngamanburru' and black plums called 'muying' have fruit and are ready to eat.

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc
\cf mardiya
\ee This tree grows on stony slopes and has grey coloured leaves. You can chew the gum from this tree. It is called 'mardiya'. You can spot the gum from a long way off because it sparkles in the sun. You can also use the wood to make fighting sticks called 'guduru'.

\lx ganamarurru
\sf ganamururru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge mosquito
\de mosquito (big)
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re mosquito (big)
\re Diptera
\re Culicidae
\va
\sy ginarli
\sc
\gr gurrang, wamajngarna, miril, bayarnimiril
\gg kanamarrurru, kirnali
\sc Diptera
\sc Culicidae
\pc Mosquito.jpg
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(16:45-18:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(15:15-16:15)
\ee Mosquitoes are often active at dawn and dusk and they suck your blood which is called 'gungulu'. They can be chased away by lighting a smoky fire or by placing dry manure from horses or cattle on the coals. The smoke from burning gutta-percha or 'manyingila' and conkerberry called 'ngamanburru' is especially good for repelling mosquitoes. The activity of mosquitoes, including their noise and bite, is referred to as 'ngiing'. There is a Mosquito Dreaming site near the Nitjpurru (Pigeon Hole) turnoff along the highway which is a cluster of small stony hills.
\nt CHECK RN kanamurru
\dt 17/Jan/2008

\lx gangarndayawung
\sf gangardayawung_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge freshwater.crocodile
\de freshwater crocodile
\sd I Reptiles
\re crocodile (freshwater)
\re freshwater crocodile
\re Crocodylus johnstoni
\va
\sy warrija
\sy darrmard
\sc Crocodylus johnstoni
\gr warrija
\gg warrija, kangarntayawung, lirrayawung, nakakany, purruyurl (large ones)
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc freshwater_croc.jpg
\ee In the past the men used to hunt them with spears with stone points, and they were eaten more commonly than they are now. The tail meat is the tastiest part and is eaten in preference to the rest of the meat. The stomach is opened by cutting from under the front leg, down the side and under the stomach and the intestines are removed from the gut cavity. This is then filled with heated rocks and the body and tail are then roasted in hot coals and ashes in a cooking process called 'wubgarra' or cooked in a ground oven called 'durdurl'. The meat is skinned before eating. The small hatchlings are called 'laging'. The mother crocodile sometimes takes these babies from the nest in the sand to the water by carrying them in her mouth. The eggs are also eaten after boiling in water or cooking in hot sand. The tracks of the mother are followed to the nest and the sand dug out and the eggs collected. The eggs are ready to be collected during the hot weather time when the jangarla tree produces its large white flowers. Another indication that the eggs are ready to be collected are when the march flies or 'burrju' start biting. Another way to tell the eggs are ready is when there is a cloudy look about the Southern Cross stars. The name 'gangarndayawung' refers to their big teeth.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx ganggulanga
\sf ganggulanga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge curry.orange
\de curry orange or plum trees and their fruit
\sd M Plants
\re curry orange
\re plum
\re Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\sy garrajgarraj
\sy madarrgu
\sc Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\gr garrajgarraj
\gg karrajkarraj
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc curry.orange.jpg
\ee The fruit ripen  during cold weather time. The fruit are brown,  sweet and tasty. The pulp is eaten but the seeds and skin are spat out. The fruit can also be collected from the ground when they are dry. If the fruit are bitter they can be boiled in water with sugar to make them sweet. Another way of preparing them is to warm them on the hot coals. They are also cooked wrapped with 'marlin' or 'nalij' (green water weed). This moistens them and makes them nicer to eat. If there are lots of unripe fruit they can be lightly cooked in a ground oven to make them ripen quickly. The leafy, rounded canopy provides dense, cool shade. The timber can be used as firewood.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx garil
\sf garil_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge cucumber
\de bush cucumber
\sd M Plants
\re cucumber (bush)
\re bush cucumber
\re Cucumis melo
\va
\sy gawujin
\sc Cucumis melo
\cf girdbarn
\pc cucumis_melo.jpg
\ee This plant is recognised as being similar to 'girdbarn', but it has very different qualities and the fruit are smaller and sweet tasting. You can eat the fruit when they are ripe, light green. The fruit must be rubbed before eating to remove any short hairs that may be on the outside. If these are not removed the lips and tongue can become sore and painful. The fruit have sweet taste and crispy texture when ripe. When fully ripe they have a strong sweet fruity smell. Sometimes the fruit are mixed with sugar and then eaten. When the pheasant coucal 'girribudbudda' calls, he is singing to this plant to make it produce more fruit. 
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\gg karlawarr
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_04ih:(8:55-9:45, 10:25-10:40)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(13:40)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_02ih:(6:30-8:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(13:15)
\nt bird with white wing and red neck.  051123: elicited with picture of Pacific baza, but that might have been mistaken for a spinifex pigeon, again elicited with picture of spinifex pigeon.  Could be garlawarl?
\nt 060124 Ivy mistakes for yawarrwarl (yawarlwarl) in recording
\ee The spinifex pigeon is sometimes called the indian-head pigeon because of the feathers sticking up from its head. He calls out 'coo.coo....coo.coo....coo.coo'. The meat is roasted on hot coals and eaten. This pigeon only lands on the ground or on ant-beds called 'mardumardu'. It never perches in trees.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx garlin
\sf garlin_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\va
\sy
\re Vachellia pachyphloia
\re Vachellia valida
\gr
\gg karlin
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\sc Vachellia pachyphloia
\sc Vachellia valida
\ee This is a good shade tree. You can chip the bark off and boil it in water. Once the liquid has cooled down, you use it as a wash to treat skin sores called 'marndara'. The gum that comes from damaged areas of the branches and trunks can be eaten. It is clear and has a sweet taste. The timber can be used to make boomerangs called 'gurrubardu' and fighting-sticks or 'guduru'.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\gg purrurru

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc lancewood.jpg
\ee The wood is hard, strong and dark in colour. It makes excellent firewood. The smoke from burning the wood repels mosquitoes. You can also use the wood for bough shelters, fence rails and fence posts. You can also use the wood for boomerangs, clap sticks, spear heads, shields and fighting sticks.

\lx garrada
\sf garrada_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spider
\de spider
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re spider
\re Arachnida
\va
\sy yumbu
\sy darru
\re Arachnida
\re Araneae
\sc Araneae
\sc Arachnida
\gr
\gg karrata
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc spider.jpg
\ee All spiders have the same name though many different types of spider are recognised and some are dangerous. Some of the larger spiders live in burrows in the ground. Others live in webs. Spider webs are used in certain ceremonies and have important Dreamtime stories associated with them. In Bilinarra country there is a place called Wuna where you can see flat river rocks with red striations. These striations were left by a 'darru' who dragged its web across the rock. This is the same place where the husbands of the Nangangari women made 'wirrgala' (hairstring belts).
\dt 11/Feb/2008

\lx garrajgarraj
\sf garrajgarraj_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge curry.orange
\de curry orange or plum trees and fruit
\sd M Plants
\re curry orange
\re plum
\re Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\va
\sy madarrgu
\sy ganggulanga
\sc Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\gr garrajgarraj
\gg karrajkarraj
\rf I. Hector. 2002. Nyampa Nyawa Garndi. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so 050428ih
\so 050518mh
\so 050608ih,bb
\so 050913ih
\so 051130bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc garrajgarraj.jpg
\nt bush plum (050608ih), "like a plum" (050913ih), 051130 fruit comes at start of wet
season
\ee The fruit ripen during cold weather time. The fruit are brown, sweet and tasty. The pulp is eaten but the seeds and skin are spat out. The fruit can also be collected from the ground when they are dry. If the fruit are bitter they can be boiled in water with sugar to make them sweet. Another way of preparing them is to warm them on the hot coals. They are also cooked wrapped with 'marlin' or 'nalij' (green water weed). This moistens them and makes them nicer to eat. If there are lots of unripe fruit they can be lightly cooked in a ground oven to make them ripen quickly. The leafy, rounded canopy provides dense, cool shade. The timber can be used as firewood.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx garralbinang
\sf garralbinang_SH.mp3

\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih: 1:45, 14:30, 14:55 - 15:05, 16:00, 19:40, 21:00)
\so 050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(15:55)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc glassfish.jpg
\ee These small fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. Larger ones can be eaten after roasting on hot coals and ashes, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'. They look like silver-coloured bream.

\pc squirrel_glider.jpg
\ee This small animal lives in hollow logs called 'gulundurru' and can glide from one tree to another. This animal is not known to current Gurindji or Bilinarra people, but the biocultural knowledge was recorded in the 1980s.

\lx Garrari
\sf Garrari_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de Nangangari Dreaming place. Black Range is a long sandstone range which can be viewed along the long road to Yarralin. It is a Nangangari Dreaming place. The women walked along the ridge and camped here. Later gardiya tried to bore a well in the hill, but the women would not give them water. This place has a sacred women's site which men cannot go to
\sd O Place Names
\re Black Range
\xv Yalangurlu-ma-lu yanirni gan.gula bardardaj Garrari.
