\lx garrgany
\sf garrgany_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge hawk
\de chickenhawk and large kites
\sd J Birds
\re kite
\re hawk
\re Milvus migrans
\sy
\va garrgulany
\sc Milvus migrans
\gr garrgan
\gg karrkany
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc chickenhawk.jpg
\ee These birds are commonly seen around the dry season grass fires looking for insects and lizards. This bird can make you into a traditional healer or witch-doctor. It does this by calling out 'garrg ... garrg' and throwing a small stick at you. This stick can then be used to heal a person by placing it on the part of the body causing problems. Both men and women can be traditional healers.

\lx garrmarninymarniny
\sf garrmarninymarniny_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge red-faced.turtle
\de red-faced turtle
\sd I Reptiles
\sd K Water Animals
\re red-faced turtle
\re turtle (red-faced)
\re Emydura victoriae
\va
\sy
\sc Emydura victoriae
\gr
\gg karrmaninymaniny
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_02ih:(11:05, 11:10, 11:20, 11:40, 12:25, 12:30)
\pc
\cf gurraj
\nt
\ee This turtle is generally caught on hand-lines called 'wuyurrun'. The meat is very tasty and highly sought after. They can also be caught by feeling around in the water in billabongs called 'langgarna' and slow moving parts of rivers. They are quite common and have a distinctive yellow or reddish stripe on their face. This turtle acts as a guard and messenger for the rainbow serpent called 'gurraj'. When you see it travelling across land away from water, it is an indication that the rainbow serpent is angry and a flood called a 'bulngayid' is coming. They have the colour from the rainbow serpent on their face. Some people don't harm these turtles because of their links to the rainbow serpent or 'Gurraj'.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx Garunya

\lx gawarla
\sf gawarla_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge coolamon
\de coolamon. Coolamons are made from 'ngimbija' or 'gulunjurru' trees. They are used for carrying babies. Smaller coolamons are used for carrying bush tucker and medicine.
\sd D Things
\dk
\re coolamon
\va
\sy
\gr gawarla
\gg kawarla, piyati (small coolamon), kartiyi (deep, wide coolamon)
\xv Ngayi-ma-rna burrb-ma birrgab mani nyawa gawarla.
\xe I finished making this coolamon.
\rf SH: FM08_a088: 21:42min
\sfx gawarla_SH_eg1_nyagi.mp3
\xv Larrba-ma-lu ganya gajijirri-lu-ma garu-ma gawarla-ngga julujuluj.
\xe Before the women carried their babies in coolamons.
\rf SH: FM08_a088: 28:11min
\sfx gawarla_SH_eg2_larrba.mp3
\xv Gawarla ngayiny-ju ngamayi-lu birrgab mani ngayiny-gu garu-wu.

\lx gawujin
\sf gawujin_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge cucumber
\de bush cucumber
\sd M Plants
\re cucumber (bush)
\re bush cucumber
\re Cucumis melo
\va
\sy garil
\sc Cucumis melo
\cf girdbarn
\pc cucumis_melo.jpg
\ee This plant is recognised as being similar to 'girdbarn', but it has very different qualities and the fruit are smaller and sweet tasting. You can eat the fruit when they are ripe, light green. The fruit must be rubbed before eating to remove any short hairs that may be on the outside. If these are not removed the lips and tongue can become sore and painful. The fruit have a sweet taste and crispy texture when ripe. When fully ripe they have a strong sweet fruity smell. Sometimes the fruit are mixed with sugar and then eaten. When the pheasant coucal 'girribudbudda' calls, he is singing to this plant to make it produce more fruit. 
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\gg kawulnga

\pc nankeen.jpg
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(24:55-26:05), Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This bird lives in thick bush near rivers and makes strange noises.
It always hides and is rarely seen. When you hear it calling that signals that danger is approaching.

\lx gawurlu
\sf gawurlu_CA.mp3
\sn 1
\ps n
\ge sister
\de sister, mother's sister's daughter. Opposite sex siblings cannot call each other's names after a brother goes through ceremony. They also cannot share the same shade and a brother cannot eat food prepared by his sister.
\sd B People
\re sister
\sy gabugu
\sy nyanawuwi
\xv Ngayiny-gu gawurlu-wu gurdurdu.
\xe My sister's child.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (4-28)
\xv Yan.gu-rnawula ngayiny gawurlu.
\xe We two will go, [me and] my sister.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (4-147)
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge nurse
\de nurse
\sd B People
\dk jija
\re nurse
\va
\sy
\gr gawurlu
\gg kawurlu, kapuku
\xv Gawurlu yanirni murlanggurra garrab-gu garu-walija.
\xe The nurse came here to examine all of the kids.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (6-51)

\lx gawurn
\sf gawurn_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge ashes
\de ashes for tobacco
\sd E Food and Cooking
\re ashes (for tobacco)
\va
\sy buna
\gr buna
\gg kawurn
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050505ih
\so 050707bb,mh
\so 051027ih,mg,bb
\pc
\cf walarri
\cf ngurrgurrgu
\ee The bark from the walarri tree (ghost gum) makes the best ashes.
You collect dry bark from the tree or cut wet bark and leave it to dry in the sun. You burn the bark and use the whitest ashes for tobacco.
You put the tobacco in your mouth to soften it up, then take it out and roll it in the tobacco. The ashes give the tobacco extra flavour. 
\nt
\cf ngurrgurrgu
\cf walarri
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx gilbugud
\sf gilbugud_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge goat
\de goat
\sd H Mammals
\re goat
\re billy goat
\re nanny goat
\re Capra hircus
\re
\va
\sy
\sc Capra hircus
\gr
\gg kilpukut
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft
\ee In the past, goats were kept on stations and at missions for the meat called 'ngarin' and milk called 'ngabulu'. In particular there was a small herd of them kept by the police at Wave Hill police station (at the current site of Kalkaringi police station). Gurindji people used to look after them for the police.
\nt LC- also use kriol words nenigut (nenigut) and biligut (billy goat)
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx gilibi
\sf gilibi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.banana
\de bush banana
\sd M Plants
\re bush banana
\re banana (bush)
\re Marsdenia australis
\re Marsdenia viridiflora
\va
\sy
\sc Marsdenia australis
\sc Marsdenia viridiflora
\gr gilibi
\gg kirlipi
\xv Mani-warla-lu nyila-ma gilibi-ma jag.
\xe They made the bananas fall down.
\rf SH: FM08_a091: 16:31min
\sfx gilibi_SH_eg1_mani.mp3
\so 050427bb
\so 051130bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf 
\pc gilibi.jpg
\ee The fruit and leaves may be eaten. They are sweet and tasty. The young fruit are the best to eat as they are soft and crunchy. Older fruit becomes hard and chewy though they may be softened by lightly roasting them on hot coals. The flowers can also be eaten. The leaves are also good for you and are like eating cabbage or lettuce. The small ones that are found in the heavy rain time of the wet season are called 'ngamurrurru'. They are small and round, and contain a lot of juice.
\nt LC- check for names of leaves, GUR pinti and yurtu, which are edible.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx gilirrwarla
\sf gilirrwarla_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spear.grass
\de spear grass
\sd M Plants
\re spear grass
\re grass (spear)
\re Sorghum intrans
\va
\sy
\sc Sorghum intrans
\gr marrud (speargrass)-not sure if same species
\gg kilirrwarla
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050427bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc gilirrwarla.jpg
\ee This grass forms large stands during the wet season. When the rains stop the stems dry off and become brown. When this grass is burnt during the early dry season, it cleans the country up and makes it healthy again. The roots of this grass are used to treat boils called 'garlaba'.

\lx ginarli
\sf ginarli_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge mosquito
\de small mosquito
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re mosquito (small)
\re Diptera
\re Culicidae
\va
\sy ganamurrumurru
\sc Diptera, Culicidae
\gr gurrang, wamajngarna, miril, bayarnimiril
\gg kanamarrurru, kirnali
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(16:45-18:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(15:15-16:15)
\nt CHECK RN kanamurru
\pc Mosquito.jpg
\ee Mosquitoes are often active at dawn and dusk and they suck your blood which is called 'gungulu'. They can be chased away by lighting a smoky fire or by placing dry manure from horses or cattle on the coals. The smoke from burning gutta-percha or 'manyingila' and conkerberry called 'ngamanburru' is especially good for repelling mosquitoes. The activity of mosquitoes, including their noise and bite, is referred to as 'ngiing'. There is a Mosquito Dreaming site near the Nitjpurru (Pigeon Hole) turnoff along the highway which is a cluster of small stony hills.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx ginygirridu
\sf ginygirridu_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge goose
\de green pygmy goose
\sd J Birds
\re goose
\va
\sy
\so 050510ih
\va
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(00:15-2:00, 2:35)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(8:20-10:10)
\nt might be anothe rname for 'whistling duck'?  051123 elicited with picture of green
pygmy goose.  Used to eat it in early days, cooked on coals.  Not clear that this one is
really the green pygmy goose--some question in recording about whether the one
pictured is from Bilinarra country.  Could be magpie goose as well (check recording),
notes say Ivy not sure of the name of magpie goose, which lives at billabong and river
and is eaten (body but not eggs), cooked on coals, looks like jamud  Might be -rdu?
\nt 060124 green pygmy goose.  Ivy says the ??Aboriginal name??for this one is jibilyigu,
not sure quite what she means here, but also seems to accept ginygirri(r)du.  ??This one
now melabat callim ginygirrirdu, an jibilyigu im really name.??Then she says of
ginygirrirdu ??Yeah, (is?) proper name, he got two name like. Jibilyigu im langa
country name.??

\lx ginyjirrga
\sf ginyjirrga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge kurrajong
\de red-flowered kurrajong
\sd M Plants
\re red-flowered kurrajong
\re kurrajong (red-flowered)
\re Brachychiton megaphyllus
\va
\sy miyaga
\sc Brachychiton megaphyllus
\gr ginjirrga
\gg kirnjirrka, miyaka
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050505ih
\so 050728bb,mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc ginyjirrga.jpg
\nt Species of tree growing in Yolngu yard.  Seeds edible, roast them.  NG form seems unrelated; GU dict also mentions 'kinyjirrka' as a variant of the kurrajong matrilineal
clan in entry for 'yimiyaka' (no separate head entry).  Barbara and Mildred confirm seeds are edible on 050728, crush with stone to eat them, many found at Lajamanu
and Top Springs.
\nt LC- miyaka given as GUR for this, not BIL syn in ethno work
\ee This plant has the same name as 'Brachychiton spectabilis' below, however it is a smaller tree that grows in a different habitat.
\sn 2
\ge kurrajong
\de red-flowered kurrajong
\sd M Plants
\re Brachychiton spectabilis
\va
\sy miyaga
\sc Brachychiton spectabilis
\gr ginjirrga
\gg kirnjirrka, miyaka
\ee This tree is also sometimes referred to using the Mudburra term 'miyaga'. When the sun sets in the mid dry season and turns red, like the colour of the flowers, and streaky, it indicates that the fruit are ready to be collected. The seeds inside the pod are edible, but not the hairs. The seeds are taken out of the large pod. They are then pounded, winnowed out in a coolamon called a 'gawarla', or burnt to get rid of the fine hairs. Finally they are crushed, eaten raw or made into johnnycakes. The skin of the inner pod of the fruit can also be rubbed on the skin to make it lighter like 'Mungamunga' (spirit women's) skin. 
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx ginyuwurra
\sf ginyuwurra_SH.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bush.onion
\de bush onion
\sd M Plants
\re bush onion
\re onion (bush)
\re Cyperus bulbosus
\va
\sy
\sc Cyperus bulbosus
\pc ginyuwurra.jpg
\gr yunurrbany
\gg kinyiwurra, jarrwana
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\ee These onions are eaten. They grow in patches called 'janangarn'. You can eat the small bulbs. You cook them in hot sand and then rub them between your hands to loosen the dark papery skin. Brolgas called 'gurrarndal' and kangaroos called 'jiya' also eat the small bulbs.
\sn 2
\ge sedge
\de sedge
\sd M Plants
\re sedge
\re Eleocharis brassii
\re Eleocharis sphacelata
\va
\sy
\sc Eleocharis brassii
\sc Eleocharis sphacelata
\ee The white lateral roots in the mud are dug up and eaten by kangaroos called 'jiya' and brolgas called 'gurrarndal'.
\sn 3
\ge plant.sp
\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\re
\va
\sy
\re Schoenoplectus praelongatus
\sc Schoenoplectus praelongatus
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\ee The roots are eaten by kangaroos called 'jiya' and brolgas called 'gurrarndal'.
\sn 3
\ge water.chestnut
\de water chestnut
\sd M Plants
\re water chestnut
\re chestnut (water)
\re Eleocharis dulcis
\va
\sy
\sc Eleocharis dulcis
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\ee The small chestnuts at the base of the stems can be collected and lightly roasted in hot ashes, they are then eaten.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx girdbarn
\sf girdbarn_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bitter. cucumber
\de bitter cucumber
\sd M Plants
\re cucumber (bitter)
\re bitter cucumber
\re Cucumis picrocarpus
\va
\sy
\sc Cucumis picrocarpus
\pc girdbarn.jpg
\ee These fruit may be used medicinally. Ripe fruit are gently rubbed and squeezed until the inner flesh becomes soft and pulpy. A small hole is made in the skin and the liquid squeezed out and rubbed onto skin disorders such as rashes and ringworm, or to use as eye-drops. This cucumber tastes bitter and grows on the plains country. The fruit can be eaten, but you have to wait until they ripen fully and they have a bitter taste. They are very similar to 'garil' but are larger and bitter tasting.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\rf AN: RN90-007a: 23:36min
\sfx gankgula_AN_eg5_girdigirdi.mp3

\lx giribi
\sf giribi_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge passionfruit
\de wild passion fruit (introduced)
\sd M Plants
\re passion fruit
\re Passiflora foetida
\sy
\sc Passiflora foetida
\gr gunbirdi
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc passionfruit.jpg
\ee This plant is introduced and it is often called 'gribi', which is not a proper language name but may derive from the English term 'creeper'. The inner flesh of the yellow-orange fruit can be eaten. It is especially favoured by children. Many birds also eat the fruit. The leaves can be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat scabies, itchy skin and ringworm. The leaves and stems can also be used as fish poison. They are dragged through the water and this has the effect of stunning the fish so that they float to the surface and can be easily collected, then cooked and eaten. The slightly sticky leaves and stems must not be put near your eyes as the juice can cause very sore eyes. 
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx girnirriny
\sf girnirriny_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge tree.snake
\de green tree snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re green tree snake
\re snake (green tree)
\re Dendrelaphis punctulata
\va
\sy
\sc Dendrelaphis punctulata
\gr girnirij
\gg kirnirriny
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_03ih:(12:10, 12:15, 12:25)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc green_tree_snake.jpg
\nt LC- Check if Bilinarra know story of Girnirriny and Jurndagarl swapping teeth.
\ee This is a quiet snake that lives in trees, especially pandanus called 'gajguru' and other trees near rivers and creeks called 'bin.ga'. It cannot hurt you but can give you a fright when it appears close to you when you are fishing. They like to eat frogs called 'ngalyja'. There is a Dreamtime story about this snake and why it is now harmless. In the Dreamtime this green tree snake had large poisonous fangs and the 'jurndagarl' (a mythical taipan-like snake) was harmless. Jurndagarl teased the green tree snake, until it opened its mouth and the fangs fell out. Jurndagarl grabbed the fangs and put in his own mouth. Now Jurndagarl is poisonous and the green tree snake is harmless. 
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx girrawa
\sf girrawa_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge goanna
\de goanna, particularly sand goannas
\sd I Reptiles
\dk guana
\re goanna
\va
\sy
\gr girriwa, warlgan
\gg kirrawa
\xv Wanyjiga-n bani nyila girrawa.
\xe Where did you kill that goanna?
\rf IH: RN fieldnotes 1990: 02:104
\xv Gula-rna magiliwarn-ma bani, nyawa-ma-rna girrawa-rni baraj bunya.
\xe I didn't kill kangaroo, I only found a goanna.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (5-62)
\re Varanus panoptes
\sc Varanus panoptes
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_02ih:(03:20, 14:45, 20:25, 20:40, 20:50, 21:05, 23:40)
\pc sand_goanna.jpg
\ee The term 'girrawa' can be used as general term for all goannas but is often applied to sand goannas. This goanna often digs deep holes and can be tracked to the holes and then dug out. Often the holes have to be dug very deep and a lot of work is required to get the goanna out. They are then roasted and eaten.
\nt LC- check extra gurindji words:  small goannas 'mirlapita' (Gur).  bit bigger ones, but too small to eat 'Kaniwurru' (Gur)
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx girrbirli
\sf girrbirli_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge tree.species
\de type of acacia
\sd M Plants 
\re
\cf lamawurd
\re Acacia acradenia
\sc Acacia acradenia
\ee This plant is used in bush medicine. The fruit and leaves are boiled in water and used as a wash to help children grow tall and walk strong. It can also be used to treat sore legs and hips, and sore muscles in general. Witchetty grubs called 'lamawurd' can be found at the base in the roots of the tree. They are found by spotting their excrement and are retrieved by twisting the roots around until they are revealed.
\dt 03/Aug/2012

\lx gubuwubu
\sf gubuwubu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge lemon.grass
\de lemon grass
\sd M Plants
\re lemon grass
\re Cymbopogon procerus
\sy
\va gububu
\re Eulalia aurea
\re Iseilema sp
\re Cymbopogon procerus
\sc Cymbopogon procerus
\sc Eulalia aurea
\sc Iseilema sp
\gr gububu
\gg gubuwubu, gububu
\xv Gubuwubu mana balangari-la garu-walija-wu gambarnu.
\xe She gets the lemon grass from the blacksoil country for treating kids.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.48: 2003
\sfx gubuwubu_IH_eg1_gubuwubu.mp3
\xv Mana gubuwubu ganggu-rnalu-nga ngurra-nggurra.
\xe She gets the lemon grass and we will bring it back to camp.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.49: 2003
\sfx gubuwubu_IH_eg2_mana.mp3
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\pc gubuwubu.jpg
\nt Bush medicine plant used for bathing when you have a cold.
\nt LC- two types recognised, one from blacksoil and the other from rocky country. Both have the same name.
\ee This grass is used in bush medicine. It has strong healing properties and is especially effective for small children. You boil the leaves and stems and wash itchy skin and boils called 'garlaba'. It is often boiled up in flour tins and small children are made to sit in the cooled liquid for some time. To treat colds you drink the tea.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\nt big pigeon found in river country.  GU dict lists 'kutkukutkuk' as a synonym under
marrparlangparlang and kuljara, glossed as above, but headword missing.  
\nt Mildred 051027 says when this bird sings out you can catch turtle and catfish. 
\nt 051123: elicited with pictures of emerald-shouldered dove (but this probably not from
Bilinarra country), partridge pigeon, bar-shouldered dove, gets its name from its song
"gudgu gudgu", when it sings out you know you can get turtle and fish, not eaten (this
last bit was offered for the partridge pigeon).  Tokens around 13:00
JS051123BIL.DAC_02ih sound like final -g variant.
\nt 060124 picture of bar-shouldered dove.  With picture of partridge pigeon, Ivy says it
looks like gudgugudgu but is different.
\nt LC- ethnobiology notes now just have this name for partridge pigeon, bar-shouldered and others

\lx guggug

\sd J Birds
\dk jukjuk
\re chicken
\re chook
\re Gallus gallus
\va

\sc Gallus gallus

\gg kukkuk
\pc chicken.jpg
\ee Many stations, missions and settlements used to keep chickens for the meat called 'ngarin' and eggs called 'gambij'. Water pythons used to get in to the chicken coops and eat them, and you could see the lumps in the snakes where the chickens were that they had eaten.

\lx gujibadawan
\sf gujibadawan_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge children's.python
\de children's python
\sd I Reptiles
\re children's python
\re python (children's)
\re Liasis childreni
\va
\sy
\sc Liasis childreni
\gr
\gg kujipartan
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc childrens_python.jpg
\nt LC- check if Bil has story about being teased about it's hair and goin off crying.
\ee This small python is considered to be the offspring of black-headed python or 'mulyuguna'. It has pretty markings on the skin and is also sometimes called a pie-bald snake. It is a quiet snake that can be picked up and handled. It is too small to be eaten. The name 'gujibadawan' refers to it having strong bones. It is not poisonous.
\dt 28/Apr/2008

\lx Gulibayarrbirr
\sf Gulibayarrbirr_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de This is a Nangangari Dreaming place on the Victoria River near Nitjpurru. This site used to have a standing tree and some rocks which were the Nangangari's children. However the tree was pushed down by floodwaters in 2001/02 and some of the rocks were washed downstream. Some were rescued and brought into the community because they were crying. But other twin rocks are still missing. Only women and girls are allowed to go here
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv
\xe
\rf I. Hector. Nangangari Dreaming video and booklet. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so FM:PigeonHole:IH:BIL04.track01.01aud:2003
\pc 
\gp 736851E, 8139326N
\nt CHECK pronunciation.
\dt 29/Apr/2008

\lx Gulija
\sf Gulija_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de rocky hill about 7km south of Pigeon Hole. Nangangari Dreaming place and Billy Campbell's outstation. The Mungamunga also came here. There are some good trees with bush honey here too
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv Gurlarra marluga-ma nyila-ma gurlarrag Gulija-ma-nginyi nyarruluny ngumbarna.
\xe Those old men went south to Gulija, their husbands, that is.
\rf IH: FM: BIL04.track01.01aud: 2003: 07:25min
\sfx gulija_IH_eg1_gurlarra.mp3
\so I. Hector. Nangangari Dreaming video and booklet. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC

\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx gulinyaga
\sf gulinyaga_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.orange
\de bush orange
\sd M Plants
\re bush orange
\re orange (bush)
\sy gurlardardi
\xv Nyawa-ma-rna yan.gu gulinyaga-wu. Yuwarru-rnayina-nga gardag-gula.
\xe I'm going [to get some] bush oranges.  I'll put them in the billy for them.
\rf Nordlinger grammar
\pc JS051130BIL.PIG_03 ; JS051130BIL.PIG_04
\re Capparis umbonata
\sc Capparis umbonata
\pc gurlardardi.jpg
\ee When the fruit ripen they go a slightly orange-yellow colour and have a strong pleasant smell which can be noticed from a long way away. You can eat the ripe fruit or you can bury the unripe fruit in the sand to help ripen them. Sometimes this might take as long as two weeks. The wood makes good firewood because it lights quickly. You can also use the bark as medicine for scabies called 'garangaji'. When the large flooding rains of the wet season are coming this plant can be used to chase the rains away. You can place the leaves on a fire and waft the smoke towards the rain clouds to make them go away.
\dt 19/Dec/2008

\lx guliyan
\sf guliyan_CA.mp3

\lx gulugurra
\sf gulugurra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge condys.plant
\de Condy's plant
\sd M Plants
\re Condy's plant
\re Senna oligoclada
\va
\sy
\sc Senna oligoclada
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This plant is used in bush medicine. You boil the leaves and use the liquid to treat skin sores. The liquid is a dark colour similar to a Condy's crystals mixture. You use this liquid to treat skin disorders such as itchy skin and boils called 'garlaba'. It may also be used to treat internal pain and muscle soreness.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx gulumarra
\sf gulumarra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge sandalwood
\de sandalwood
\sd M Plants
\re sandalwood
\re Santalum lanceolatum
\va
\sy
\sc Santalum lanceolatum
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc gulumarra.jpg
\ee The wood can be burnt to ash and this is mixed with water and then rubbed through the hair called 'gardbi' to make it go black. The bark of this tree is also scraped off and boiled up into a tea. The tea is used to treat many internal ailments such as cancer called 'guliyan' and kidney problems. The name 'gulumarra' has also been recorded for the plants Cardiospermum halicacabum, Dodonaea platyptera and Maytenus cunninghamii.
\nt LC- ngaliwurru eat fruit and use bark for medicine, but no uses listed for Bilinarra
\dt 14/Mar/2008

\lx Gulygulya
\sf gulygulya_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de Bad Cold Dreaming, sickness country. Two lots of rocks near each other. One small cluster is dark coloured. It is very dangerous. It will make you cough, then your eyes and tongue come out.  You must be very quiet when you go near it and you cannot touch it for fear of death. The bark of the 'lunyja' can cure you if you become sick. The larger group of rocks next to it is OK.
\sd O Place Names
\re Bad Cold Dreaming
\xv Wambal-barni galu yalangga-ma Gulygulya-ngga-ma.
\xe Walk quietly at the Badcold Dreaming.
\rf IH: FM: BIL01.track02.03: 2003: 18:45min
\sfx Gulygulya_IH_eg1_wambal.mp3
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\so I. Hector. Barrjirda Dreaming video and booklet. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\pc 
\gp 738068E, 8147466N (viewing from the top of the river bank)
\nt

\lx gulyjara
\sf gulyjara_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge dove
\de diamond dove
\sd J Birds
\re diamond dove
\re Geopelia cuneata
\re dove (diamond)
\va
\sc Geopelia cuneata
\gr gulyjarra
\gg kuljara
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_02ih:(11:35-12:50, 14:05-14:50)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_03ih:(12:40-13:05)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_02ih:(15:00-15:05)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(15:25-16:40)
\nt Small pigeon found in bush and river country.  
\nt 051123:  elicited with pictures of diamond dove and peaceful dove, later with oriental
cuckoo (but this one different, from different country, probably not a real example).
\nt 060124 picture of bar-shouldered dove, but then Ivy changed this to gudgugudgu

\lx gulyulyurra
\sf gulyulyurra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge budgerigar
\de budgerigar
\sd J Birds
\re budgerigar
\re Melopsittacus undulates
\sy ngurrawaji
\sc Melopsittacus undulates
\gr gumulyurrany
\gg kulyulyurra, kumuyurra
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_03ih:(4:00-5:20, 8:20-9:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(21:40-21:55) 
\pc budgerigar.jpg
\ee Budgerigars nest in hollow trees and often occur in large flocks. In the past they were hunted with throwing sticks during the dry season. The sticks would be thrown into the flocks and sometimes a large number of birds would be caught. These were lightly roasted and then eaten; the younger ones were tender and tasty. The young budgerigars were also collected from the hollow trees by widening the entry into the trees and reaching in and taking them out.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx gumbari
\sf gumbari_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge red.meat.ant
\de red meat ant
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re red meat ant
\re meat ant
\re ant (red meat)
\sy bingi
\va
\re Hymenoptera spp; Formicidae; Iridomyrmex purpureus group
\sc Hymenoptera spp; Formicidae; Iridomyrmex purpureus group
\gr
\gg kumpari

\cf birna
\ee The eggs called from inside the underground nests can be eaten; they are winnowed in a coolamon called a 'gawarla' to remove dust and grit and then eaten raw. The ants are attracted to food scraps when you are camping, especially beef or 'ngarin'.

\lx gumbulyu
\sf gumbulyu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge white.currant
\de white currant, white plum
\sd M Plants
\re white currant
\re white plum
\re Flueggea virosa
\va
\sy
\sc Flueggea virosa
\gr gumbulyu (white currant)
\gg kumpulyu (gooseberry growing on thorny tree)
\xv Ngayi-ma yana-rna warlagab gumbulyu-wu.
\xe Me, I'm going looking for white berries.
\rf Ivy and Sheila Hector. 2006. Wanyjiga-warla-n yana? Produced by L. Campbell for DAC
\so 050914bb,ih
\pc gumbulyu.jpg
\nt like ngamanburru
\ee The fruit ripens in the middle of wet season. You can use the stems for bush matches. You can also use the root to treat swelling. The young roots are cut from the tree, usually from the exposed roots on the side of riverbanks when the water level is low. The bark of the roots is then scraped off revealing the white root underneath. The bark should not be consumed. The white root is then boiled which causes the water to turns red. It can be drunk like this or mixed with tea. It is used to treat coughs called 'gulyurrg' and headaches. It is also used as a diaretic to treat swelling and to increase urine. It is especially good for people who have walked a long way and are tired and have swollen legs.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\re cockroach

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc bush_cockroach.jpg

\lx gunanduru
\sf gunanduru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.bean
\de bush bean
\sd M Plants
\re bush bean
\re Acacia maconochieana
\va
\sy
\sc Acacia maconochieana
\gr
\gg kunanturu
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee You can eat the seeds inside the green pods after lightly roasting the pods in hot coals and ashes. If the pods are dry you can collect them, place on a sheet and hit them with a stick to release the seeds. 
Afterwards you can collect the seeds and grind them into a coarse powder which you can eat. You can also use the hard timber to make boomerangs, fighting sticks and digging sticks. The wood also makes good firewood.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx gundidi
\sf gundidi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge plant.sp
\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\va
\sy
\re Cajanus crassicaulis
\sc Cajanus crassicaulis
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\ee This plant has no specific use.
\sn 2
\ge plant.species
\de bush tobacco plant
\sd M Plants
\re bush tobacco
\re tobacco (bush)
\re Cullen leucanthum
\va
\sy
\sc Cullen leucanthum
\gr
\gg kuntiti
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- check the species vs senses. two types? nothing about tobacco for the first ones.
\ee In the old days the leaves were dried and used as bush tobacco. The stems are used by children as toy arrows and spears.
\sn 3
\ge plant.sp
\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\va
\sy
\re Newcastelia spodiotricha
\sc Newcastelia spodiotricha
\ee The white, soft flowers can be used to fill pillows. In the past the flowers were collected in large amounts for pillows. The flowers were also used for body decoration. Children make toy spears and arrows from the straight stems.
\sn 4
\ge kapok.bush
\de kapok bush
\sd M Plants
\va
\sy
\re Aerva javanica
\sc Aerva javanica
\ee The white, soft flowers can be used to fill pillows. In the past the flowers were collected in large amounts and used for pillows. Children make toy spears and arrows from the straight stems. This is an introduced plant; it has the same names as a similar native plant.
\sn 5

\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\re 
\va
\sy
\re Tephrosia rosea
\sc Tephrosia rosea
\ee The stems can be used as toy spears by young boys.

\lx gunggarla

\sn 1
\ps n
\ge matches
\de matches
\sd D Things
\re matches
\va
\sy
\gr jawi
\gg jawi, warlu
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\nt Ngarinyman and Gurindji just use 'fire' words for matches
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge fire.stick.tree
\de fire stick tree
\sd M Plants
\re fire stick tree
\re Clerodendrum floribundum
\re Premna acuminata
\re Wrightia saligna
\va
\sy
\sc Clerodendrum floribundum, Premna acuminata, Wrightia saligna
\gr gunggala
\gg kungkala
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc gunggarla.jpg
\ee You use the smooth, straight stems and branches to make fire-sticks or bush matches to light a fire using the traditional drilling called 'binyinyib'. The pale light timber can also be used to make the shaft of a spear-thrower called 'warlmayi'.

\lx gunguna
\sf gunguna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge ti.tree
\de ti-tree
\sd M Plants
\re ti-tree
\re Melaleuca minutifolia
\va
\gr
\gg tawurn, wungurn
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology LC080606BIL.PHbbmh
\sc Melaleuca minutifolia
\ee The papery bark can be used to light fires and to make small coolamons called 'gawarla'. This small tree is a favoured host of native bee-hives called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru'. In the past it was used for medicine and the soft inner-bark was used to make dishes.
\dt 03/Jul/2008

\lx gunjird
\sf gunjird_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bloodwood
\de type of bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re bloodwood
\re Corymbia drysdalensis
\va
\sc Corymbia drysdalensis
\gr
\gg kurnjirt
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050608ih,bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt found at Winingili rockhole.
\nt LC- not the same as other 'bloodwood' -jardburra.
\ee The timber is good firewood. Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. The white bark is burnt to a fine white ash called 'buna' to mix with chewing tobacco called 'warlayarra' or 'ngunyju'.
\sn 2
\ge rusty.bloodwood
\de rusty bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re rusty bloodwood
\re bloodwood (rusty)
\re Corymbia ferruginea
\va
\sc Corymbia ferruginea
\ee You can find sugarbag in this tree which is particularly sweet. 
You can also make didgeridoos from the hollow stems and branches. The timber also makes good firewood.
\sn 3
\ge hill.woollybutt
\de hill woollybutt or scarlett gum
\sd M Plants
\re hill woollybutt
\re scarlett gum
\re Eucalyptus phoenicea
\va
\sc Eucalyptus phoenicea
\pc gunjird.jpg
\ee Stems of the appropriate diameter that have been hollowed by termites can be used to make didgeridoos. Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' can often be found in this tree. It grows on rocky hills and creates good shade. It is only found in the more northerly areas, often on sandstone and is not very common.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx gunudjari
\sf gunudjari_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge olive.python
\de olive python or rock python
\sd I Reptiles
\re olive python
\re rock python
\re python (olive)
\re python (rock)
\re Liasis olivaceus
\va
\sy gurnamurlu
\sc Liasis olivaceus
\gr
\gg kurnamurlu, kunutjari
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Olive_Python.jpg
\nt
\ee This python looks similar to the water python and the king brown. It is often seen on roads at night and is also very good to eat. It is not poisonous.

\lx gurdagaji
\sf gurdagaji_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bloodwood.fruit
\de bloodwood fruit or bush coconut (insect galls)
\sd M Plants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re bloodwood fruit
\re coconut (bush)
\re bush coconut
\re insect gall
\sy gurdagarla
\va
\re Hemiptera
\re Sternorrhyncha
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Sternorrhyncha
\gr
\gg kurtakarla (large gall found on bloodwood trees, often has an edible core, along with an edible grub)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(12:20-14:00)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc
\cf jardburru
\pc bloodwood_gall.jpg
\ee The small soft pink grub inside these insect galls is eaten. They are very sweet and tasty. Children especially like to eat them. The white inner flesh of the gall can also be eaten. It looks a bit like the inside of a coconut. If they are a bit hard they can be softened by placing them in hot ashes for a while. They are found mainly on bloodwood trees called 'jardburru'.
\nt CHECK forms. Edible fruit of bloodwood tree.  Originally I had 'gurragaji' in my notes from Anne
Pollock.  Ivy says form 'gurdagarla' from Barbara might be Ngarinyman or
Mudburra; it matches the  GU form.  There is a song associated with this fruit
according to Barbara and Mildred, two women 'sang the fruit'
\nt
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx gurdagarla
\sf gurdagarla_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bloodwood.fruit
\de bloodwood fruit or bush coconut (insect galls)
\sd M Plants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re bloodwood fruit
\re coconut (bush)
\re bush coconut
\re insect gall
\sy gurdagaji
\va
\re Hemiptera
\re Sternorrhyncha
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Sternorrhyncha
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc
\cf jardburru
\pc bloodwood_gall.jpg
\ee The small soft pink grub inside these insect galls is eaten. They are very sweet and tasty. Children especially like to eat them. The white inner flesh of the gall can also be eaten. It looks a bit like the inside of a coconut. If they are a bit hard they can be softened by placing them in hot ashes for a while. They are found mainly on bloodwood trees called 'jardburru'.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx Gurdurdularni
\sf Gurdurdularni_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de Nangangari Dreaming place on the Victoria River crossing near Pigeon Hole. The Nangangari women left their Jangala children here. The rocks are inhabited by spirit children who cry out in the night for their mothers. This is one place you can go if you want to get pregnant. These rocks can only be reached when it the water level gets lower, right at the end of the build up
\sd O Place Names
\dk
\re
\xv Murlangurlu-ma-lu yani garu-na-yinangulu lunyluny-ja nyila gurlarra.
\xe They went from here, leaving their kids behind just south of here. 
\rf IH: FM: BIL04.track01.01aud: 2003: 07:17min
\sfx Gurdurdularni_IH_eg1_murla.mp3
\so I. Hector. Nangangari Dreaming video and booklet. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\pc 
\gp 737040E, 8141030N
\nt
\dt 29/Apr/2008

\lx gurlardardi
\sf gurlardardi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.orange
\de bush orange
\sd M Plants
\re bush orange
\re orange (bush)
\va
\sy gulinyaga
\gr
\gg kurlatarti, yumarli
\xv Ngayi yana-rna warlagab gurlardardi-wu.
\xe I'm going looking around for bush orange.
\rf Ivy and Sheila Hector. 2006. Wanyjiga-warla-n yana? Produced by L. Campbell for DAC
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(10:40-11:30)
\re Capparis umbonata
\sc Capparis umbonata
\pc gurlardardi.jpg
\nt big mob of these in the bush, looks 'like a vegetable' or 'like an orange', biggish, grows
on a tree, eat the whole thing (no peel).  
\nt 051130: fruit comes at start of wet.
\nt 060124 bush orange (mistaken for bloodwood fruit in recording), some tokens
sounds like -gardi.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf yirdinggi
\ee When the fruit ripen they go a slightly orange-yellow colour and have a strong pleasant smell which can be noticed from a long way away. You can eat the ripe fruit or you can bury the unripe fruit in the sand to help ripen them. Sometimes this might take as long as two weeks. The wood makes good firewood because it lights quickly. You can also use the bark as medicine for scabies called 'garangaji'. When the large flooding rains of the wet season are coming this plant can be used to chase the rains away. You can place the leaves on a fire and waft the smoke towards the rain clouds to make them go away.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx gurluju
\sf gurluju_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge native.hen
\de black-tailed native hen
\sd J Birds
\re native hen
\re hen (native)
\re Gallinula ventralis
\va
\sy
\sc Gallinula ventralis
\gr guluju
\gg kurluju
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(16:25-18:00)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_05ih:(4:10-4:40)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_02ih:(2:00-2:20, 3:00-3:05)
\pc hen.jpg
\nt walks around at night, big one, brown like garlawarl, straight beak.  Another Dreaming
for Ivy? 051123:  runs fast, not eaten today but people used to eat them before.  Eggs
not eaten.
\nt LC- check if there is a song (like emu) for making kids run fast.
\ee These birds look like introduced chickens that lay eggs. They have bright red legs and run like a chook, however they can run very fast. They live near waterholes and lakes. The meat can be eaten.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx gurlun
\sf gurlun_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge ti-tree
\de ti-tree
\sd M Plants
\re ti-tree
\re Melaleuca bracteata
\va
\sy
\sc Melaleuca bracteata
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc gurlun.jpg
\ee This is a small tree that has small leaves. It is found in bush country and the bark is not used as it is not available in large enough pieces.
\nt LC- sometimes considered a type of bagarli because its bark is like paperbark.
\sn 2
\ge turkey.bush
\de turkey bush
\sd M Plants
\re turkey bush
\re Calytrix exstipulata
\va
\sy
\sc Calytrix exstipulata
\pc turkey_bush.jpg
\ee This plant has pretty pink flowers; the bark is similar to a hard paperbark but it is not used for anything. It often grows by billabongs. The branches can be used as a bush broom to clear leaves away from camping areas. The stems can be used for making the front section of spear-shafts. 
\sn 3
\ge bush.paperbark
\de bush paperbark
\sd M Plants
\re paperbark (bush)
\re Melaleuca stenostachya
\va
\sy
\sc Melaleuca stenostachya
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\dt 29/Feb/2008

\lx Gurraj
\sf Gurraj_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge rainbow.serpent
\de rainbow serpent
\sd C Language and Culture
\sd I Reptiles
\re rainbow serpent
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg kurraj
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050707bb,mh
\so 051110ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- check what else to include about gurraj.
\nt LC- check for Bilinarra: Baby rainbow serpents are called kawurrwarang and young ones are called lawirtawirta (Gur).
\ee This Dreaming snake lives in deep waterholes and does not normally come out, though it will rarely during very heavy rain events, when it may move to another waterhole. When Gurraj hears another language being spoken it gets angry and the water may begin to bubble up. If it is disturbed there will be heavy rains and flooding. You can see Gurraj moving underwater because the surface will appear smooth where it is rippled elsewhere. Gurraj has enormous spiritual importance for Bilinarra people. A number of other animals are messengers for Gurraj including 'garrmaninmanin' (red faced turtle). Their eggs and the animals themselves are left alone for fear of aggravating Gurraj.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx gururrunggu
\sf gururrunggu_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge nail-tail.kangaroo
\de nail-tail kangaroo
\sd H Mammals
\re kangaroo (nail-tail)
\re nail-tail kangaroo
\re left-hand kangaroo
\re Onychogalea unguifera
\va
\sy ngungungmarna
\sc Onychogalea unguifera
\gr gurrurrungguny
\gg gururrungku
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_05ih:(21:05, 21:40)
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(00:40-2:05)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(19:00-20:20)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Northern_nailtail_wallaby.jpg
\nt CHECK variants. 060124 tokens sound like gururrunggu or gurrurrunggu
\ee This kangaroo has a nail or 'libi' in the end of its tail and often makes a 'oo..oo..oo' noise when it hops. There is also a special song that it sings as it hops along. It holds its left arm up to its chest when hopping, and is sometimes called 'Left-hand Charlie' because of this habit. These kangaroos sometimes have a distinctive 'humped back'. They can be roasted in a ground oven and eaten, but do not taste very good. The tendons, called 'gambun', from the tails are used to attach spear heads called 'yirlga' or axe heads called 'gurrwa' to shafts, and hooks called 'narra' to spear-throwers called 'warlmaya'. 
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\re stone (oven)
\re rock (oven)

\lx guwarlambarla
\sf guwarlambarla_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge turtle
\de short-neck turtle, snapping turtle
\sd I Reptiles
\sd K Water Animals
\re turtle (short-neck)
\re Elseya dentata
\va
\sy
\sc Elseya dentata
\gr guwarlambarla
\gg kuwalampala
\xv
\xe
\xv Jardgarra-rnalu nyanya jiwirri na, guwarlambarla-ma.
\xe We ate the cooked turtle.
\rf CJcorpus:Yarralin:KJ:Guw
arlambarla_story:29_7_98
\xv Gambala-rnalu wubgarra nyanga-rnalu jardgarra guwarlambarla-ma, ngandiba-ma.
\xe We roast the turtle then eat it, we do.
\so JD040722BIL.DACih
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_02ih:(8:20, 10:00, 11:00, 12:20)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(10:55-12:05, 12:45-13:45)
\pc shortneck_turtle.jpg
\ee This turtle is generally caught on hand-lines called 'wuyurrun'. The meat is very tasty and highly sought after. These turtles have a hard bite and must be handled carefully. They are common in the smaller creeks called 'bin.ga' and billabongs called 'langgarna'. This is the most commonly eaten turtle.
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge tractor
\de tractor
\sd D Things
\re tractor
\so Anzac: RM90-002a
\dt 30/May/2008

\lx Guyuwarndarni
\sf Guyuwarndarni_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de Blanket Knob. A hill and waterhole at the junction of a channel of the Victoria River with a western tributary creek located about 2km northwest of Watsons Yard
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so NLC: Bilinara (Coolibah-Wavehill Stock Route land Claim). May 1989. (Anzac Munganya, Alan Young, Hector Wanayarri)
\so AAPA: Aboriginal Scared Sites within large vicinity of Pigeon Hole Outstation, 2003.
\gp 722800E, 8164700N
\nt CHECK pronunciation and place. Kaya Dreaming? 
Originally written down by NLC as 'Buralgada' but not recognised by Barry Young, George Campbell or Horace Warlman.
Barry Young thinks this might be 'Guyuwarndarni.
Note there is also a Giyuwarndarni in dict.
\dt 14/Aug/2008

\lx jabarlng
\sf jabarlng_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge desert.tree.frog
\de desert tree frog
\sd K Water Animals
\re frog (desert tree )
\re desert tree frog
\re Litora rothii
\sy ngaanyi
\sc Litora rothii
\re Litora tornieri
\sc Litora tornieri
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_05ih:(9:30 - 9:40)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc desert_tree_frog.jpg
\nt This small brown frog has a colourful patch on its back leg. It can be used as bait to catch fish. It is generally found in pandanus plants called 'gajguru' near rivers called 'lamarn' and creeks called 'bin.ga'.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx jabawing
\sf jabawing_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge river.fig
\de river fig
\sd M Plants
\re fig (river)
\re river fig
\re Ficus coronulata
\va jabawuwi, jabawi
\sc Ficus coronulata
\gr
\gg japawing, wurtuyawung
\so 050518mh
\so 050914bb,ih
\so 060124ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jawawing.jpg
\dg soft plum tree
\nt recorded at Mistake Crossing with Mildred (050518).  Barbara and Ivy (050914)
mentioned it has a fruit (need to check if edible)
\nt 060124ih picture of river fig tree in Jawoyn ethnobotany book.  Fruit from this tree is
eaten by fish.
\ee This tree is used in bush medicine. You can dab the white sap onto skin sores called 'marndara' to help them heal. You can also boil the bark and leaves and use the liquid to treat itchy skin and congestion called 'gulygulya'. The fruit is also edible, but some people do not eat the fruit when they are brown. 
Fish and turtles also eat the fruit when they fall in the water. Kangaroos eat the fruit when they fall on the ground. You can use the straight dry stems to make fire-sticks or bush matches.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jagiliny
\sf jagiliny_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge full.moon
\de full moon
\sd G Environment
\re moon (full)
\re full moon
\va
\sy bardangarra
\gr jagiliny
\gg jakaliny
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 051027ih,mh,bb
\pc
\cf ginyuwun
\nt
\sn 2
\ge moon.grub
\de moon grub
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re moon grub
\re Coleoptera
\va
\sy
\sc Coleoptera
\gr
\gg jakaliny
\xv
\xe
\ee These white grubs look like the moon, when they are curled up, and this is why they have the same name as the moon. They can be used as bait when fishing with a hand-line called a 'wuyurrun', but are not eaten by people. They are found in the ground, not in tree trunks and roots. They are the larval stage of several taxa.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx jagilirra
\sf jagilirra_CA.mp3
\sn 1
\ps n
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re whitewood
\re Atalaya hemiglauca
\va
\sy
\sc Atalaya hemiglauca
\gr
\gg jakilirra
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This is a good tree to sit under as it provides dense, cool shade. The pale timber can be used to make boomerangs called 'gurrubardu' and fighting-sticks 'guduru'. Birds are attracted to the flowers which are full of nectar.
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge whitewood
\de whitewood
\sd M Plants
\re
\va
\sy
\re Ehretia saligna 
\sc Ehretia saligna 
\gr
\gg jakilirra
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee You can use the straight stems as firesticks.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx jagudaguda
\sf jagudaguda_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge dodder
\de dodder, thin vine that hangs from trees
\sd M Plants
\re dodder
\sy
\va jagudgagudga
\va jagujagarra
\re Cassytha filiformis
\sc Cassytha filiformis
\gr
\gg jakutajakuta
\rf I. Hector. 2002. Nyampa Nyawa Garndi. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so 050427bb
\so 050517sh?
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jagudaguda.jpg
\nt Used as bush medicine, but especially used to boil it for hair dye (according to
Barbara), or maybe burned for charcoal for that purpose (Ivy)?  Mentioned in NG dict
in entry for 'ngabulu-ngabulu' = milk plant, caustic vine, but no separate head entry. 
Second variant probably mishearing.
\ee This plant has cosmetic uses. You can burn the stems and use the ash to darken your skin or hair. You can also use this vine to make your hair grow longer. You boil the vine, mix the liquid with oil, rub onto your hair, and leave it for three days. You can also boil the stems to treat itchy sores.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jagulaji
\sf jagulaji_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge possum
\de brush-tail possum
\sd H Mammals
\re brush-tail possum
\re possum (brush-tail)
\re Trichosurus vulpecula
\va
\sy jangana
\sc Trichosurus vulpecula
\gr jangarna
\gg jangana, jakulaji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050728bb,mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Brushtail_possum.jpg
\nt LC- at times have had 'barrjida' as synonym, but no-one really sure what it is. FM it is a quoll.
\ee Possums live in hollow trees and their climbing tracks can be seen on the trunks of trees that they live in. They were more common in the past than they are now, but there are still a lot in the Cattle Creek (Kunawa) area. In the past they were eaten a lot, but they have not been eaten much in recent times. Possum fur was used in the past to make pubic tassels or loin cloths.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jalarlga
\sn 1
\sf jalarlga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge catfish
\de any kind of catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (any)
\re Arius spp
\sy warrag
\va 
\sc Arius spp
\so Ethnobiology draft 2008
\so McNair
\pc jalarlga.jpg
\cf ngirnngirda
\ee All catfish have prickles or spines on their fins. These spines are dangerous because they contain poison and if they prick the skin they cause severe pain and swelling. The spines should be broken off and burnt on the fire, thrown in the water or placed in a safe place. If you step on a spine then you can slap the area with the tail of the fish to stop the pain and swelling. You can also treat the area of the sting with urine from the catfish or place hot sand on it. Small or baby catfish are called 'ngirnngirda'.
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge long.nose.catfish
\de long nose catfish or silver cobbler
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (long nose)
\re long nose catfish
\re Neoarius midgleyi
\va
\sy warrag
\sc Neoarius midgleyi
\gr jalarlga
\gg jalalka
\xv Jalarlga jiyala buba-ngga wubgarra.
\xe She roasts the catfish on the fire.
\rf I. Hector. 2002. Wuyurrun.garra. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(3:10-3:40, 4:50-5:35, 6:15)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(30:25-31:05)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jalarlga.jpg
\cf ngirnngirda
\nt 060124 this catfish has a long nose, 
\nt LC- haven't confirmed jabuga in ethno work
\ee This is a very large catfish that is good to eat. The flesh and fat can be eaten after roasting in hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'. If a really large one is caught it can take two or three people  to pull it in. They can be over a metre long and weigh over 20 kilograms. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison and can cause severe pain and swelling. You should break off the spines and burn them on the fire, throw them back in the water or put them in a safe place. If you step on the spine, you should slap the area with the tail of the fish. This stops the pain and swelling. Baby catfish are called 'ngirnngirda'.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\sd J Birds
\re kookaburra
\re Dacelo leachii
\sy julagurr
\sc Dacelo leachii

\so JS051123BIL.DAC_04ih:(8:00-8:45)

\pc blue_winged_kookaburra.jpg
\nt species of bird similar to gumalawuda? 
\nt 051123: elicited with picture of blue-winged kookaburra, probably jalgurrurru?
\ee This bird hunts for lizards and snakes and they often wake you up in the morning with their loud raucous calls. When someone close passes away they will sit near you and sing like they are crying.

\lx jalwag
\sf jalwag_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.potato
\de bush potato
\sd M Plants
\re bush potato
\re potato (bush)
\re Brachystelma glabriflorum
\va
\sy
\sc Brachystelma glabriflorum
\gr warnmala, wijibard
\gg kuliji
\xv
\xe
\pc gurliji.jpg
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This potato is juicy and has a very pleasant starchy taste and is considered excellent food. The shoots appear in the early wet season after the first rains and the potatoes are best at the end of the wet season and early dry season when they are big and juicy. You dig up the disc-shaped potato, clean it and eat it. You can also roast it.

\lx jamanmaya
\sf jamanmaya_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge black.bream
\de black bream or sooty grunter
\sd K Water Animals
\re black bream
\re bream (black)
\re sooty grunter
\re grunter (sooty)
\re Hephaestus fuliginosus
\va
\sy
\sc Hephaestus fuliginosus
\gr jamunmaya, jiwug, bija
\gg yulwa, karrwuring
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(6:25 - 6:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(31:10-31:35)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\so Ethnobiology LC080604BIL.PHmhbbca
\pc black_bream.jpg
\ee This is one of the most favoured fish to eat because the flesh is very tasty. They are quite common and they are easy to catch on hand-lines called 'wuyurrun' in waterholes and creeks. They take bait really well and are always hungry. The flesh is roasted on hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra', or cooked on the stove. Jenkins' Grunter is very similar to the black bream and has the same name and uses.
\nt LC- earlier entires in ethno had jamunmaya, but bb and mh changed to jamanmaya 080604
\sn 2
\ge grunter
\de Butler's grunter or sharp nose grunter
\sd K Water Animals
\re Butler's grunter
\re sharp nose grunter
\re grunter (sharp nose)
\re grunter (Butler's)
\re Syncomistes butleri
\va
\sy
\sc Syncomistes butleri
\ee This fish is very similar to the black bream, above. It is very good to eat.
\sn 3
\ge grunter
\de Neil's grunter or Angalarri grunter
\sd K Water Animals
\re Neil's grunter
\re Scortum neili
\re grunter (Angalarri)
\re grunter (Neil's)
\va
\sy
\sc Scortum neili
\ee This fish is similar to the black bream, above, but has better tasting flesh. It sometimes has a black spot on the side and is lighter in colour. It is not very common.
\dt 04/Jul/2008

\lx jaman.gurla
\sf jamangurla_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge frill.necked.lizard
\de frill-necked lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re lizard (frill-necked)
\re frill-necked lizard
\re Chlamydosaurus kingii
\va
\sy ngarranginy
\sc Chlamydosaurus kingii
\gr
\gg jamankurla, ngarrangirn
\xv
\xe
\so EC:IH:Animal Pictures:2001
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc frilled_neck_lizard.jpg
\nt
\ee These lizards are roasted and eaten. The flesh and fat are tasty. The frill or blanket is burnt on ashes until it turns black and it is then rubbed with fat called 'wararr'. This is in turn rubbed through the hair called 'gardbi' to make it go dark and healthy. When the rains begin the blanket lizard runs around eating ants called 'bingi'. Frill-necked lizards are 'cheeky' or guliyan and will chase you and try to bite you. They are very aggressive when they have eggs.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx Jamarndagurlarni
\sf Jamarndagurlarni_SH.mp3

\de place on the Coxes River which is a Lardaj Dreaming place
\sd O Place Names

\xe Then he went down to the place on the river called Jamarndagurlarni.

\sfx binkga_IH_eg1_ganyjurra.mp3
\rf I. Hector. Lardaj Dreaming video and booklet. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so felicity/Documents/Felicity_Work/DOBES/Bilinarra dictionary/Dict_Images\Place_Names\Jamandagurlarni.jpg
\gp 733000E, 8154000N

\lx jamba
\sf jamba_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge leichhardt
\de Leichhardt tree
\sd M Plants
\re Leichhardt tree
\re Nauclea orientalis
\sy ngimili
\sc Nauclea orientalis
\pc jamba.jpg
\so AN: RN90-002a
\ee This is a large tree that grows on rivers or 'lamarn' and near springs called 'winyji'. It is a good shade tree. The fruit can be eaten when they are ripe and brown. The fruit that fall in the water are eaten by turtles, black bream and other fish so it is a good idea to fish under these trees. The wood is light and relatively soft, and some people think it is too light to use for any purpose.
\dt 04/Mar/2010

\lx jamud
\sf jamud_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.turkey
\de bustard, bush turkey, Australian bustard
\sd J Birds
\re bush turkey
\re bustard
\re turkey (bush)
\re Ardeotis australis
\va
\sy
\sc Ardeotis australis
\gr jamud, jamuj, jandura
\gg jamut, jantura, jikparn, kurrkuparti
\xv Ngayiny-ju ngaba-lu jamud bani.
\xe My [older] brother killed a turkey.
\rf RNgrammar:PigeonHole:1990
\xv Garu-lu gayi bani jindagu jamud mirlarrang-jawung-du.
\xe A kid chased one bush turkey with a spear.
\rf SH: FM08_a087: 10:00min
\sfx jamud_SH_eg2_garu.mp3
\xv Jamud-ma-rnalu barra nyila-ma-rnalu durdurl gambala jamud-ma.
\xe We shot the bush turkey and roasted it in the fire.
\rf IH: FM08_a086: 2001: 2:43min
\sfx jamud_IH_eg3_jamud.mp3
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(4:35, 19:00-22:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_06ih:(1:05-1:20)
\pc bush_turkey.jpg
\nt 051123: "bush killer", cook it by roasting in ground oven (durdurl) or in a stove, or boil it and mix with noodles.  Hunted with rifles today, used to be hunted with spears and boomerangs.  Guts are taken out but some of them are eaten (which ones??).  Fat is taken out initially but then put back in for cooking.  Eggs not eaten.
\ee Bush turkey is one of the best bush meats. They were hunted with boomerangs in the past, now shotguns and rifles are used. You can boil or roast the meat in a ground oven. Bush turkeys like to eat grasshoppers and bush fruits. When they are carrying eggs they are not hunted.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx jangambala
\sf jangambala_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge spring.pandanus
\de spring pandanus
\sd M Plants
\re pandanus (spring)
\re spring pandanus
\re Pandanus spiralis 
\va
\sy
\sc Pandanus spiralis 
\gr jangawa 
\gg wirnpi
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050616ih
\so 060124ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc spring_pandanus.jpg
\nt type of pandanus found around Hutt Spring off Yarralin Road, Ivy says different from jangawa (river pandanus); 'winyji-ngarna jangawa'
\ee The base of the ripe, orange-coloured fruit segments may be chewed and sucked. It is sweet and chewy with a pleasant taste. The pale cream flesh may be eaten by pulling out the new leaves and chewing the cabbage at the base of the leaves. The seeds can be chopped out of the orange fruit segments and eaten. They taste like peanuts. The peduncle or fruit stalk that remains when the fruit segments drop may also be eaten. It has a fibrous texture and starchy taste. 
\cf jangawa
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jangana
\sf jangana_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge possum
\de brush-tail possum
\sd H Mammals
\re brush-tail possum
\re possum (brush-tail)
\sy
\re Trichosurus vulpecula
\va
\sy jagulaji
\sc Trichosurus vulpecula
\gr jangarna
\gg jangana, jakulaji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050728bb,mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Brushtail_possum.jpg
\ee Possums live in hollow trees and their climbing tracks can be seen on the trunks of trees that they live in. They were more common in the past than they are now, but there are still a lot in the Cattle Creek (Kunawa) area. In the past they were eaten a lot, but they have not been eaten much in recent times. Possum fur was used in the past to make pubic tassels or loin cloths.
\dt 04/Jul/2008

\lx jangarla
\sf jangarla_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spring.corkwood
\de spring corkwood
\sd M Plants
\re spring corkwood
\re Sesbania formosa
\va
\sy
\sc Sesbania formosa
\gr
\gg jangarla
\xv
\xe
\so I. Hector. 2002. Bilinarra Bush Medicine. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so 050518mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt This tree grows along Victoria River (seen at Mistake Crossing 050518). When burnt, it was used to rub on baby's skin to make them blacker to prevent the child being taken by the police.
\pc jangarla.jpg
\ee You can burn the bark and use the black ashes to make hair or skin look darker. This method was used in the old days on lighter-skinned children so that the welfare officers would not take them away. The large white flowers come out at the start of the build-up when freshwater crocodiles called 'warrija' and turtles called 'guwarlambarla' are laying eggs. You can also boil the bark and leaves to treat skin sores.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jangawa
\sf jangawa_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge pandanus
\de river pandanus
\sd M Plants
\re pandanus (river)
\re river pandanus
\re Pandanus aquaticus
\va
\sy gajguru
\sc Pandanus aquaticus
\gr jangawa
\gg jangawa, kajkuru
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050518mh
\so 050609bb,mh
\so 050616ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt seen at Mistake Crossing (050518)
\nt LC- child medicine, roots and stums are put on the fire till hot and formed into a bed with warm sand and water. it makes the baby strong.
\pc pandanus.jpg
\ee The fruit are eaten by black bream called 'jamanmaya' and turtles called 'guwarlambarla' when they break into small pieces and fall into the water. You can use the roots and stems of this plant as medicine. The roots and dried stems are put on the fire until they are hot. They are then formed into a bed with warm sand and water and a small baby is placed on it. This makes the baby strong and healthy.
\cf jangambala
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx Jan.gamarlarlu
\sf Jankgamarlarlu_CA.mp3

\dt 07/Apr/2008

\lx jardburru
\sf jardburru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge bloodwood
\de bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re bloodwood
\re Corymbia bleeseri
\va
\sy
\gr jadburru
\gg jartpurru
\sc Corymbia bleeseri
\cf dirnung
\cf nganyiwan
\cf gurdagaji
\cf jidibidbi
\pc jardburru2.jpg
\ee The sap from bloodwood is called 'nganyiwan' or 'dirnung' and it is used to make bush medicine. It can be placed directly onto an aching tooth to stop the pain. It can also be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat skin sores called 'marndara'. The sap can also be boiled, mixed with milk and drunk. This medicine is considered very powerful, able to cure cancers called 'guliyan'. This mixture can be kept for a number of months in the fridge. You can also find bush coconuts or 'gurdagaji' on this tree. They are insect galls that have a hard brown or grey outer skin. Bush coconuts are broken open to expose a small grub (larva) which can be eaten and is very sweet and tasty. You can also make 'jirdbirdbi' which are the seedpods into necklaces. Sugarbag called 'namawurru' is often found in this tree. Sugarbag contains honey, pollen and wax. 
\sn 2
\ge swamp.bloodwood
\de swamp bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re swamp bloodwood
\re bloodwood (swamp)
\va
\sy
\gr jadburru
\gg jartpurru
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\re Corymbia polycarpa
\sc Corymbia polycarpa
\cf nanyjarrnga
\cf jirdbirdbi
\pc jardburru.jpg
\ee Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' which contain honey, pollen and wax can be found in this tree. The timber makes good firewood. Sugar-leaf, a sweet edible insect which is called 'nanyjarrnga', can also be found on the leaves of this tree. The nuts called 'jirdbirdbi' can be made into necklaces.
\sn 3
\ge bloodwood
\de bloodwood
\sd M Plants
\re
\va
\sy
\gr jadburru
\gg jartpurru
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\re Corymbia terminalis
\sc Corymbia terminalis
\ee Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' which contain honey, pollen and wax can be found in this tree. The timber makes good firewood. Sugar-leaf, a sweet edible insect which is called 'nanyjarrnga', can also be found on the leaves of this tree. The nuts called 'jirdbirdbi' can be made into necklaces. The red sap is called 'nganyiwan' or 'dirnung' is used in medicine. It can be placed directly onto an aching tooth and to stop the pain or boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat skin sores called 'marndara'. It can also be boiled and mixed with milk. This medicine is considered very powerful, able to cure cancer called 'guliyan'. The mixture can be kept for a number of months in the fridge. Jardburru is the only variety of bloodwood which is referred to by Bilinarra people as 'bloodwood'.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jardgarra
\sf jardgarra_CA.mp3
\ps cv
\ge eat
\de eat 
\sd E Food and Cooking
\re eat
\sy ngala
\va jawardgarra
\gr jardgarra, jawardgarra
\gg jaartkarra
\xv Garndi nyawawu-ma bani birndirrib yuwarra-yiwula garndi-gari-la, ngayiny-ma. Ganggurni-yiwula jardgarra-wu.
\xe "That tree, you know the one, you two cut at another trunk for me [to get the honey]." The two of them will bring it to me [then] so I can eat it.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.35: 2003
\sfx jardgarra_IH_eg1_garndi.mp3
\xv Nyawa-ma-rna yan.gu dan.gu-wu jawardgarra-wu.
\xe I will go and eat my tucker. 
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (6-16)
\pc eat.jpg
\nt
\se jardgarra nyanga
\de eat
\xv Nyanga-rna jardgarra ngarlu.
\xe I'm eating the sugarbag.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.37aud: 2003
\sfx jardgarra_IH_eg3_nyanga.mp3
\se jardgarra ngala
\de eat
\xv Dimana-lu yuga jawardgarra ngala.
\xe A horse is eating grass.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (4-122)
\se jardgarra garra
\de there eating
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jarlardu
\sf jarlardu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge snake.vine
\de snake vine
\sd M Plants
\re vine (snake)
\re snake vine
\re Tinospora smilacina
\sc Tinospora smilacina
\gr jalardu
\gg jarlatu, warampurr, nalyiki
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050427bb
\so 050706ih
\so 050607bb,mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jarladu.jpg
\nt CHECK variant. grows around other trees, very thick stem.  On 050607 Barbara and Mildred said this
is a big bush banana, like gilibi but bigger.
\ee This climbing plant often grows around the trunks of trees. You can rub the red fruit in the hair called 'gardbi' to make it healthy and dark. The stems can be used as bush rope to tie things up like bundles of firewood.
There is a special song about this plant and the rains of the wet season. This is the plant that 'jungguwurru', the echidna, used as rope to carry the shade tree on his back in the Dreamtime story.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx jarlwa
\sf jarlwa_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge white-necked.heron
\de white-necked heron
\sd J Birds
\re white-necked heron
\re heron (white-necked)
\re egret
\re Egretta pacifica
\va
\sy
\sc Egretta pacifica
\gr jarlwa (crane (blue), egret (?))
\gg jalwa (white-faced heron, straw-necked heron, Ardea novaehollandiae)
\cf murlguwurru
\so 051123BIL.KAT_03ih:(5:10-6:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(00:05-00:25, 00:35-00:45, 3:30)

with a small picture of a spoonbill royal--need to check if this form covers both or just

\lx jarlwarl
\sf jarlwarl_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge cluster.fig
\de cluster fig
\sd M Plants
\re fig (cluster)
\re cluster fig 
\re Ficus congesta
\va
\sy nambula
\sc Ficus congesta
\re Ficus racemosa
\sc Ficus racemosa
\gr nambula (river fig tree, ficus racemosa)
\gg nampula (bush fig-tree, Ficus racemosa), jarlwarr
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so CJcorpus:Yarralin:KJ:Garndi_names:8/5/95
\so 050608ih,bb
\so 050914bb,ih
\so 060124ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc nambula.jpg
\nt JS - edible fruit of dinbarli tree/plant? other dicts suggest maybe a different tree similar to
dinbarli.
\nt FM - pretty sure this is just a type of fig tree plus its fruit
\nt 050914 Ivy and Barbara suggest this is a name for the tree too.
\nt 060124 Ivy says this is some kind of fig tree similar to jabawing
\nt LC- check if used for coolamons too (GUR)
\ee The fruit, which are eaten, go red to brown when they ripen. They are tasty. Flying-foxes called 'warrbawurru', fish called 'yawu' and turtles called 'guwarlambarla' also eat the fruit. 
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx jarnag
\sf jarnag_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge tree.species
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\va
\sy
\xv
\xe
\re Abelmoschus ficulneus
\sc Abelmoschus ficulneus
\pc jarnag.jpg
\ee This plant grows on the seasonally flooded plains country. It used to be more common but Brahman cattle like to eat it and there are fewer around now. The white inner pith of the stem may be lightly roasted and eaten. 
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx jarnbij
\sf jarnbij_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge smoke.tree
\de smoke tree, silver box
\sd M Plants
\re smoke tree
\re silver box
\re Eucalyptus pruinosa
\va
\sy yanjurru
\sc Eucalyptus pruinosa
\gr
\gg yanjurru, jarnbij (GUR dict coolibah)
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jarnbij.jpg
\ee Stems and branches that have been hollowed by termites and are of the appropriate diameter can be made into didgeridoos. Sugarbag called 'namawurru' or 'ngarlu' can be found in this tree. Timber from young plants can be use to make fighting sticks called 'guduru' or spear-throwers called 'warlmayi'. The bark is burnt to a fine white ash called 'buna' to mix with chewing tobacco called 'warlayarra' or 'ngunyju'.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx jarnbirda
\sf jarnbirda_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge fungus
\de horse-dung fungus
\sd M Plants
\re horse-dung fungus
\re fungus
\re Pisolithus tinctorius
\va
\sy
\sc Pisolithus tinctorius
\gr
\gg jarnpirta
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology  LC080604BIL.PHbbmh
\pc
\ee This fungus grows on the ground like a white ball. Young boys sometimes use the black part inside to paint a beard on their face.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jarrarda
\sf jarrarda_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge ceremony
\de mostly secret women's ceremony brought by the Mungamunga women through dreams. 
\sd C Language and Culture
\re ceremony (women's)
\va
\sy
\gr jarrada
\gg jarrarta
\xv Girri-nggu-ma-lu wanyjarni warrgab jarrarda.
\xe All of the girls were performing jarrarda.
\rf LC061106BIL.DACih:2:21
\xv Jangala-lu garrwani-ma-yi. Jarrarda-yi mani.
\xe Jangala married me. He did love magic on me. 
\rf DW: 1975: MCCONVELL_P08-014876: 38:43min
\sfx jarrarda_DW_eg2_Jangala.mp3
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\so Catherine Berndt (1950) "Women's changing ceremonies"
\so Jan Lauridson (1990) "Women's jarata of north central Australia". 
\pc

\nt Note that a lot of these theses contain secret women's material and should not be read by men.

\lx jibilyugu
\sf jibilyugu_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge duck
\de any kind of duck, whistling duck, Australian grebe, wandering duck, plumed whistling duck, grey teal duck, Pacific black duck and introduced ducks.
\sd J Birds
\re duck (any)
\re grebe
\re Tachybaptus novae-hollandiae
\re Poliocephalus poliocephalus
\re Dendrocygna arcuata
\re Dendrocygna eytoni
\re Anas gracilis
\sc Tachybaptus novae-hollandiae
\sc Poliocephalus poliocephalus
\sc Dendrocygna arcuata
\sc Dendrocygna eytoni
\sc Anas gracilis
\gr jibilyugun
\gg jipilyuku, jipilyku (Wandering Whistling-Duck, Plumed Whistling-Duck, Dendrocygna arcuata, Dendrocygna eytoni)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_02ih:(12:13-12:55, 14:00-14:05, 21:45)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(6:10-7:40, 9:29)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(5:45-5:50, 8:20-10:10)
\cf ginygirridu
\pc duck.jpg
\nt 051123: stimulus picture of Australian Grebe, also grey teal, wandering whistling
duck, plumed whistling duck, pink-eared duck, Pacific black duck, hardhead duck. 
Ivy said picture of hoary-headed grebe might be garu for jibilyigu.  Catch these at
billabongs, hit with a stone or stick.  Take out the guts and feathers and cook on top of
coals.  People used to eat the eggs in olden times, but not anymore.  Could be
jibilygu? The -yugu variant could be i->u assimilation?
\nt 060124 Ivy gives "whistle duck" as translation for this, then gives it again with picture
of green pygmy goose, which is also known as ginygirridu.  Ivy says the ??Aboriginal
name??for this one is jibilyigu, not sure quite what she means here, but also seems to
accept ginygirri(r)du.  ??This one now melabat callim ginygirrirdu, an jibilyigu im
really name.??Then she says of ginygirrirdu ??Yeah, (is?) proper name, he got two
name like. Jibilyigu im langa country name.?? Dreaming for Cedrina.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx jidjijuwal
\sf jidjijuwal_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge long.tom
\de freshwater long tom
\sd K Water Animals
\re long tom
\re Strongylura krefftii
\sy diwurru
\sy bulumarnda
\sy jurrgurnduj
\sc Strongylura krefftii
\gr jurrgunduj
\gg jidjijuwal, punumarnta, tiwurru
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(12:30 - 13:25)
\so 050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(2:25 - 2:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(33:50-34:55)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc longtom.jpg
\ee The flesh from larger fish can be roasted and eaten. It is tasty but has a lot of bones. The smaller fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. This fish is recognised for its long pointy nose, as recognised in the name jidji-juwal (nose-long).

\lx jig

\lx jiga
\sf jiga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge beard
\de beard (on a man), whiskers (on an animal)
\sd A Body
\re beard
\re whiskers
\sy
\gr jiga
\gg jika
\xv
\xe
\rf
\cf ngurungngurung
\nt
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge bilby
\de bilby
\sd H Mammals
\re bilby
\re Macrotis lagotis
\sc Macrotis lagotis
\so McConvell
\so Ethnobiology draft 2008
\cf yarninggi
\pc Bilby.jpg
\ee Bilbies have long ears, pointy noses and long tails with white tips. They live in sand-hill country in southern areas and dig large burrows that they live in during the hot weather. They are not seen now. In the old days, they were hunted by digging the burrows up. People would stand near holes to catch them if they ran out. They were eaten and the tails were used to make ceremony decorations called 'yarninggi' worn around the necks of young men. The long black and white tails were also used in women's ceremonies.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx jigala
\sf jigala_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge wax
\de wax (spinifex or sugarbag)
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\sd M Plants
\re wax
\va
\sy
\sc
\gr biyarnag, darla, gajirra, gajarra
\gg jikala, tarla
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_07ih:(11:45-12:00)
\pc
\cf warraaj
\nt
\ee You can use this wax to join a spear or axe head to the shaft. You hold the wax over the flames until it goes black and soft.
Then you beat it out, and repeat the process. You place the wax in the shaft and stick the head in. The whole joint is then tied up with 'gumbun' (animal tendon). When the wax hardens and the tendon dries, the result is a very hard joint.
\nt 060123 wax from sugarbag bee, used for spearheads
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx jigamuru
\sf jigamuru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge water lily
\de water lily
\sd M Plants
\re water lily
\re lily
\re Nymphaea violacea
\va
\sc Nymphaea violacea
\gr jigamurru
\cf mindaarraj
\xv Lablab-ba-rnalu mani nyawa-ma jigamuru.
\xe We collected water lilies.
\rf LC080606BIL.PH_03bbmh 3:20
\xv Jigamuru-ma nyila-ma garra ngabagu-la.
\xe Waterlilies are found in the water.
\rf DW: 1975: MCCONVELL_P08-014876: 22:31min
\sfx jigamuru_DW_eg2_jigamuru.mp3
\so 050728bb,mh LC080605BIL.PHbbmh
\pc jigamuru.jpg
\ee This water lily is similar to the 'mindaarraj', but it has smaller fruit and tastes a bit bitter, but it can still be eaten. It also tends to grow in shallower water. The stalks of 'jigamuru' are not eaten.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\gg ngarlu, jirnuk (sugarbag), kuntarri, kumpaying

\lx jigirrij
\sf jigirrij_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge willy.wagtail
\de willy wagtail
\sd J Birds
\re willy wagtail
\va
\sy
\rd jigirrij-jigirrij
\re Rhipidura leucophrys
\sc Rhipidura leucophrys
\gr jigirrijigirri
\gg jikirrij (Willie Wagtail, Rhipidura leucophrys)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_05ih:(1:00-2:25, 3:40, 7:35-8:05, 8:40-8:50, 11:40-12:20)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(26:10-26:40)
\pc willy_wagtail.jpg
\nt 051123: elicited with pictures of white-browed robin, male shining flycatcher (not
female), Willie wagtail.  Name is based on its call "jigirrij, jigirrij".
\nt 060124 pic of willie wagtail
\nt LC- CHeck, then put in ee: There is an important
creation period story about this bird.  It is important not to harm
Jigirrij, if you kill them your mother and father will pass away.
\ee The name of the bird is based on the sound of its call. It has a long tail and is an excellent dancer. There is an important creation period story about this bird. Children are told not to harm 'jigirrij' or their mother will pass away.
\dt 28/Apr/2008

\lx jimurug
\sf jimurug_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge water.python
\de water python or rainbow snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re snake (water python)
\re water python
\re python (water)
\re rainbow snake
\re snake (rainbow)
\re Liasis fuscus
\va
\sy
\sc Liasis fuscus
\gr jimurug
\gg jimuruk, japartajaparta
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 060209ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc water_python.jpg
\nt 060209 Ivy gave this as an alternate name either for naminamij
(curl snake?) or mulyuguna (black-headed python), or (based on
info in GU and NG dict) might be different snake altogether? RN
gives this as a water snake.
\nt LC- confirmed in ethnobiology work as water python
\nt LC- check if Bilinarra also give it jabarda skin (like gurindji)
\ee These snakes are not poisonous. They live in waterholes and have a distinctive shiny skin that reflects light like a rainbow called 'waji'. They can get very large. These snakes have links with the rainbow serpent called 'Gurraj', which also lives in deep waterholes. Water pythons are speared or caught by hand and are cooked in the same way as the black-headed python. They taste similar to goanna. 
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jinggurl
\sf jinggurl_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge swamp.box
\de swamp box
\sd M Plants
\re swamp box
\re Lophostemon grandiflorus
\va
\sy bawulyji
\sc Lophostemon grandiflorus
\gr
\gg pawulji
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc swamp_box.jpg
\ee This is a good shade tree that grows in creek and riverbeds. The wood makes good firewood for cooking meat, fish or any food. Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. Stems of smoking-pipes can be made from small hollow branches.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx jingi
\sf jingi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bauhinia
\de bauhinia
\sd M Plants
\re bauhinia
\re Lysiphyllum cunninghamii
\va
\sy wanyarri
\sc Lysiphyllum cunninghamii
\gr wanyarri
\gg wanyarri, jingi
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc wanyarri.jpg
\cf ngabirlibirli
\nt LC- wanyarri is the more common name
\ee The inner red bark makes good medicine. You can boil it and use the water as a wash and drink to treat headaches, colds called 'gulygulya' and skin sores called 'marndara'. You can also chew the leaves to treat colds. You can also find sugarbag called 'namawurru' in this tree. The red flowers can be sucked to get the sweet nectar. The seed pods are called 'ngabirlibirli'. You can burn the outer bark to make tobacco ashes called 'buna', and chew the leaves if you are thirsty. Chewing the leaves helps produce saliva or 'jawul' and stops the feeling of intense thirst.
\dt 09/Jun/2008
