\lx jirragbarn
\sf jirragbarn_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge triller
\de white-winged triller, others
\sd J Birds
\re white-winged triller
\re triller (white-winged)
\re Lalage sueurii
\va
\sy
\sc Lalage sueurii
\gr
\gg jirrakparn (a kind of honeyeater, with pellow spots, eats buttenflies and grass seeds, similar to
yellow wagtail)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih:(15:55-16:10)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_03ih:(13:10-14:00)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_04ih:(17:50-18:05, 19:35-19:55)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_05ih:(2:40-3:40, 5:15-5:30, 6:45-6:50, 8:30-8:45, 9:30-9:55, 11:10-11:30)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_02ih:(2:20-3:25, 6:05-7:00, 14:30-15:50, 17:25-19:10, 19:47, 22:25-23:20, 24:30-25:15)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(28:40-29:20)
\nt 051123: could be jiragbarn? Song recorded on JS051123BIL.KAT_06ih.  Not used
for anything (food, eggs, etc.).  Elicited with pictures of pallid cuckoo, white-winged
triller, lemon-bellied flycatcher, jacky winter, sandstone shrike-thrush, leaden
flycatcher (but this one not at PH according to Ivy), grey fantail, and (060123)
weebill, several species of honeyeater (singing, grey-fronted, yellow-tinted,
grey-headed, white-throated, rufous-throated).  Eats honey from flowers, the only bird
that does this.
\nt 060123 unrecorded, but seen in tree overhead, either silver-crowned or helmeted
friarbird
\nt 060124 picture of grey shrike-thrush, Ivy certain at first but wavers a bit.
\ee This name is given to many small to medium sized birds that are inconspicuous or have no particular use. This includes many of the honeyeaters. Their nests look like dilly bags hanging from trees.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx Jirrigig

\lx jiwawurru
\sf jiwawurru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bowerbird
\de bowerbird, stealing bird also called a 'jawurrany jurlag'
\sd J Birds
\re bowerbird
\re stealing bird
\sy
\va jiwayurru
\so 050609mh
\re Chlamydera nuchalis
\sc Chlamydera nuchalis
\gr jiwayurru
\gg jiwayurru
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_07ih:(1:45-1:50, 2:20-2:30)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_03ih:(14:55-15:10)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_04ih:(11:35, 16:06-16:30)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_05ih:(15:20-15:35)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_02ih:(00:10-1:10, 11:15-11:45, 12:35-12:55, 16:05-17:25)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_03ih:(11:25-12:05, 14:00-16:25, 19:24)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(30:40-32:15, 33:20)
\pc Bowerbird.jpg 
\ee This bird likes to make its nest or bower under conkerberry bushes called 'ngamanburru'. It steals coins and takes them to its nest. It also collects the white shells of land snails called 'dinyinggirra' to decorate their bowers. The name of the bird probably originally derives from Jaminjung (jiwiya=nose, -wurru=having).
\nt 060123: Ivy gave this term for several bird species (grey-crowned babbler, little friarbird, white-gaped honeyeater, olive-backed oriole) but in general this seemed to be cases of mistaking unfamiliar birds for the bowerbird. 
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jiwirrirri
\sf jiwirrirri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge mussel
\de sandstone freshwater mussel found in rivers
\sd K Water Animals
\re mussel (sandstone)
\va
\gr jirilili
\gg jiwirrirri
\xv
\xe
\re Lortiella rugata
\sc Lortiella rugata
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(28:55-30:45)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jiwirrirri.jpg
\cf dugu
\cf wijalngarniny
\cf naribu
\nt long one, found in river country
\ee These mussels occur in rivers and creeks often under rocks. They are long and thin. They are roasted on hot coals and eaten. Mussels cannot be eaten by boys; men can only eat them after they have been initiated. The meat can also be boiled in water with a little salt and made into soup called 'yingalg' and this can be drunk to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' and diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. The juice from mussels can also be used to treat ear aches and infections. It is dripped straight into the ear.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx jubanyiny
\sf jubanyiny_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge plains.kangaroo
\de plains kangaroo, antilopine wallaroo
\sd H Mammals
\re plains kangaroo
\re kangaroo (plains)
\re wallaroo (antilopine)
\re antilopine wallaroo
\re Macropus antilopinus
\va
\sy
\sc Macropus antilopinus
\gr jaliny (big male), jarrdugal, jubanyin
\gg jupanyiny, jaliny
\xv
\xe
\pc Antilopine_Wallaroo.jpg
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- big Dreaming story across Gurindji and other country, check for Bilinarra.
\ee This kangaroo is often seen in grassy plain areas. It has long thin legs and can hop fairly quickly. The meat is good to roast and eat. The tendons, called 'gambun', from the tails are used to attach spear heads called 'yirlga' or axe heads called 'gurrwa' to shafts, and hooks called 'narra' to spear-throwers called 'warlmaya'. 
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx judiyina
\sf judiyina_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge tawny.frogmouth
\de tawny frogmouth or mopoke
\sd J Birds
\re tawny frogmouth
\re mopoke
\re Podargus strigoides
\va
\sy
\sc Podargus strigoides
\gr
\gg jutiyina
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc tawny_frogmouth.jpg
\ee These birds look like a dead stick in a tree and sit quite still. On full moons they all sit together and sing, moving from side to side together. Some people are scared by their call, saying it sounds like the devil. They sing 'bunggiyid bunggiyid, didliwud didliwud, ngi ngi'. They have the Nalyirri skin.
\nt song: bunggiyid bunggiyid didliwud didliwud nge: nge:
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx jumunyjumuny
\sf jumunyjumuny_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.tea
\de bush tea leaf, also pronounced 'bujtilip'
\sd M Plants
\re bush tea leaf
\re Ocimum tenuiflorum
\va
\sy
\sc Ocimum tenuiflorum
\gr jumunyjumuny, ngurnungurnung
\gg lampalamparr
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050608ih,bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc juminjumin.jpg
\nt Seen off Yarralin road near Jamanbuluga
\nt LC- not many people know this name, it is normally called 'bujtilip', or nalija.
\ee You can make tea from the leaves and stems. They smell a bit like aniseed or liquorice. You can also use this plant to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' and to wash itchy skin. The drink is also good for providing sustenance when walking a long way. The tea can keep you going until food is found. It makes you strong when you are feeling weak.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jungguwurru
\sf jungguwurru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge echidna
\de echidna, porcupine
\sd H Mammals
\dk pokipain
\re echidna
\re porcupine
\re Tachyglossus aculeatus
\sy bagayawung
\sy nginyiwurda
\sc Tachyglossus aculeatus
\gr junggurru, jungguwurru, bagayawung
\gg jungkuwurru
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_05ih:(1:35, 1:40, 3:15, 3:50)
\pc echidna.jpg
\nt many to be found near Top Springs and Montejinni station; this is Ivy's Dreaming
from her dad.
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so Ethnobiology draft 200
\ee Jungguwurru often live in rocky country, where they hide in crevasses and cracks. They can be pulled out with wire hooks or hooked branches. They are much more commonly seen at night when they walk around looking for food. They are most active during full moon periods in the cold weather of the dry season. When they walk they leave a little track where the prickles drag along the ground. When they are approached, they roll into a tight ball to protect themselves. Their favourite foods are ants called 'bingi' and termites called 'mun.gurd' which they eat with their tongue called 'jalany'. They are often found near termite mounds called 'mardumardu'. During the hot weather of the build-up they can be found in cool areas near rivers called 'lamarn', where they look for wet ground that is cool to sleep on. The name 'jungguwurru' is derived from Jaminjung (junggu=point of elbow plus -wurru=having). Porcupines or echidnas are also often called baga-yawung (having spikes). You can roast the flesh and eat it. The meat is sweet like pork. It has a lot of tasty white coloured fat. You need to chop off the spines and feet prior to cooking the whole body in a ground oven. You can soften the spines by placing them on hot coals for a short time or by placing them in a bucket of very hot water. The flesh cannot be eaten by young boys and mothers during initiation ceremonies. Pregnant women called 'ngardurr' cannot eat them because the spikes might poke the baby and it will be born a cripple. Jungguwurru has a Dreaming story about how he got his prickles. Jungguwurru got mad when he found out that the other animals weren't giving him the good meat. He took all of the shade trees away, so the other animals speared him, giving him his prickles.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx jurrgurnduj
\sf jurrgurnduj_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge long.tom
\de freshwater long tom
\sd K Water Animals
\re long tom
\re Strongylura krefftii
\sy diwurru
\sy bunumarnda
\sy jidjijuwal
\sc Strongylura krefftii
\gr jurrgunduj
\gg jidjijuwal, punumarnta, tiwurru
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(12:30 - 13:25)
\so 050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(2:25 - 2:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(33:50-34:55)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc longtom.jpg
\ee The flesh from larger fish can be roasted and eaten. It is tasty but has a lot of bones. The smaller fish are used as bait to catch larger fish. This fish is recognised for its long pointy nose, as recognised in the name jidji-juwal (nose-long).
\nt 060124 Ivy says this is same as bulumarnda (bunumarnda), says this word is
Ngarinyman, isn't sure about diwurru but thinks in might be a different fish.
\nt LC- gurindji lists tiwurru as syn, but also given for mullet (BIL and GUR). Consider taking out diwurru as synonym.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee The reddish-fruit are eaten by birds but not by people. This small tree grows in rocky areas and has cool dense shade. The bark can be boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat itchy skin.

\lx laju
\sf laju_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge witchetty.grub
\de witchetty grub
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re witchetty grub
\re Lepidoptera
\sy lamawurd
\sc Lepidoptera
\re Cossidae
\re Hepialidae 
\sc Cossidae
\sc Hepialidae 
\pc Witchetty_grub.jpg
\ee This is a Warlpiri word. These white grubs are mainly found in bloodwoods, 'dimarlan' (red river gum) and wattle species such as 'mulurrmi', 'girrbirli' and 'birrbun'. They live in tree trunks and roots. They are spotted by looking for the entrance hole with associated  'bundu' (fine dust) or 'gura' (excrement) on the trunk and branches. The wood is then chopped just above the hole to widen it, and the grub pulled out with a piece of thin hooked wire or a hooked stick called a 'narra'. When they are in tree roots you look for the small piles of 'gura' at the entrance hole and then dig up or push over the plant so that the roots are exposed. In the wet season when the ground is soft, the small 'mulurrmi' shrubs are just pushed over and the roots pull up out of the ground. The grubs can then be easily collected. They are eaten raw or lightly cooked in hot ashes. They taste like scrambled eggs and are much sought after. They can also be used as fishing bait, but are usually eaten first, as they taste so good.
\so 050728bb,mh
\nt CHECK - JS - Barbara and Mildred said it's like a little snake--might be some sort of grub? Cut
dimalarn with axe to get it, then take back to camp and cook it (wubgarra) in coals
(linyard).
\nt LC- we have this as GUR for witchetty grub, check if really BIL
\nt FM changed according to Gurindji dictionary
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\se lamala mana
\de feel around with feet

\lx lamawurd
\sf lamawurd_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge witchetty.grub
\de witchetty grub 
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\sd E Food and Cooking
\re witchetty grub
\va
\sy
\gr lamawud
\gg lamawurt
\re Lepidoptera
\re Cossidae
\re Hepialidae
\sc Lepidoptera
\sc Cossidae
\sc Hepialidae
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(25:00-28:15)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(19:40-20:50)
\pc Witchetty_grub.jpg
\nt found on roots of mulurrmi plant/tree and on top of dimalarn, cooked and eaten, Ivy
says it's like beef, fat one, commonly found down at Lajamanu.  GU dict has synonym
for laju.  
\nt 060123 lives in ground at roots of mulurrmi in desert country (where they are dug up
with a crowbar) or in white gum tree in river country (where they are taken out of the
tree with an axe by splitting the bark sideways).  Used as bait for catching catfish as
well.  Good tucker, cooked in hot ground (durdurl).
\ee These white grubs are mainly found in bloodwoods, 'dimarlan' (red river gum) and wattle species such as 'mulurrmi', 'girrbirli' and 'birrbun'. They live in tree trunks and roots. They are spotted by looking for the entrance hole with associated  'bundu' (fine dust) or 'gura' (excrement) on the trunk and branches. The wood is then chopped just above the hole to widen it, and the grub pulled out with a piece of thin hooked wire or a hooked stick called a 'narra'. When they are in tree roots you look for the small piles of 'gura' at the entrance hole and then dig up or push over the plant so that the roots are exposed. In the wet season when the ground is soft, the small 'mulurrmi' shrubs are just pushed over and the roots pull up out of the ground. The grubs can then be easily collected. They are eaten raw or lightly cooked in hot ashes. They taste like scrambled eggs and are much sought after. They can also be used as fishing bait, but are usually eaten first, as they taste so good.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx langajuwal
\sf langajuwal_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge donkey
\de donkey
\sd H Mammals
\re donkey
\re Equus asinus
\va
\sy
\sc Equus asinus
\gr
\gg langajuwal
\xv
\ee The language name refers to the distinctive long ears. In the past they were used to carry heavy loads and pull carts. They are stronger and longer working than horses. In the past, large teams of donkeys would pull wagons from the depot at Timber Creek to Wave Hill Station loaded with supplies. Individual donkeys were also used to carry loads of firewood and water.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt literally 'long ears'
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx lardaj
\sf lardaj_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge rough-tailed.goanna
\de rough-tailed goanna or little lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re rough-tailed goanna
\re goanna (rough-tailed)
\re little lizard
\re Varanus acanthurus
\va
\sy
\sc Varanus acanthurus
\gr ladaj
\gg lataj
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_02ih:(13:45, 14:10, 14:35, 14:45, 18:30, 19:05, 26:05)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_07ih:(27:15-28:15)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(14:30)
\pc
\pc Varanus_acanthurus.jpg
\ee This small goanna has a rough tail like a rasp and lives in rocky country. The meat is good to eat but it can make you bleed which is called 'gungulu'. There is an important Bilinarra Dreaming story about Lardaj. Lardaj went to Jamanburluga then Giliyanga. From Giliyanga he went north. He built himself a home for himself up there. From that place, he went down and made water to drink at Winingili which is a well-known table-like rock. Then he headed north climbing over two hills. He went down to a place then on the river called Jamarndagurlarni. From Jamarndagurlarni he went to Wanbangi. At Wanbangi he stopped for good.
\nt LC- check for names for little ones: gurindji 'wankarrana'
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\sfx larlub_IH_eg1_gardag.mp3

\lx lawa
\sf lawa_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge lemon.wood
\de lemon wood
\sd M Plants
\re lemon wood
\re Dolichandrone heterophylla
\va
\sc Dolichandrone heterophylla
\gr lawa
\gg lawa
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050427bb
\so Ethnobiologydraft 2007
\pc lawa.jpg
\ee The leaves and bark are boiled in water and the liquid used as a medicinal wash to treat itchy skin, scabies called 'garangaji', sores called 'marndara' and general pain. It is often used in conjunction with 'yirrijgaji'. If you wash with it everyday for three days, it will heal any sores. Alternatively the leaves of 'lawa', 'yirrijgaji' and 'dimarlarn' can be put into a fire pit which has burnt down and children are held over the pit to inhale the smoke and allow it to waft over their skin. The leaves of the 'lawa' can also be heated up on the coals of a fire and applied to a person's head to alleviate a headache or applied to sore, swollen feet. This technique is also used to reverse curses on a person.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx lawara
\sf lawara_CA.mp3

\ge no

\dk najing
\sd X Exclamations
\re no
\re nothing
\va
\sy wagurni

\xv Jala-ma-rnalu wumara-ma lawara!
\xe We don't have any money today!
\xv Yanggiyanggi-rna bani warlayarra-wu-ma najing lawara-birag-ma-yi mani.

\lx lawurra
\sf lawurra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge riflefish
\de rifle fish or archer fish
\sd K Water Animals
\re rifle fish
\re archer fish
\re Toxotes chatareus
\sy luwarra
\sc Toxotes chatareus
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc riflefish.jpg
\ee This fish has distinctive spots on its side and it spits water at insects to knock them into the water, so that it can eat them. It is mainly used as bait to catch other fish, especially barramundi called 'yinarrwa'. Children like to catch them, cook them on hot coals and then eat the meat.

\lx lirrimilirrimi
\sf lirrimilirrimi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge plant.species
\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\re Euphorbia hirta
\va
\sy ngamulurd
\sc Euphorbia hirta
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050428ih
\so 050428bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc ngamulurd.jpg
\cf lirrimi
\nt Bush medicine used for sores:  boil with water, swim (Barbara); Ivy: boil leaf for itches
and sores, makes red-coloured water when boiled.
\ee This plant can be used in bush medicine. You use the white sap called 'ngabulu' or the red liquid from boiling the leaves to treat skin sores called 'marndara'. There are lots of these small plants around Pigeon Hole. The dry leaves are the same colour as 'lirrimi' (centipedes).

\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx lumbung
\sf lumbung_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge fish.poison.bush
\de fish poison bush
\sd M Plants
\re fish poison bush
\re Tephrosia procera
\va
\sy
\sc Tephrosia procera
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This small tree or shrub grows in areas of sandstone country. The leaves and twigs can be used as fish poison. The leaves are thrown into small waterholes and after a period the fish float to the surface and can be easily collected. They are then cooked and eaten. This works well for black bream called 'jamanmaya'. The wood can be used to make spears called 'mirlarrang', shields called 'mirda', clap-sticks called 'gilgilbgaji' and fighting-sticks called 'guduru'. 
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx lunggura
\sf lunggura_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge blue.tongue
\de northern blue-tongue lizard and desert blue-tongue lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re blue-tongue lizard
\re lizard (blue-tongue)
\re Tiliqua scincoides
\va
\sy
\sc Tiliqua scincoides
\re Tiliqua multifasciata
\sc Tiliqua multifasciata
\gr lunggura
\gg lungkura (Bluetongue lizard, Tiliqua scincoides, Central Bluetongue)
\gg lungkura (both species), jiwili (northern blue-tongue), luma (desert blue-tongue)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_02ih:(00:50, 2:05, 5:05, 5:10, 26:00)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_07ih:(27:30-27:35)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc blue_tongue_lizard.jpg
\nt
\ee There are two types of blue-tongue lizards. They are quite similar but distinctly different in skin colour. The desert blue-tongue has orange stripes on its skin, while the northern blue-tongue has darker stripes. Both types are called 'lunggura'. The flesh is roasted in a ground oven, a cooking technique called 'durdurl' also used for goannas called 'girrawa'. It has tasty fat similar to that of a goanna. They are easy to catch, however, they do have a very strong bite. They cannot run quickly and can be picked up by grabbing them firmly around the neck. They can be caught all year round.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx lunyja
\sf lunyja_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge salmon.gum
\de salmon gum
\sd M Plants
\re salmon gum
\re gum (salmon)
\re Eucalyptus bigalerita
\va
\sy wamba
\sc Eucalyptus bigalerita
\gr lunyja
\gg lunja
\xv [Lunyja-ma] daj-ba-lu bani gambarni-lu bayarni-lu gugij ngawa bunyug.
\xe They got the 'lunyja' leaves, made them soft, boiled them and they drank it to make them better. [What to do if you get sick at Badcold Dreaming place]
\rf IH: FM: BIL01.track02.03aud: 2003: 06:13min
\sfx lunyja_IH_eg1_lunyja.mp3
\so 050915ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc lunyja.jpg
\ee This is an important tree for Bilinarra people. A number exist opposite Gulygulya, the Badcold Dreaming site found along the Victoria River. This is a dangerous place which has a rock on the eastern side which is potentially deadly. Lunyja trees on the opposite bank can be used to cure people who come into contact with the rock. The timber also makes good firewood. Boomerangs called 'gurrubardu' may also be made from the hard wood. Sugarbag or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. The bark is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as a wash to treat skin problems. 
\sn 2
\ge snappy.gum
\de snappy gum
\sd M Plants
\re snappy gum
\re gum (snappy)
\re Eucalyptus brevifolia
\va
\sy wamba
\sc Eucalyptus brevifolia
\cf malangarna
\pc lunyja2.jpg
\ee The timber is good long lasting firewood. Boomerangs may be made from the hard wood. The bark can be used in bush medicine. It is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as a wash to treat skin problems and congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya'. Sugarbag or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. The sugar-leaf, a sweet edible insect, collected from 'lunyja' is called 'malangarna'.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx luwarra
\sf luwarra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge riflefish
\de rifle fish or archer fish
\sd K Water Animals
\re rifle fish
\re archer fish
\re Toxotes chatareus
\sy lawurra
\sc Toxotes chatareus
\gr luwarra, lawarra
\gg luwarra, lawarra
\xv
\xe

\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(19:20 - 19:35, 20:40 -20:45, 21:35)
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(8:30 - 8:40, 16:55)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(7:15-7:20, 32:05-32:40)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc riflefish.jpg
\nt 060124 good bait to catch catfish and barra.
\ee This fish has distinctive spots on its side and it spits water at insects to knock them into the water, so that it can eat them. It is mainly used as bait to catch other fish, especially barramundi called 'yinarrwa'. Children like to catch them, cook them on hot coals and then eat the meat.

\lx madarrgu
\sf madarrgu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge curry.orange
\de curry orange or plum trees and fruit
\sd M Plants
\re curry orange
\re plum
\re Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\va
\sy garrajgarraj
\sy ganggulanga
\sc Ziziphus quadrilocularis
\gr garrajgarraj
\gg karrajkarraj
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc curry.orange.jpg
\ee The fruit ripen  during cold weather time. The fruit are brown,  sweet and tasty. The pulp is eaten but the seeds and skin are spat out. The fruit can also be collected from the ground when they are dry. If the fruit are bitter they can be boiled in water with sugar to make them sweet. Another way of preparing them is to warm them on the hot coals. They are also cooked wrapped with 'marlin' or 'nalij' (green water weed). This moistens them and makes them nicer to eat. If there are lots of unripe fruit they can be lightly cooked in a ground oven to make them ripen quickly. The leafy, rounded canopy provides dense, cool shade. The timber can be used as firewood.
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx magiliwarn
\sf magiliwarn_CA.mp3

\pc Agile_Wallaby.jpg
\ee These small kangaroos live in areas near rivers called 'lamarn' and creeks called 'bin.ga'. They are common in some areas and there are a lot near the Victoria River and around Pigeon Hole. The flesh can be eaten after roasting and is very good to eat.
\nt 060124 found in river country

\lx magurru
\sf magurru_CA.mp3
\sn 1
\ps n

\de cold, cold weather
\sd G Environment
\dk kolbala
\re cold
\va
\sy
\gr magurru
\gg makurru

\sfx magurru_IH_eg1_bunyug.mp3

\sn 2

\de school
\sd D Things
\dk
\re school
\xv Garra-rnalu nyawangga magurru-la.

\gg makurru
\ee This word is used to mean school because 'school' sounds similar to 'cool'.
\nt The school meaning is a back translation through Kriol 'magurru' - 'kul' - 'school'. It has also been claimed that it refers to the fact that schools are airconditioned but this is unlikely.

\lx Majul
\sf Majul_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge Queenie.Rockhole
\de Queenie Rockhole. A rockhole in gap in ranges
\sd O Place Names
\re Queenie Rockhole
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so NLC: Bilinara (Coolibah-Wavehill Stock Route land Claim). May 1989. (Old Jimmy Mangayarri, Elsey Tunkulkarri)
\gp
\nt CHECK pronunciation and place. Emu and Quail Dreaming. 
Emu swapped small eggs for large one from Quail (bundaru).

\lx malangarna
\sf malangarna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge lerp
\de sugarleaf from the snappy gum, lerp
\sd M Plants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarleaf (snappy gum)
\re snappy gum sugarleaf
\re lerp
\re Hemiptera
\re Psyllidae
\va
\sy
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Psyllidae
\gr malangana
\gg malangana
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf lunyja
\cf wamba
\cf nanyjarrnga
\cf burrngun
\pc Lerps.jpg
\ee These small white scale-like insect-coverings are collected off the leaves of a snappy gum called 'wamba' or 'lunyja' during the early part of the dry season, when the first smoke or 'gabarru' is in the air. They are very sweet and tasty. The branches and twigs are broken off and left to dry over a calico sheet called a 'balginy'. The lerps are knocked off the leaves with a stick and then collected and shaped into small johnnycakes or biscuits and eaten. These can also be stored in cake-tins for weeks and months.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx malawa
\sf malawa_CA.mp3

\de small creek
\sd F Water
\sd G Environment
\dk riba
\re creek
\va
\sy
\gr malawa, bin.ga, parnda
\gg parnta, pinka
\xv Wiyid-ba-rna jayinya garlanggarlag nyawa malawa-gari.
\xe I pointed at another creek here towards the west. 
\rf KJ: 1975: MCCONVELL_P08-014876: 11:23min
\sfx garlarra_KJ_eg5_wiyid.mp3
\pc
\cf bin.ga
\nt
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx mali
\sf mali_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge mother.in.law
\de man's mother-in-law (and her brothers), woman's son in law. This is an avoidance relationship. You cannot talk to a person you call 'mali' (though you can talk to them through someone else). You also need to pass things to them with two hands. 
\sd B People
\re mother-in-law (man's)
\re son-in-law (woman's)
\va
\sy
\gr mali
\gg mali
\xv Yan.gu-rnalu-nga mali dinggalb-barni galu.
\xe We might skirt around our son-in-law. 
\rf KJ: 1975: MCCONVELL_P08-014876: 08:24min
\sfx dinggalb_KJ_eg1_yangu.mp3
\xv Nyila-ma-nga jayinggu wardan-du gujarra-nggu.
\xe That one might pass it using two hands [one hand holding the wrist of the other].
\rf MH: FM08_a090: 01:38min
\sfx mali_MH_eg2_nyila.mp3
\so 050706ih
\so 050721bb,ih
\cf gurriji
\cf luwarra

\lx mangurlu
\sf mangurlu_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge pigweed
\de pigweed
\sd M Plants
\re pigweed
\re Portulaca oleracea
\va
\sy
\sc Portulaca oleracea
\gr
\gg mangurlu
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee The small black and white seeds look like sand and in the past the seeds were made into small dampers called 'mangarri'. The plant is small and it grows along the ground. The whole plant can be placed onto a coolamon called a 'gawarla' and the seeds are winnowed out and collected. When enough are available, they are ground up using a grinding stone called a 'jungari'. The flour is then mixed with water and made into small dampers. These are lightly cooked then eaten. Dampers are very good food and in the past it was an important food source, however, making the food was hard work.
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx mangurluyaba
\sf mangurluyaba_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge cormorant
\de little pied cormorant
\sd J Birds
\re cormorant (little pied)
\re Phalacrocorax melanoleucos
\va
\sy
\sc Phalacrocorax melanoleucos
\gr
\gg mangurlu yapa
\dg pied cormorant, Phalacrocorax varius
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_02ih:(19:10-19:50, 20:45-21:00)
\pc little_pied_comorant.jpg
\nt Ivy gave this for stimulus picture of little black cormorant, recording
(JS051123BIL.KAT_02ih) reveals that she considered it the young of the Pied
Cormorant. 
\nt LC- check if 'yaba' = small
\ee These birds are eaten. You hunt them by throwing a rock or stick at them.
When you catch them, you gut them, singe off their feathers, then roast them on hot coals. In the old days people ate the eggs as well.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx manyanyi
\sf manyanyi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge river.manyanyi
\de river manyanyi
\sd M Plants
\re
\va
\sy
\re Blumea axillaris
\sc Blumea axillaris
\gr manyanyi
\gg manyanyi
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050427bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This small plant has a strong pleasant smell and is used as a medicine. The plant is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' or itchy skin. It is very effective. This is plant is often referred to as 'River Manyanyi'. There is a special women's song for this plant but it cannot be sung when men are around. The smell of manyanyi is also associated with the Mungamunga spirit women who live in the Kunawa (Cattle Creek) area and steal children. They also leave manyanyi leaves when they visit men at night time.
\nt LC- There is a mungamunga song for manyanyi (women only).
\sn 2
\ge manyanyi
\de manyanyi
\sd M Plants
\re Streptoglossa odora
\re Pterocaulon globuliflorus
\re Pterocaulon serrulatum
\re Pterocaulon verbascifolium
\re Streptoglossa bubakii
\sc Streptoglossa odora
\sc Pterocaulon globuliflorus
\sc Pterocaulon serrulatum
\sc Pterocaulon verbascifolium
\sc Streptoglossa bubakii
\gr manyanyi
\gg manyanyi
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050427bb
\pc manyanyi.jpg
\ee This small plant has a strong pleasant smell and is used as a medicine. The plant is boiled in water and the liquid used as a wash to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' or itchy skin. It is very effective. There is a special women's song for this plant but it cannot be sung when men are around. The smell of manyanyi is also associated with the Mungamunga spirit women who live in the Kunawa (Cattle Creek) area and steal children. They also leave manyanyi leaves when they visit men at night time.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx manyingila
\sf manyingila_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge gutta.percha
\de gutta percha
\sd M Plants
\re gutta percha
\re Excoecaria parviflora  
\va
\sy
\sc Excoecaria parviflora  
\gr manyingila
\gg manyingila
\xv
\xe
\rf I. Hector. 2002. Bilinarra Bush Medicine. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so 050518mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc manyingila.jpg
\nt seen on Buntine Hwy on the way to PH (050330), and at Mistake Crossing (050518)
\nt LC-This tree has small leaves and has white sap; it grows of plains and creeklines. 
\ee This tree has small leaves and white sap. It grows on plains and along creek lines. You can boil the leaves and use the liquid to wash sores on the scalp caused by nits. You can also burn the wood and use the smoke to keep mosquitoes away. The smoke has a nice smell. The hard dark timber also makes good boomerangs called 'gurrubardu' and shields called 'mirda'. The branches and leaves can also be used as fish poison. You drag them through small waterholes, making the fish float to the surface, where they can be collected, cooked and eaten. You should not get the white milk-like sap near your eye as it can cause blindness. Sugarbag called 'namawurru' or 'ngarlu' can be found in this tree.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx manyjangga
\sf manyjangga_CA.mp3

\sd K Water Animals
\re crab
\re Holthuisana transversa

\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc crab.jpg
\ee Crabs live in burrows in the mud near creeks and swamps. In the past they were cooked and eaten. Now they are used as bait. They are a totem for some people. 
\nt

\lx mardumardu
\sf mardumardu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge antbed
\de antbed, termite mound
\sd G Environment
\sd M Plants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re antbed
\re termite mound
\sy
\gr mardumardu
\gg tamarra
\xv Mardumardu bani nyila-ma ganggu munuwu-yirri.
\xe She broke up that antbed to take back to camp.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.53: 2003
\sfx mardumardu_IH_eg1_mardumardu.mp3
\xv Nyawa-ma-rna barru dajgarra mardumardu wumara-yawung.
\xe I'm going to pound the antbed with a stone.
\rf Bilinarra Grammar 2013 EX (1103)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_05ih:(2:00-7:30)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf mun.gud
\pc Antbed.jpg
\ee Termite mounds are used in bush medicine. The fine soil from inside the ant hill is used to treat diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. The inner soil is heated on a fire and then added to water. This is allowed the grass bits settle out before it is drunk. This drink also promotes milk for nursing mothers. It is also used when 'cooking' babies to strengthen their body. Newborns are slathered in a mix of wet antbed and 'mirndiwirri' to close their fontanelle. The 'mirndiwirri' is burnt down and mixed with the crushed and heated antbed. Around the age of one, mothers 'cook'  babies' lower backs and legs in the same mixture to help them start walking. Antbed is also placed over a fire with water and the baby is held in the smoke and steam. This makes the baby physically strong in later life. Antbed is also used in conjunction with other bush medicines including 'warrwa'. 'Warrwa' is added to the wet slurry after the antbed has been heated up. This is a dryer mixture. Ground sugarbag called 'nanggalij' is often found in termite mounds, especially the large rounded mounds. In the past the larger mounds were hollowed out in the centre and you could sit in them during heavy rain periods and stay dry. Porcupines (echidnas) called 'jungguwurru' are sometimes found camped in the holes in termite mounds. They like to eat the termites inside.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx marlag
\sf marlag_CA.mp3
\ps cv
\ge swear
\de swear
\sd R Talking and Looking
\re swear
\sy

\gr
\gg ngartikirri, junana, yirrigug (not in dict but SH says this is a Gurindji word)

\lx marlangarr
\sf marlangarr_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge mistletoe
\de mistletoe
\sd M Plants
\re mistletoe
\re Amyema benthamii
\sy narlinjirri
\sy ngalinggirri
\sc Amyema benthamii
\gr
\gg marlangarr
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc marlangarr.jpg
\ee These plants grow on trees. They are often seen growing on bloodwoods, for example 'jardburru' and bauhinia trees called 'wanyarri'. Birds and children eat the fruit which is like chewing gum.
\nt
\sn 2
\ge mistletoe
\de mistletoe
\sd M Plants
\re Lysiana subfalcata
\sy narlinjirri
\sy ngalinggirri
\sc Lysiana subfalcata
\gr
\gg marlangarr
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee These plants grow on trees. The fruit are eaten by birds. The leaves are placed on a fire and the smoke used to smoke babies to make them strong and healthy.
\nt
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx marlarn
\sf marlarn_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge river.red.gum
\de river red gum
\sd M Plants
\re gum (river red)
\re river red gum
\re red gum
\re Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\sy dimarlarn
\sc Eucalyptus camaldulensis
\gr dimalarn
\gg marlarn
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc dimarlarn.jpg
\nt LC- lirid is the verb for dragging the fish poison in the water.
\ee The leaves are used in bush medicine. You boil the new leaves until the water goes cloudy. The liquid is used as a wash to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya', skin problems and coughs called 'gulyurrg'. A small amount may also be drunk to treat coughing. This liquid has a good smell like Vicks. The leaves may also be placed on a burnt down fire to produce smoke. The patient is then rubbed with fat and wafted with the smoke. This heals the person by passing the smell of the tree over them. Babies and small children are held over the smoking leaves. The leaves can be used as fish poison. Small branches and twigs are thrown onto small waterholes, or the branches are dragged through the water. The fish become 'drunk' and float to the surface, where they can be easily collected, cooked and eaten. The leaves can also be added to any meat being cooked in a ground oven. They keep the meat moist and they give the meat a good flavour. Bush turkeys called 'jamud' can be stuffed with the leaves prior to cooking. Small leafy branches can also be spread on the ground to keep meat clean while it is being prepared and after it is cooked. Sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. The wood also makes good firewood. Witchetty grubs called 'lamawurd' can also be found in the lower trunk of this tree. The sugar-leaf, a sweet edible insect, collected from this tree is called 'burrngun'.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx marlarrb

\lx marlimarli
\sf marlimarli_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge butterfly
\de butterfly, moth
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re butterfly
\re moth
\re Lepidoptera
\va
\sy
\sc Lepidoptera
\gr marlimarli
\gg marlimarli
\xv Baraj bunya marlimarli murrgun.
\xe She found three butterflies
\rf I. Hector. 2007. Colouring in and Language book. Produced by J. Spence for DAC
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(22:55-24:50)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(18:00-18:20)
\pc butterfly.jpg
\cf Marlimarlilarni
\cf milgurr
\cf murrguriny
\ee There are many different types of butterflies and moths in various colours and sizes. When they come close to you or land on you it indicates that a family member will be coming to see you soon. There are a number of Dreaming sites near Nitjpurru (Pigeon Hole), the main ones are Marliyirralarni and Marlimarlilarni.
\nt
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx marnba
\sf marnba_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge eel-tail.catfish
\de eel-tail catfish, Hyrtl's Tandan
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (eel-tailed)
\re flat-tailed catfish
\re eel-tail catfish
\re Hyrtl's Tandan
\re Neosilurus hyrtlii
\re Neosilurus ater
\sy bardigibanu
\gr marnba
\gg marnpa
\va
\sc Neosilurus hyrtlii
\sc Neosilurus ater
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(9:05)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc flat-tailed_catfish.jpg
\ee Eel-tail catfish are generally caught with a spear or a spinifex bundle used as a fish net. They generally do not take bait on hand-lines. The larger ones can be roasted and eaten. The flesh is tasty. The smaller ones are used as bait to catch larger fish such as barramundi called 'yinarrwa'. These eel-tail catfish have dangerous spines that must be carefully avoided. These fish often eat small stones that look like the fruit of 'bardigi' trees hence their other name.
\nt CHECK - JS - might be bardigibanuwu
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx marnda
\sf marnda_CA.mp3

\de bush gum
\sd E Food and Cooking
\sd M Plants
\re gum (bush)
\re bush gum
\va
\sy mardiya
\sc
\gr mardiya
\gg martiya
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050728bb,mh
\ee You can use the gum to treat diarrhoea. You soak it in water and make a thick tea. Kids eat it for fun. It can make you very thirsty.
\nt Barbara and Mildred say this is the Bilinarra word, 'mardiya' is Gurindji

\lx marndayag
\sf marndayag_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge pear.tree
\de pear tree
\sd M Plants
\re pear tree
\re Terminalia platyphylla
\va
\sy
\sc Terminalia platyphylla
\gr marndayang
\gg marntayak
\so 050518mh
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc marndayag.jpg
\ee This large tree grows in creeks and river beds. It is an excellent shade tree. The gum that exudes from damaged trunks and branches can be eaten. It is called 'marnda' and is a highly sought-after delicacy. The gum is also used to treat diarrhoea called 'ngajgula' and to strengthen the digestive tract. The wood can be used as firewood. The fruit is also eaten by black cockatoos called 'walugbin'.
\cf marnda
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx marralung
\sf marralung_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black.plum
\de black plum
\sd M Plants
\re black plum
\re Vitex glabrata
\va
\sy muying
\sy burrgarl
\sc Vitex glabrata
\gr marralung
\gg muying
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(16:45-18:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(15:15-16:15)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc muying.jpg
\nt tree with fruit at start of wet season.  Was used to make fire before there were matches
and lighters.  051130 Barbara says marrarlung is the tree, muying is the fruit, fruit
comes at start of wet season.
\ee The black fruit are eaten when they are ripe. They are very sweet and tasty. Traditionally they are collected off the ground because picking fruit from the tree was said to cause eye disease. The fruit can also be pounded on a flat rock and made into small dampers, which are lightly roasted and are highly regarded as a food source. In the old days the dry sweet fruit was washed then cooked in bark or a coolamon with small hot flat rocks. The ripe juicy fruit was also washed then pounded on rocks before being eaten, particularly by people with bad teeth. The fruit are generally produced around the early wet season, but sometimes are available later in the year. When the firefly begins blinking its light, it indicates the fruit are ripe and ready to eat. The straight dry stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches. They are used to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method called 'binyinyib'. 
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\sf marrangan_CA.mp3

\lx Marrgandu
\sf Marrgandu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de Nangangari Dreaming place. This is a waterhole a long way off the road to Yarralin. You can find it just past Giliyanga. You have to walk through some scrub, across grass plains and over a flat topped hill to reach roughly layered sedimentary rock. The site is a waterhole which at one point was very deep. Sand has filled up some of it now. Another waterhole at this site has a short cave which you can see through to the other side
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv Yalangurlu-ma-lu yani gurlanggurla Marrgandu. 
\xe They went south to Marrgandu.
\rf I. Hector. Nangangari Dreaming video and booklet. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\sfx Marrgandu_IH_eg2_yala.mp3
\so FM:PigeonHole:IH:BIL04.track01.01aud:2003
\pc 
\gp 732222E, 8143206N (On flat hill just before it. Lost pen)
\nt
\dt 29/Apr/2008

\lx milbirri
\sf milbirri_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge mullet
\de mullet
\sd K Water Animals
\re mullet
\sy 
\va milbirriny
\re Liza alata
\sc Liza alata
\gr
\gg mipirri
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc mullet.jpg
\ee This fish is good to use as live bait to catch bigger fish, though the larger ones are good to eat. They are hard to catch on hand-lines called 'wuyurrun' as they don't take bait. They often occur in large schools which makes them easier to spear.

\lx milinyin
\sf milinyin_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bamboo
\de bamboo
\sd M Plants
\re bamboo
\re Bambusa arnhemica
\va
\sy
\sc Bambusa arnhemica
\gr milinyin
\gg milinyin
\ee This plant does not occur in Bilinarra country. It occurs in areas to the north such as Daly River and the Darwin area. In the past the stems were traded with northern Aboriginal groups. The strong flexible stems can be used to make spear shafts and larger stems can also be used to make didgeridoos. Sometimes they are also used to make rafts. These were covered with large sheets of paper bark to make them more stable. They were tied together with bush string, and pandanus stems were also used. 
\so 050330
\nt
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx minawud
\sf minawud_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge euro
\de male rock or hill kangaroo, euro
\sd H Mammals
\re rock kangaroo
\re hill kangaroo
\re kangaroo (hill)
\re kangaroo (rock)
\re euro
\re Macropus robustus
\va
\sy bunggiyid
\sy bamarrngarna
\sy wumarangarna
\sc Macropus robustus
\gr ngalijirri (antilopine), bunggayin (hill kangaroo)
\gg kumpang, pungkiyin
\so Ethnobiology LC080605BIL.PHmhbbca ~40:00
\pc euro.jpg
\ee These kangaroos are often seen in hilly areas and are good to eat after roasting. They often have longish hair and can range in colour from dark grey to light grey to a bit reddish. This kangaroo is sometimes also called 'wumarangarna' or 'bamarrngarna', which means rock-dweller and refers to its preferred habitat in rocky areas. The tendons, called 'gambun', from the tails are used to attach spear heads called 'yirlga' or axe heads called 'gurrwa' to shafts, and hooks called 'narra' to spear-throwers called 'warlmaya'. 
\dt 04/Jul/2008

\lx mindaarraj
\sf mindaarraj_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge water.lily
\de water lily
\sd M Plants
\re water lily
\re lily
\re Nymphaea macrosperma
\va
\sy
\sc Nymphaea macrosperma
\gr jalgi, jigamurru
\gg mirntaarraj, kulkurtukurtu, ngatinyan, pumata
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_03ih:(7:30)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc mindaarraj.jpg
\nt edible seeds and fruit
\nt
\ee Different parts of the water lily can be eaten. The fruit are called 'bumbarda'. You collect them from the bottom of the water by feeling around for them. You peel the skin off to expose the seeds which can be eaten. The seeds are very tasty and somewhat oily. You can roast the fruit or they may be eaten uncooked. You can also dry the seeds in the sun and grind them into a flour to make johnnycakes called 'mangarri'. You then roast these. The flower of the lily is called 'gulgudugudu'. The stem is called 'girliwarr'. You can also eat this once you peel off the green skin. You can also eat the tuber in the mud once you roast it. It is called 'yirrngan'. The darker ones are considered to be the mother of the yam, 'ngadinyan', and their babies are referred to as 'nanda'. There is a billabong near Pigeon Hole called Nawundarni which relates to the Water-lily Dreaming story. You can brush leaves over a hole in the rocks here which helps the water-lilies grow.  
\cf gurlgurdugurdu
\cf bumbarda
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx mirndibuwa
\sf mirndibuwa_CA.mp3

\lx mirndiwirri
\sf mirndiwirri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge boomerang.tree
\de boomerang tree
\sd M Plants
\re boomerang tree
\re Hakea arborescens
\va
\sy
\sc Hakea arborescens
\rf I. Hector. 2002. Bilinarra Bush Medicine. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\gr minidwirri
\gg mirntiwirri, ngirrirri
\xv An mirndiwirri-yawung darug-ba-yi yuwani ngayiny-ju-ma ngamayi-lu. 
\xe And my mother bathed me with the mirndiwirri tea.
\rf IH: FM: BIL01.track02.05: 2003: 03:28min
\sfx mirndiwirri_IH_eg1_an.mp3
\xv Mirndiwirri ngarlaga mana nyila-ma Nanagu-lu-ma gambarnu garu-wu yabagayi-wu.
\xe Nanagu gets mirndiwirri seeds for 'cooking' the babies.
\rf IH: FM: BIL05aud: 2003: 05:27min
\sfx mirndiwirri_IH_eg2_mirndiwirri.mp3
\cf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt See 'Children's Bush Medicine' book. Mix ashes of wood with
dirt to make 'hot ground' (jurrbarra), which is smeared on babies to keep them healthy. Can also mix the seed with water in a drum, have kids take a shower in it.
\pc mirndiwirri.jpg
\ee You can use the ashes mixed with termite mound or 'mardumardu' to treat babies. You lie the baby down on a layer of this mix and more is piled around the baby and firmly pressed against the arms, chest, throat, hips, lower back and legs. The child's legs are straightened as the hot mix is applied. This procedure, called 'gambarnub' or cooking has the effect of closing the baby's fontanelle or strengthening the baby's legs in preparation for walking. Adults with sore joints are also treated this way. You can also use the seeds or 'ngarlaga' to treat small children. You boil the seeds and make babies sit in the liquid. It makes their legs strong, helping them to start walking. The hard timber makes good boomerangs. In the past, people made ashes called 'yarnarndi' from burning the leaves. These ashes were mixed with tobacco and chewed.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx mirrgiliny
\sf mirrgiliny_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge spinifex
\de big spinifex
\sd M Plants
\re spinifex (big)
\re Triodia sp.
\va
\sy
\sc Triodia sp.
\gr
\gg mirrkiriny, wilarrawurru
\cf jigala
\cf warraaj
\cf warrwa
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee You can use the sticky leaves and stems to treat congestion and skin ailments. The wax called 'warraaj' or 'jigala' is used to attach a spear or axe head to the shaft. You hold the wax over flames until it goes black and soft. Then you beat it out, and repeat the process. You place the wax in the shaft and stick the head in. The whole joint is then tied up with 'gumbun' (animal tendon). When the wax hardens and the tendon dries, the result is a very hard joint. You can also burn the leaves to repel mosquitoes called 'ganamarurru'. The spinifex is also used in a fishing technique where the grass is rolled along in the water.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx miyad
\sf miyad_CA.mp3

\de fully-initiated man
\sd B People
\re man (initiated)

\dt 30/Oct/2008

\lx miyaga
\sf miyaga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge red-flowered.kurrajong
\de red-flowered kurrajong
\sd M Plants
\re red-flowered kurrajong
\re kurrajong (red-flowered)
\re Brachychiton megaphyllus
\sy ginyjirrga
\sc Brachychiton megaphyllus
\re Brachychiton spectabilis
\sc Brachychiton spectabilis
\pc ginyjirrga.jpg
\ee This is a Mudburra word. The seeds inside the pod are edible, but not the hairs. The seeds are taken out of the large pod. They are then pounded, winnowed out or burnt to get rid of the fine hairs. Finally they are crushed, eaten raw or made into johnny cakes. The skin of the inner pod of the fruit can also be rubbed on the skin to make it lighter like Mungamunga women's skin. When the sunsets in the mid dry season turn red and streaky it indicates that the fruit are ready to be collected.
\so 050728bb,mh
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx mugmug
\sf mugmug_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge owl
\de barking owl and others
\sd J Birds
\re owl
\re barking owl
\re Ninox connivens
\va
\sc Ninox connivens
\gr mugmug
\gg mukmuk (Southern Boobook, Ninox novaeseelandiae)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_04ih:(11:15, 11:35)
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_05ih:(5:30-6:20)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_03ih:(18:00-19:10)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_04ih:(00:00-1:20, 2:50-3:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(9:05-9:10, 11:00-11:20)
\pc barking_owl.jpg
\nt 051123: barking owl, southern boobook, possibly barn owl; the name mugmug is imitative of the how the bird sings out at night, "mug mug" and lets you know when people are coming or that it's time to wake up, not eaten.  Southern Boobook (JS051123BIL.DAC_04ih 2:50 and  forward) definitely makes this call, seems most certain.
\ee The name 'mugmug' is based on the sound of their call. All owls are given the same name, but this is the most common species. 
\nt BIL?- There is a creation period story about this owl.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx mulurrmi
\sf mulurrmi_SH.mp3
\sn 1
\ps n
\ge wattle.species
\de wattle species
\sd M Plants
\re wattle type
\re Acacia conjunctifolia
\va
\sy
\sc Acacia conjunctifolia
\gr
\gg murlurrmi (turpentine bush, Acacia lysiphloia, Acacia monticola)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(20:15-20:25)
\nt Mentioned in NG dict in entry for 'birrbuny' as a Wardaman word for a species of
acacia that is used for medicinal purposes.  Found at "long ridge" near the Victoria River
crossing.
\nt
\ee This is a good medicine plant. You can boil the leaves and use the water to wash sores or 'marndara'. 'Lamawurd' or witchetty grubs are often found in the roots of these trees, particular in desert areas.
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge turpentine.wattle
\de turpentine wattle
\sd M Plants
\re turpentine wattle
\re wattle (turpentine)
\re Acacia lysiphloia
\va
\sy
\sc Acacia lysiphloia
\gr
\gg murlurrmi (turpentine bush, Acacia lysiphloia, Acacia monticola)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc mulurrmi.jpg
\ee This is a good medicine plant. You boil the leaves and use the water to wash sores. 'Lamawurd' (witchetty grubs) are often found in the roots of these trees, particular in desert areas.
The leaves can also be warmed on a fire and held against sore muscles and joints to relieve pain. The heated leaves can also be held against the head to relieve headaches. Leaves may be placed on hot coals so that they produce smoke. The smoke is allowed to waft around the body to treat the same symptoms.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx mulybu
\sf mulybu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge calm
\de calm, placid person, easy to get along with, friendly dog
\sd N Description
\re gentle
\re placid
\re calm (person)
\so Anzac RN90-016a
\dt 31/Oct/2008

\lx mulyuguna
\sf mulyuguna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black-headed.python
\de black-headed python, pie-bald snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re snake (pie-bald)
\re black-headed python
\re python (black-headed)
\re pie-bald snake
\re Aspidites melanocephalus
\va
\sy waluru
\sy warlujabi
\sy murnduj
\sc Aspidites melanocephalus
\gr
\gg muylukuna, murntuj
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_03ih:(6:20, 6:25, 8:45, 10:00)
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_03ih:(6:50)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc black_headed_python.jpg
\cf naminamij
\nt Ivy says warlujabi is Gurindji, mulyuguna is Bilinarra; see note at warlujabi.  Note tthat
the "bible" here might be "purple"--Ivy and Mildred on 050921 were pointing to its
coloration.  Or "piebald"? (cf GU dict entry for black-headed python = murntuj,
includes common name "Piebald Snake".  Mildred (050921, 6:35) suggests this snake
might have a skin (maybe Namija or Nambin?). Token at 6:50 distorted, other tokens
very clearly 'ly'.  Used to be eaten, not any more.
\nt LC- warlujabi has not
\ee This python has a distinctive black shiny head and pretty stripes on its body. It is a quiet snake. It is sometimes called 'waluru' in reference to these stripes. Young people cannot eat the meat from this snake. If they do they will become crippled; only elders can eat the meat. This snake also has a sacred song that can only be heard by men. There is a Dreaming for this python and in the story it has the name 'naminamij'.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx Mungamunga
\sf Mungamunga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spirit.women
\de spirit women
\sd C Language and Culture
\sd B People
\re spirit women
\gr
\gg mungamunga
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050608mh
\so 050616ih
\so 051110ih
\pc
\cf jarrarda
\ee The Mungamunga are spirit women who appear to women in dreams and give them songs. These songs are called 'jarrarda' and are secret women's songs. The Mungamunga also steal husbands and children. The Mungamunga passed through Bilinarra country visiting many places created by the Nangangari. There are Mungamunga songs associated with these places. There are still Mungamunga at Kunawa (Cattle Creek).
\nt
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx mun.gud
\sf mungud_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge termite
\de termite or white ants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re termite
\re white ant
\re Isoptera spp 
\va
\sy
\sc Isoptera spp 
\re Macrotermes spp 
\sc Macrotermes spp 
\gr mun.gud, mun.gun
\gg murnkurt
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FM:PigeonHole:IH:BIL03:28/08/03
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Termite.jpg
\ee Termites eat the wood on the inside of trees. You can make didgeridoos from the hollow trunks and branches called  'gulundurru'. Porcupines (echidnas) called 'jungguwurru', frill-necked lizards called 'ngarranginy' and bush turkeys called 'jamud' like to eat the termites and their eggs. In the past the eggs were eaten by humans too. They were collected from the ant-beds called 'mardumardu' and then winnowed in a coolamon called a 'gawarla' to remove the dust and grass seeds. The eggs were then eaten raw.
\dt 07/Feb/2008

\lx murlguwurru
\sf murlguwurru_SH.mp3

\sd J Birds
\re egret (great)

\pc Great_Egret.jpg
\gr mulguwurru

\so JS051123BIL.KAT_04ih:(03:20)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(3:50-4:30)
\nt 060119 Ivy says this is like jalwa (jarlwa)
\nt CHECK pronunciation
\nt 060124ih Ivy says this is like jalaw (jarlwa) only with dark blue colour.  Tokens ambiguous, but one good "murlguwurru".
\nt 060209 Ivy says like an ibis but with blue colour, found at billabongs at Pigeon Hole.
\ee This large white bird is always seen around the water's edge poking around for food with its beak.

\lx murlu-
\ps dem
\ge this.one
\de this, proximal demonstrative, this one
\sd V Space and Time
\dk dijan
\re this
\va murla-
\sy nyawa
\gr murlu
\gg murlu
\ee This bare form is rarely found. Generally 'nyawa' is used, and 'murlu' is the stem used for inflected forms. Note that younger speakers use only 'nyawa' as a stem and no longer 'murlu'
\se murlulu
\de this one did it
\se murlunggu
\de this one did it
\se murluwu
\de for this one

\lx murrulumbu
\sf murrulumbu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge prickle.bush
\de prickle bush
\sd M Plants
\re prickle bush
\re Dichrostachys spicata
\sc Dichrostachys spicata
\gr murrulumbu (spike tree, needle brush)
\gg murrulumpu (bindi-eye)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This plant has sharp hard prickles. It grows in open areas and is a good shade tree. Bullocks, camels and goats eat the leaves. It is used for making spear-thrower hooks called 'narra'.
\sn 2
\ge tree.sp
\de type of tree
\sd M Plants
\re Vachellia farnesiana
\sc Vachellia farnesiana
\ee This plant has sharp hard prickles. In the past the flowers were crushed and sprinkled on ladies' hair for decoration and perfume. The sharp prickles can be poked into the base of warts, this slowly kills the wart and after a while they fall off.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx murrunggun
\sf murrunggun_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge water.rat
\de water rat
\sd K Water Animals
\re water rat
\re rat (water)
\re Hydromys chrysogaster
\sc Hydromys chrysogaster
\pc Water_Rat.jpg
\ee They live in rivers and permanent waterholes where they like to eat mussels called 'dugu', fish called 'yawu' and freshwater crabs called 'gaburdij'. They are good swimmers. Water rats are not eaten by humans. Sometimes they eat all the mussels at a waterhole so that there are none left.

\lx muying
\sf muying_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black.plum
\de black plum
\sd M Plants
\re black plum
\re Vitex glabrata
\va
\sy marralung
\sy burrgarl
\sc Vitex glabrata
\gr muying
\gg muying
\xv Ngandiba yana-rnalu warlagab ngamanburru-wu muying-wu.
\xe Us mob are going to look for conkerberries and black plum.
\rf Ivy and Sheila Hector. 2006. Wanyjiga-warla-n yana? Produced by L. Campbell for DAC
\so 050609bb,mh
\so 051130bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc muying.jpg
\nt CHECK - This doesn't sound right. 051130 : Barbara says marrarlung is the tree, muying is the fruit; fruit comes at start
of wet season. NG dict has the 'muying' and 'marralung' as the same species.
\ee The black fruit are eaten when they are ripe. They are very sweet and tasty. Traditionally they are collected off the ground because picking fruit from the tree was said to cause eye disease. The fruit can also be pounded on a flat rock and made into small dampers, which are lightly roasted and are highly regarded as a food source. In the old days the dry sweet fruit was washed then cooked in bark or a coolamon with small hot flat rocks. The ripe juicy fruit was also washed then pounded on rocks before being eaten, particularly by people with bad teeth. The fruit are generally produced around the early wet season, but sometimes are available later in the year. When the firefly begins blinking its light, it indicates the fruit are ripe and ready to eat. The straight dry stems are used to make fire-sticks or bush matches. They are used to light a fire using the traditional drilling or friction method called 'binyinyib'. 
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx na
\sf na_CA.mp3
\ps part
\ge FOC
\de focus particle borrowed from Kriol (originally from the English word 'now'). It is used to draw attention to something in the sentence or contrast it with something else. It is also used to link two events which happen one after the other. It translates as 'then' in these cases. 
\sd Y Word Endings
\re now
\re then
\sy -warla, -barla
\va -na
\gr na
\gg na
\xv Nyila-ma-lu yanirni ngajig-barni na garlarra. 
\xe Then that mob kept coming all the way west.
\rf IH: FM: BIL04.track01.01aud: 2003: 04:53min
\sfx na_IH_eg1_nyila.mp3
\xv Gungulu-na-yi na wanda, wardan-nginyi.
\xe My blood is falling from [my] hand.
\rf IH: RN90-010a: 10:03min
\sfx gungulu_IH_eg1_gungulu.mp3
\nt This focus particle is an established Kriol borrowing. It is used instead of '-warla' and '-barla' by younger speakers. It is used to draw attention to something in the sentence or contrast it with something else. It is also used to mean to link two events which happen one after the other. It translates as 'then' in these cases.

\lx naminamij
\sf naminamij_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black-headed.python
\de black-headed python, pie-bald snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re snake (pie-bald)
\re black-headed python
\re python (black-headed)
\re pie-bald snake
\re Aspidites melanocephalus
\va
\sy
\sc Aspidites melanocephalus
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\cf mulyuguna
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_04ih:(4:00, 6:50, 7:30, 9:25-9:30)
\ee This python has a distinctive black shiny head and pretty stripes on its body. It is a quiet snake. It is sometimes called 'waluru' in reference to these stripes. Young people cannot eat the meat from this snake. If they do they will become crippled; only elders can eat the meat. This snake also has a sacred song that can only be heard by men. There is a Dreaming for this python and in the story it has the name 'naminamij'.
\nt Similarity to Namija skin...quiet one.  Black head.
\nt 060209ih asked Ivy about any connection with Namija skin.  Not clear that there is a
connection with the skin name still, but Ivy said that this is the Dreaming name for this
snake, the name it had in the dreamtime.  She offered another word "jimurug" either
for this snake (or for mulyuguna?) as the common (non-Dreaming) name.
\dt 04/Jan/2008

\lx nanguba
\sf nanguba_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge cat
\de cat, pussycat
\sd H Mammals
\dk pujikat
\re cat
\re pussycat
\re Felis catus
\va
\sy ngajugayin
\sy ngaya
\sc Felis catus
\gr walumumba, wilurrumawu
\gg ngaya, minija, nyutinyuti
\xv Nyila-ma nanguba-ma mani-rna garlarra.
\xe I got that cat out west.

\pc cat.jpg
\nt
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx nangurrungurru
\sf nangurrungurru_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge emu
\de emu
\sd J Birds
\dk imiyu
\re emu
\re Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\sy yibarrardu
\sc Dromaius novae-hollandiae
\gr yibarrardu
\gg yiparrartu
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so RJ: MCCONVELL_P08-014878
\pc emu.jpg
\cf wininiwinini
\cf wanya
\nt
\ee Emus are not seen much near Pigeon Hole community, but they are plentiful in some bush areas on Bilinarra country. Emus eat much of the bush fruit that people also eat. They also eat many insects. In the early days people hunted them with spears called 'mirlarrang' and boomerangs called 'gurrubardu'. If a spear misses, a boomerang can be thrown at the legs to make it fall down. Hunters may also wait for them at billabongs where they kneel to drink. They are easy targets then. When killed, emus are then gutted and the innards called 'garnngirri'  or 'lubu' are throw away, but the 'durlang' (heart), 'marlumba' (liver) and 'wararr' (fat) can be put back in for cooking. The bird is then cooked in a ground oven using a method called 'durdurl', with hot stones called 'guruwarrany' placed inside the gut cavity, then covered with paperbark to keep the meat clean. The meat is dark and smells strong. You can also eat the eggs. Baby emus are called 'wininiwinini' and the feathers of an emu are called 'wanya'.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx nanyjarrnga
\sf nanyjarrnga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bloodwood.sugar-leaf
\de sugar-leaf found on bloodwood tree
\sd M Plants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re sugarleaf (bloodwood)
\re bloodwood sugarleaf
\re lerp (bloodwood)
\re Hemiptera
\re Psyllidae
\va
\sy
\sc Hemiptera
\sc Psyllidae
\cf burrngun
\cf malangarna
\cf jardburru
\pc Lerps.jpg
\ee These small white scale-like insect-coverings are collected off the leaves of a bloodwood called 'jardburru' during the early part of the dry season, when the first smoke or 'gabarru' is in the air. They are very sweet and tasty. The branches and twigs are broken off and left to dry over a calico sheet called a 'balginy'. The lerps are knocked off the leaves with a stick and then collected and shaped into small johnnycakes or biscuits and eaten. These can also be stored in cake-tins for weeks and months.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2008
\dt 13/Oct/2009

\lx Nan.ga Spring
\sf NangaSpring_CA.mp3

\de Nangangari Dreaming place. This is a spring
\sd O Place Names

\xe From there they kept coming to another place called Nan.ga Spring
\rf IH: BIL04.track01.01aud: 2003: 04:22min
\sfx NangaSpring_IH_eg1_yalangurlu.mp3
\so I. Hector. Nangangari Dreaming video and booklet. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so NLC: Bilinara (Coolibah-Wavehill Stock Route land Claim). May 1989. (Anzac Munganyi, Old Jimmy Manngayarri, Barry Young)
\nt
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx naribu
\sf naribu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge mussel
\de mussel from billabong
\sd K Water Animals
\re mussel (billabong)
\re Velesunio wilsonii
\va
\sy dugu
\sy wijalngarniny
\sc Velesunio wilsonii
\gr wijarlnganany, daga, narubu
\gg murrunkirn, narupu, turta, wijalngarniny
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology LC080604BIL.PHmhbbca
\pc mussel.jpg
\ee This short, solid mussel is found in the mud at the edges of billabongs called 'langgarna'. They are roasted on hot coals and eaten. Mussels cannot be eaten by boys; men can only eat them after they have been initiated. The meat can also be boiled in water with a little salt and made into soup called 'yingalg' and this can be drunk to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' and diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. The juice from mussels can also be used to treat ear aches and infections. It is dripped straight into the ear.
\cf jiwirrirri
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx narlambang
\sf narlambang_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge saltwater.crocodile
\de saltwater crocodile
\sd I Reptiles
\dk aligeida
\va narlamba
\re crocodile (saltwater)
\re saltwater crocodile
\re Crocodylus porosus
\sy
\sc Crocodylus porosus
\gr
\gg narlampany
\xv Nyila-ma-wuliny-nga bayarni narlamba-nggu.
\xe Maybe the salt-water crocodile bit them. 
\rf AN: RN90-003b: 01:04min
\sfx gu_AN_eg1_nyila.mp3
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_02ih:(7:00-7:20)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(15:05-16:05)
\pc saltwater_croc.jpg
\cf laging
\nt CHECK pronunciation - 060124 first token at 15:05 could be ng-?
\ee These large man-eating crocodiles are common in large rivers called 'lamarn' and billabongs. They are very dangerous and are carefully avoided. They also attack horses called 'yawarda' or 'dimana', cattle and kangaroos called 'jiya' when they drink from the river. Occasionally these large crocodiles come up river to places like Pigeon Hole, but generally there are only freshwater crocodiles in these areas. The small hatchlings are called 'laging'.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx narlinjirri

\de mistletoe
\sd M Plants
\re mistletoe

\va
\sy marlangarr
\sy ngalinggirri
\sc Amyema benthamii
\gr
\gg marlangarr
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc marlangarr.jpg
\ee These plants grow on trees. They are often seen growing on bloodwoods, for example 'jardburru' and bauhinia trees called 'wanyarri'. Birds and children eat the fruit which is like chewing gum.

\sc Lysiana subfalcata
\gr
\gg marlangarr
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee These plants grow on trees. The fruit are eaten by birds. The leaves are placed on a fire and the smoke used to smoke babies to make them strong and healthy.

\lx ngaba
\sf ngaba_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge brother
\de brother, father's brother's son. Opposite sex siblings cannot call each other's names after a brother goes through ceremony. They also cannot share the same shade and a brother cannot eat food prepared by his sister.
\sd B People
\dk baba
\re brother (older)
\va baba
\sy ngabadi
\gr ngaba, baba
\gg ngaba, baba
\xv Warrguj mana nyanuny-ju ngaba-lu.
\xe Her brother picks her up.
\rf IH: FM: BIL05aud: 2003: 30:38min
\sfx ngaba_IH_eg1_warrguj.mp3
\so 050721bb,ih
\nt Only 'baba' is used now. Note that it is also found in Kriol, so it may be a Kriol word. It may have also derived as a babytalk form of 'ngaba'.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx ngabagardarn.gardarn
\sf ngabagardarnkgardarn_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge skink
\de skink or slippery lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re skink
\re slippery lizard
\re lizard (slippery)
\re Ctenotus spp
\va
\sy wirarra
\sc Ctenotus spp
\gr
\gg wirarra, ngapakartarnkartarn
\xv
\xe
\pc Skink.jpg
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This small lizard that can be described as 'girinygiriny' when it has slippery skin and then 'wirarra' when it grows legs. It eats insects and butterflies called 'marlimarli' and is active at dusk and dawn. It has no specific use and are generally left alone.

\lx ngagbarn
\sf ngagbarn_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge frog
\de any kind of frog
\sd K Water Animals
\sd I Reptiles
\re frog (any)
\va
\sy
\sc
\gr ngalja
\gg ngakparn
\xv Ngagbarn nyawa wumara-ngga bardaj garra.
\xe The frog is sitting up on the rock.
\rf I. Hector. 2005. Colouring in and Language book. Produced by J. Spence for DAC
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(22:30-22:40)
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_05ih:(1:55 - 2:00, 3:30, 6:45-8:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(26:50-28:00)
\nt 060124 Ivy gave this with picture of sand frog, but also rocket frog (possible
mis-identification?)
\nt
\sn 2
\ge sand.frog
\de sand frog
\sd K Water Animals
\sd I Reptiles
\re frog (sand)
\re sand frog
\re Limnodynastes ornatus
\re Cyclorana longipes
\sc Limnodynastes ornatus
\sc Cyclorana longipes
\ee These small frogs live in burrows in the ground, especially in sandy areas called 'warrayal' near water. Aboriginal people from the desert dig them up and use them as food. People use them as bait for catching fish called 'yawu'.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx ngaji
\sf ngaji_CA.mp3
\sn 1
\ps n
\ge father
\de father, father's brother
\sd B People
\dk dadi
\re father
\sy
\va ngajidi
\so RJ: MCCONVELL_P08-014874
\xv Ngayiny-ma ngaji-ma-rna garlamala, yalanggurra.
\xe I approached my father there. 
\rf DW: 1975: MCCONVELL_P08-014876: 44:29min
\sfx garlamala_DW_eg1_ngayiny.mp3
\nt Younger people are losing the 'father' meaning, using the Kriol term instead, with 'ngaji' meaning 'God' only.
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge God
\de God. These days most fathers are called 'Daddy' and God is called 'ngaji'
\sd C Language and Culture
\re God
\va
\sy
\gr ngaji
\gg ngaji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\nt Used as a noun, as well as an exclamation, similar to English.

\lx ngalgurun

\ps n
\ge onion.lily
\de onion lily
\sd M Plants
\re onion lily
\re lily (onion)
\re Crinum angustifolium
\va
\sy
\sc Crinum angustifolium
\gr
\gg ngalkurun, tilji
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc ngalgurun.jpg
\ee This plant has a tuber like an onion underneath. You can use it to prevent snake bites and to treat swollen legs. You pound the tuber and boil it. You then wash someone's legs in it.

\lx ngalinggirri
\sf ngalinggirri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge mistletoe
\de mistletoe
\sd M Plants
\re mistletoe
\re Amyema benthamii
\sy narlinjirri
\sy marlangarr
\sc Amyema benthamii
\gr
\gg marlangarr
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc marlangarr.jpg
\ee These plants grow on trees. They are often seen growing on bloodwoods, for example 'jardburru' and bauhinia trees called 'wanyarri'. Birds and children eat the fruit which is like chewing gum.
\nt
\sn 2
\ge mistletoe
\de mistletoe
\sd M Plants
\re Lysiana subfalcata
\sy marlangarr
\sy narlinjirri
\sc Lysiana subfalcata
\gr
\gg marlangarr
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee These plants grow on trees. The fruit are eaten by birds. The leaves are placed on a fire and the smoke used to smoke babies to make them strong and healthy.

\lx ngamalurd
\sf ngamalurd_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge mulla-mulla
\de mulla-mulla
\sd M Plants
\re mulla-mulla
\re Ptilotus exaltatus
\va
\sy
\sc Ptilotus exaltatus
\ee This small plant has pretty pink flowers and it often occurs in large numbers near roadsides. It can be boiled in water and the cooled liquid used as a wash to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya'. Sometimes horses and kangaroos eat the flowers when other feed is short.
\sn 2
\ge milk.vine
\de milk vine
\sd M Plants
\re milk vine
\re Sarcostemma viminale
\va
\sy
\sc Sarcostemma viminale
\ee This climbing plant produces milk when it is damaged. The stems can be used as fish poison. They are crushed up and thrown into small waterholes and fish float to the surface, where they can be easily collected, cooked and eaten. After using the fish poison the water cannot be drunk.
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx ngamanburru
\sf ngamanburru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge conkerberry
\de conkerberry
\sd M Plants
\re conkerberry
\re Carissa lanceolata
\va
\sy
\sc Carissa lanceolata
\gr ngamanburru
\gg ngamanpurru
\xv Ngandiba yana-rnalu warlagab ngamanburru-wu muying-wu.
\xe Us mob are going to look for conkerberries and black plum.
\rf Ivy and Sheila Hector. 2006. Wanyjiga-warla-n yana? Produced by L. Campbell for DAC
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_03ih:(15:15, 16:25)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc ngamanburru.jpg
\cf gumbulyu
\ee This is good bush tucker. It ripens during and after the wet season. The best way to collect them is by putting a ground sheet under the tree and hitting them with a stick. The ripe fruit fall easily and are gathered up this way. You can use the inner bark as a medicine for toothaches. You dig the roots up and scrape the inner bright orange wood off in fine shavings. This is pushed into the hole in a tooth and it stops the pain.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx ngamany
\sf ngamany_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge top.head
\de fontanelle (the join in the skull at the front top part of the head). The fontanelle is not joined when babies are born. Babies are treated with heated termite mound called 'mardumardu' to help it join.
\sd A Body
\re fontanelle
\cf ngarlaga
\va
\gr
\gg ngamany (fontanelle)
\so LC081017BIL.KATH_05sh 10:33
\nt LC: given in context of cooking school kids with gubuwubu, so not fontanelle. FM definitely just fontanelle.
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\gr buuny
\gg punypuny, ngamarlu

\xe

\lx ngamulurd
\sf ngamulurd_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge plant.species
\de type of plant
\sd M Plants
\re Euphorbia hirta
\sy lirrimilirrimi
\sc Euphorbia hirta
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc ngamulurd.jpg
\nt LC- check form 'garnbirrgarnbirr' given once by IH unrecorded.
\ee The white sap called 'ngabulu' is dabbed directly onto skin sores called 'marndara'. It is very good medicine. There are lots of these small plants around Pigeon Hole. The leaves are the same colour as a 'lirrimi' or centipedes when they dry out.
\sn 2
\ge mulla-mulla
\de mulla-mulla
\sd M Plants
\re mulla-mulla
\re Ptilotus exaltatus
\sy
\sc Ptilotus exaltatus
\ee This small plant has pretty pink flowers and it often occurs in large numbers near roadsides. It can be boiled in water and the cooled liquid used as a wash to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya'. Sometimes horses and kangaroos eat the flowers when other feed is short.
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx ngana
\sf ngana_CA.mp3
\ps quest
\sn 1
\ge who
\de who
\sd W Questions
\re who
\gr ngana
\gg ngana

\lx nganyiwan
\sf nganyiwan_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge sap
\de sap from bloodwood tree
\sd M Plants
\re sap from bloodwood
\va
\sy dirnung
\sc
\gr
\gg tirnung
\xv
\xe
\rf
\ee This sap is used in bush medicine. You can place the red sap directly onto an aching tooth and it stops the pain. You can also boil it in water and use the liquid to wash skin sores.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx ngarlamarriri
\sf ngarlamarriri_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge bronzewing
\de bronzewing pigeon
\sd J Birds
\re bronzewing (pigeon)
\re flock bronzewing
\re common bronzewing
\re Phaps histrionica
\va
\sc Phaps histrionica
\re Phaps chalcoptera
\sc Phaps chalcoptera
\gr
\gg ngarlamarriri
\xv
\so Ethnobiology LC080924BIL.PH_02bbca 7:37
\ee These birds sometimes occur in large flocks. They are only seen on open plains country where they hunt for seeds to eat. They are fat and the meat is good to eat after roasting on hot coals and ashes, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'.
\nt

\cf ngunyjung; gundarri; nanggarliny
\pc sugarbag.jpg
\ee Native bee-hives or sugarbag contain sweet dark honey that is very tasty and much sought after. The hives also contain wax, pollen and eggs. The small bees have no sting and are harmless.

\lx ngarrananggu
\sf ngarrananggu_SH.mp3

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Scorpion.jpg
\ee They have a painful sting in the tail and therefore are avoided. There is a special song to stop the pain. They are a Dreaming for some Bilinarra people.

Dreaming for some people at Pigeon Hole.

\lx ngarranginy
\sf ngarranginy_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge blanket.lizard
\de blanket lizard, frill-necked lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re lizard (blanket)
\re blanket lizard
\re frill-necked lizard
\re lizard (frill-necked)
\re Chlamydosaurus kingii
\va
\sy jaman.gurla
\sc Chlamydosaurus kingii
\gr ngaranginyi
\gg ngarrangirn
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_02ih:(6:05, 6:20)
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_02ih:(6:10, 8:40)
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc frilled_neck_lizard.jpg
\ee These lizards are roasted and eaten. The flesh and fat are tasty. The frill or blanket is burnt on ashes until it turns black and it is then rubbed with fat called 'wararr'. This is in turn rubbed through the hair called 'gardbi' to make it go dark and healthy. When the rains begin the blanket lizard runs around eating ants called 'bingi'. Frill-necked lizards are 'cheeky' or guliyan and will chase you and try to bite you. They are very aggressive when they have eggs.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\sf ngarranyana_CA.mp3

\de ceremony place, ring place, meeting place
\sd C Language and Culture

\re meeting place
\va
\sy bardardi
\gr
\gg
\xv Ngarranyana-nginyi burrb-nginyi lurrbu-rnalu yanarni.
\xe After [activity at] the dancing place is finished we come home.

\nt This is the proper Bilinarra word. Bardardi is the Gurindji word.

\de water, dew
\sd G Environment
\sd F Water
\re water
\re dew
\sy ngugu
\va
\sy gurdga
\sy ngabagu
\gr ngawa
\gg ngawa, ngapaku
\xv Ngawa-ngga na yuwarra darugab-gu na.
\xe She puts her in the water to bathe her.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03.93aud: 2003
\sfx ngawa_IH_eg1_ngawa.mp3
\xv Ngawa-lu garan mani bayarni-lu.
\xe They dug around for water there and drank it. 
\rf IH: FM: BIL04.25aud: 2003
\sfx ngawa_IH_eg2_ngawa.mp3
\xv Ngawa manda-ngalangulu!
\xe You lot - get us some water!
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (5:43)
\xv Ngawa-wu-ma-yi jiyarni.
\xe I was thirsty. [Lit: It burnt me for water].
\rf AN: RN90-006b: 14:06min
\sfx jiyala_AN_eg3_ngawa.mp3
\so felicity/Documents/Felicity_Work/DOBES/Bilinarra dictionary/Dict_Images\F_water\ngawa.jpg
\nt Babytalk form 'awa'
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx ngiliwunung
\sf ngiliwunung_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge blowfly
\de blowfly
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re blowfly
\sy girlimirlimu
\gr ngiliyawunung, ngiliwurnung, nyiliwunung
\gg ngiila
\xv
\re Diptera
\re Sarcophagidae
\sc Diptera
\sc Sarcophagidae
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(20:40-21:30, 22:30-22:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(5:40-6:55)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf birlngi
\pc blowfly.jpg
\ee This large dark fly is attracted to meat where it lays eggs that hatch into maggots that eat the meat. The maggots are called 'birlngi'.
\nt big fly, attracted to meat, lays its eggs in meat
\nt 060123 tokens sound like -wurn- not -wun-
\nt 060124 token around 5:40 sounds like -wurrung, but fast speech...
\dt 28/Jul/2008
