\lx ngimbija
\sf ngimbija_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge shitwood.tree
\de coolamon tree, helicopter tree or shitwood tree
\sd M Plants
\re coolamon tree
\re helicopter tree
\re shitwood tree
\re Gyrocarpus americanus
\va
\sy gulunjurru
\sc Gyrocarpus americanus
\gr
\gg kulunjurru
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\pc shitwood.jpg
\ee The wood is soft and makes light coolamons. Children make toy helicopters from the two-winged fruit. You can also boil the inner bark and use the water to treat ringworm.
\nt CHECK FM - nimbija in Gurindji. or ngimbija? Also known as gulunjurru (gulinjirri?).  Once used to make coolamon.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx ngimili
\sf ngimili_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge leichhardt
\de Leichhardt tree
\sd M Plants
\re Leichhardt tree
\re Nauclea orientalis
\sy jamba
\sc Nauclea orientalis
\pc jamba.jpg
\so AN: RN90-002a
\ee This is a large tree that grows on rivers or 'lamarn' and near springs called 'winyji'. It is a good shade tree. The fruit can be eaten when they are ripe and brown. The fruit that fall in the water are eaten by turtles, black bream and other fish so it is a good idea to fish under these trees. The wood is light and relatively soft, and some people think it is too light to use for any purpose.
\dt 04/Mar/2010

\sn 4
\ps case
\ge SOURCE
\de after. This ending is used to show that one action occurred before the other. (switch reference marker)
\sd Y Word Endings
\re by
\sy -ngurlu
\xv Nyawa-ma-rna jamana-ma janga galu-nginyi.
\xe My foot is sore from walking.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (4-157)
\xv Mirlijmirlij-nginyi bundu yabayaba wan.gu mila-ngga ngabanyji-ngga.
\xe The splinters get in her eye as a result of stripping the bark off the wood.
\rf SH: FM08_a093: 10:43min
\sfx -nginyi_SH_eg15_mirlijmirlij.mp3
\xv Burrb-nginyi-ma yuwarra gardag-gula na.
\xe After she finishes cooking the ashes, she puts it in the milk tin.
\rf IH: FM: BIL05.09aud: 2003
\sfx -nginyi_IH_eg16_burrb.mp3
\xv Jarragab-nginyi burrb-nginyi, yan.gu-rna-nga lurrbu-ma.
\xe After the meeting finishes, I might go back. 
\rf IH: RN90-014b: 08:59min
\sfx nginyi_IH_eg17_jarragab.mp3
\nt
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx nginyiwurda
\sf nginyiwurda_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge echidna
\de echidna
\sd H Mammals
\re echidna
\re porcupine
\re Tachyglossus aculeatus
\va
\sy jungguwurru
\sy bagayawung
\sc Tachyglossus aculeatus
\so Anzac: RN90-16b
\pc echidna.jpg
\ee nginyiwurda often live in rocky country, where they hide in crevasses and cracks. They can be pulled out with wire hooks or hooked branches. They are much more commonly seen at night when they walk around looking for food. They are most active during full moon periods in the cold weather of the dry season. When they walk they leave a little track where the prickles drag along the ground. When they are approached, they roll into a tight ball to protect themselves. Their favourite foods are ants called 'bingi' and termites called 'mun.gurd' which they eat with their tongue called 'jalany'. They are often found near termite mounds called 'mardumardu'. During the hot weather of the build-up they can be found in cool areas near rivers called 'lamarn', where they look for wet ground that is cool to sleep on. The name 'jungguwurru' is derived from Jaminjung (junggu=point of elbow plus -wurru=having). Porcupines or echidnas are also often called baga-yawung (having spikes). You can roast the flesh and eat it. The meat is sweet like pork. It has a lot of tasty white coloured fat. You need to chop off the spines and feet prior to cooking the whole body in a ground oven. You can soften the spines by placing them on hot coals for a short time or by placing them in a bucket of very hot water. The flesh cannot be eaten by young boys and mothers during initiation ceremonies. Pregnant women called 'ngardurr' cannot eat them because the spikes might poke the baby and it will be born a cripple. Jungguwurru has a Dreaming story about how he got his prickles. Jungguwurru got mad when he found out that the other animals weren't giving him the good meat. He took all of the shade trees away, so the other animals speared him, giving him his prickles.
\dt 06/Mar/2009

\lx ngungungmarna
\sf ngungungmarna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge nail-tail.kangaroo
\de nail-tail kangaroo, left-hand kangaroo
\sd H Mammals
\re nail-tail kangaroo
\re kangaroo (nail-tail)
\re left-hand kangaroo
\re Onychogalea unguifera
\va
\sy gururrunggu
\sc Onychogalea unguifera
\gr ngungungmana (rock wallaby, lefthanded wallaby, short eared wallaby, nail-tailed wallaby)
\gg ngungngungmarna (Northern Nailtail Wallaby, Onychogalea unguifera), kururrungku
\xv Nyawa-ma wumara-ngga garrwala buwarraj jamana minawud-gu jurlaga-wu ngungungmarna-wu
\xe In the dreamtime, this rock got footprints from kangaroo, birds and little kangaroos.
\rf I. Hector. 2006. Bilinarra language trip. Produced by J. Spence for DAC
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_05ih:(21:00)
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(00:30-00;40, 1:50-1:55)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(19:50-20:20)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt Ivy says the ngungung part is because of the noise it makes when it runs.
\pc Northern_nailtail_wallaby.jpg
\ee This kangaroo has a nail or 'libi' in the end of its tail and often makes a 'oo..oo..oo' noise when it is hopping. There is a special song that it sings as it hops along. It also holds its left arm up to its chest when hopping, and is sometimes called 'Left-hand Charlie' because of this habit. These kangaroos sometimes have a distinctive 'humped back'. They can be roasted in a ground oven and eaten, but do not taste very good. The tendons, called 'gambun', from the tails are used to attach spear heads called 'yirlga' or axe heads called 'gurrwa' to shafts, and hooks called 'narra' to spear-throwers called 'warlmaya'. 
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx nguni
\sf nguni_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge shovel.spear
\de shovel spear
\sd D Things
\re shovel spear
\re spear (shovel)
\va
\sy murrnginy
\gg nguni
\gr

\rf
\so LC080924BIL.PH_01eamkbbmh 3:50 Elmore Anzac
\pc
\cf warlmayi
\ee This spear is thrown with a spear-thrower  (warlmayi). 
It is thinner than a 'jarlgaji' and has a flat end.
\dt 21/Oct/2008

\lx ngunyal
\sf ngunyal_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.banana
\de small bush banana which grows on the ground
\so 051130bb
\sd M Plants
\re banana (bush)
\re bush banana
\re Tylophora sp. 
\va
\sy
\sc Tylophora sp. 
\gr
\gg gilibi
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc JS051130BIL.PIG_05
\cf gilibi
\ee There are two types of bush bananas: 'gilibi' which grows as a type of vine on a tree, and 'ngunyal' which grows on the ground. The 'ngunyal' is rounder than the 'gilibi' which is a longer fruit. The fruit of the 'ngunyal' ripens at the start of the wet season. They are eaten in the same way as a bush banana and are more tender and tasty when they are still young. When they get full sized they are stringy and fibrous to eat.
\nt
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\sfx ngurlu_AN_eg9_wanyjingurlu.mp3
\xv Nyamba-ngurlu-njina bani?

\lx ngurnungurnu

\ps n

\re tobacco (bush)
\re bush tobacco
\re cattle bush
\re Trichodesma zeylanica
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg ngurnungurnu
\sc Trichodesma zeylanica
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee In the old days, the leaves were used as bush tobacco. They were dried in the sun and smoked in long-stemmed pipes. They were also chewed like commercial tobacco called 'ngunyju' or 'warlayarra'. Cattle eat this plant when grass is running out.

\lx ngurragin
\sf ngurragin_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge dingo
\de dingo
\sd H Mammals
\re dingo
\re Canis familiaris dingo
\va
\sy
\sc Canis familiaris dingo
\gr ngurragin
\gg ngurrakirn
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(16:45, 16:55, 24:35)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(22:50-23:05)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc dingo.jpg
\nt
\ee In the past the scalps were collected and sold to the police called 'murnunggu' as part of a control program. They were eaten in the past when meat was scarce. They have not been eaten for a long time.  People in the old days used to keep them as pets and for hunting kangaroos called 'jiya', goannas called 'girrawa' and lizards. They were very good at finding game. But they would also kill animals at stations such as chickens and goats called 'gilbugud'. Wild dingoes breed in the cold weather time of the dry season, when they are often heard howling at night. Pastoralists often put out poisonous baits near waterholes to kill wild dingoes so that they don't harm cattle. Ngurragin is a Dreaming for some Bilinarra people and has an important creation period story associated with it.
\dt 28/Apr/2008

\lx ngurrawaji
\sf ngurrawaji_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge budgerigar
\de budgerigar
\sd J Birds
\re budgerigar
\re Melopsittacus undulates
\sy gulyulyurra
\sc Melopsittacus undulates
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc budgerigar.jpg
\ee Budgerigars nest in hollow trees and often occur in large flocks. In the past they were hunted with throwing sticks during the cold weather time. The sticks would be thrown into the flocks and sometimes a large number of birds would be caught at once. These were lightly roasted and then eaten. The younger ones were tender and tasty. The young budgerigars were also collected from the hollow trees by widening the entry into the trees and reaching in and taking them out.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx niinii
\sf niinii_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge finch
\de double-barred finch, other bird species?
\sd J Birds
\re finch
\sy
\gr niini (any small bird, e.g. finch species,  bird sp. with red markings)
\gg nii-nii
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_07ih:(7:05-7:30)
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_05ih:(10:25-10:30, 12:45-13:25)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_02ih:(8:00-8:50, 23:35-24:30, 25:20)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_03ih:(00:045-1:40, 2:35-2:50, 5:40-6:25, 7:00-7:55, 8:25-9:15, 19:25-20:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(12:35-12:50)
\pc double-barred_finch.jpg
\nt riverside bird (Barbara 050427); billabong bird, little one, spotted (Ivy 050510). 
\nt 051123: elicited with pictures of oriental pratincole (but then Ivy said not found in
Bilinarra country), rufous whistler (but then Ivy said it looks like niini but comes from
different country).  Named for its call "nii-nii".
\nt 060123 included crimson chat, white-throated gerygone, yellow chat, star finch, zebra
finch, double-barred finch, long-tailed finch, black-faced woodswallow.  Ivy said that
the double-barred finch is "really niini" and from Bilinarra country, but other(s) are
still niini, with different colours, like from different lands.  She says she only sees the
double-barred finch on Bilinarra country.  Gets its name from its call.
\nt 060130 changed spelling to niini to accord with NG version.  But note that tokens
sometimes do sound like "niyini" e.g. JS060123BIL.DAC_03ih 1:00.
\nt 060124 picture of double-barred finch
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\ps n
\ge sister

\rf IH: RN fieldnotes 1990: 02:104
\ee Many of these words are only used by young people. Old people use different words beginning with 'yala-' or 'yalu-'.
\se nyilanggu

\se nyilawu

\se nyilarra

\nt The stem for the inflected version of this is 'yala', though younger speakers use 'nyila', e.g. yalangga vs nyilangga (there)

\lx nyirri
\sf nyirri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge cicada
\de cicada
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re cicada
\re Hemiptera
\re Cicadidae various
\va
\sy
\sc Hemiptera, Cicadidae various
\gr nyirri
\gg nyirri, nyiingkaji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(1:25-3:00, 4:00-5:00, 19:55-20:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(10:10-10:40)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Cicada.jpg
\ee These insects sit on the trunks and branches of trees and call very loudly during the hot weather of the build up, indicating that turtles called 'guwarlambarla' will be laying their eggs called 'gambij' and that the rivers will soon be full. The 'nyirri' that have an m-shaped pattern on their back can be eaten. The hard skin cases are left on the trunks of trees when the adult insect emerges. Kids play with them sometimes. They can be used as bait when fishing with a hand-line called a 'wuyurrun'. Nyirri can be held against the lips of young boys to make sure they grow up to be good didgeridoo players. There is a Dreaming site for Nyirri near Daguragu. 
\nt 060123: elicited with picture of gumtree hopper (looks like a cicada), cicada, and
antler fly (looks a bit like cicada)
\dt 07/Feb/2008

\lx nyurijban
\sf nyurijban_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge shining.flycatcher
\de shining flycatcher
\sd J Birds
\re shining flycatcher
\re flycatcher (shining)
\re Myiagra alecto
\va
\sy
\sc Myiagra alecto
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\ee This bird is bit like a willie wagtail called 'jigirrij' but it lives
near creeks and rivers. It calls out 'nyurij...nyurij...nyurij'. The black-tailed treecreeper has the same name and is considered a countryman of
the shining flycatcher.
\sn 2
\ge treecreeper
\de black-tailed treecreeper
\sd J Birds
\re black-tailed treecreeper
\re treecreeper (black-tailed)
\re Climacteris melanura
\va
\sy
\sc Climacteris melanura
\gr
\gg nyurijpan
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC-check PMc's dict for gur spell
\ee He climbs on the trunks of trees poking its beak into the bark
looking for food.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx wajbinya

\re Varanus mertensi

\sc Varanus mertensi
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc water_monitor.jpg

\lx wajirrgi
\sf wajirrgi_CA.mp3
\sn 1
\ps n
\ge preying.mantis
\de praying mantis, any stick insect
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re praying mantis
\re Mantodea
\va
\sy
\sc Mantodea
\gr jurrunjurrun, bulmirimiri (both for dragonfly), nganjarrgarda, wijilgardi (both for praying mantis) 
\gg wajirrki (square-headed green mantis, stick insect)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_05ih:(8:00-9:00, 10:45-11:30, 12:15-12:30)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(8:30-9:45)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc preying_mantis.jpg
\nt mentioned in the context of butterflies (list item L72)
\nt CHECKpraying mantis. 060123 elicited with pictures of dragonflies, water measurer and praying mantids.
\nt LC- had been glossed as dragonfly, but ih later used 'burrmirimiri', and only called praying mantis and stick insects wajirrgi.
\ee These insects hold their front legs up like they are praying and sometimes look like sticks. They should not be touched as they can cause headaches. There is also a song about them. The term was also used in the station days to refer to a deadly flu.
\sn 2
\ps n
\ge helicopter
\de helicopter
\sd D Things
\dk
\re helicopter
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg wajirrki
\xv Wajirrgi-nggu-ma-yina gayi barra bulugi.
\xe The helicopter is chasing the cattle.
\rf RNgrammar:PigeonHole:1990
\xv Nyundu-ma-njina wardan garrinya guya, gan.guliyid na, wajirrgi-ngurlu-ma.
\xe You waved at them from above from the helicopter. 
\rf HW: RN90-005: 03:41min
\sfx jina_HW_eg1_nyundu.mp3
\nt
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx walarrbarr
\sf walarrbarr_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge Willings.tree
\de Willing's tree
\sd M Plants
\re Willing's tree
\re Grevillea dimidiata
\va
\sy
\sc Grevillea dimidiata
\gr
\gg walarrparr
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt
\ee The resinous fruit are poisonous. They burn your skin. In the past the fruit were rubbed on the body to cause scarring when people undertook ceremonies. These days young people use the fruit to burn their initials onto their arms or legs.
\sn 2
\ge caustic.tree
\de caustic tree
\sd M Plants
\re caustic tree
\re Grevillea pyramidalis
\va
\sy
\sc Grevillea pyramidalis
\ee The dark and shiny fruit are covered in a thin layer of liquid. This can be rubbed onto the skin to cause scarring which is used as an indication of ceremonial rank. These days young people use the fruit to burn their initials onto their arms or legs.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx walarri
\sf walarri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge ghost.gum
\de ghost gum
\sd M Plants
\re ghost gum
\re gum (ghost)
\re Corymbia bella
\va
\sy
\sc Corymbia bella
\gr walarri
\gg warlarri, warlarriny
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc walarri.jpg
\ee The timber makes good firewood as it burns slowly and evenly. The outer smooth white bark is burnt to a fine white ash called 'buna' to mix with chewing tobacco called 'warlayarra' or 'ngunyju'. The bark is either collected dry and burnt straight away, or chopped wet from the tree and left to dry out for a few days before burning. Sugarbag or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. These trees are generally referred to as 'gum trees'. They are the only variety of eucalypts referred to as 'gum trees' by Bilinarra people.
\sn 1
\ge white.gum
\de white gum
\sd M Plants
\re white gum
\re gum (white)
\re Corymbia grandifolia
\va
\sy
\sc Corymbia grandifolia
\ee The timber makes good firewood. You can make didgeridoos from the straight, hollow branches and stems. You can also find sugarbag called 'ngarlu' or 'namawurru' in this tree.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx walmad
\sf walmad_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge wild.coconut
\de wild coconut
\sd M Plants
\re wild coconut
\re coconut (wild)
\re Livistona victoriae
\va
\sy
\re Livistona victoriae
\gr
\gg walmat, nyurlpa (ethnobotany)
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc walmad.jpg
\ee The inner cabbage can be eaten. The cabbage is generally collected from younger palms and is obtained by cutting open the leaf bases to expose the pale cabbage. The cabbage is eaten raw and has a crisp, moist texture. The leaves can be used as coverings for food when cooking in ground ovens and as mats and plates for keeping food clean when serving it out.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx walmawalmaj
\sf walmawalmaj_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.tobacco
\de bush tobacco
\sd M Plants
\re tobacco (bush)
\re bush tobacco
\re Lobelia arnhemica
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg walmawalmak (near rocky gorges), junpunpi (near rivers and springs)
\sc Lobelia arnhemica
\pc walmawalmaj.jpg
\so Ethnobiology LC080604BIL.PH_01bbmh 19:00
\ee This small plant grows in wet areas in gorges and beside springs called 'winyji'. The dried plant can be chewed as bush tobacco. It is often mixed with commercial tobacco called 'ngunyju' or 'warlayarra' and some ash called 'buna'. In the past the old people chewed this before commercial tobacco was available.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx walugbin
\sf walugbin_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge black.cockatoo
\de red-tailed black cockatoo
\sd J Birds
\re black cockatoo (red-tailed)
\re cockatoo (red-tailed black)
\re Calyptorhynchus banksii
\va
\sy dirrag
\sc Calyptorhynchus banksii
\gr walugbiny
\gg walukpin
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_02ih:(17:45-20:00)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(21:00-21:35)
\pc red_tailed_black_cockatoo.jpg
\cf
\nt 051123: could be walugbiny?  red feathers might be used in some ceremony, but have
to check with Barbara (Ivy's only seen white cockatoo feathers used).
\nt 060124 Scottrina offers "wa(r)lagbiny" a couple of times but Ivy corrects her to
"wa(r)lugbiny".  Probably -l-, not -rl-.
\ee These  cockatoos like to eat the fruit from 'marndayag' and 'bardigi'. They have very strong beaks. They call out 'dirrag ... dirrag' and one of their names is based on this sound. The red feathers from the tails of the male birds are used in some ceremonies. Sometimes they are kept as pets.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx waluru
\sf waluru_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge black-headed.python
\de black-headed python, pie-bald snake
\sd I Reptiles
\re black-headed python
\re python (black-headed)
\re pie-bald snake
\re snake (pie-bald)
\re Aspidites melanocephalus
\va
\sy mulyuguna
\sc Aspidites melanocephalus
\gr warlujabi, waluru
\gg muylukuna, murntuj, waluru
\de
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_04ih:(10:40, 10:45, 11:05)
\nt quiet one, looks like water snake, elicited with picture of bandy-bandy on 050921.
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc black_headed_python.jpg
\nt LC- Gurindji people said this name refers to the stripes on the snake's body, but 'walu' means head.
\ee This python has a distinctive black shiny head and pretty stripes on its body. It is a quiet snake. It is sometimes called 'waluru' in reference to these stripes. Young people cannot eat the meat from this snake. If they do they will become crippled; only elders can eat the meat. This snake also has a sacred song that can only be heard by men. There is a Dreaming for this python and in the story it has the name 'naminamij'. It is not poisonous.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx wamba
\sf wamba_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge salmon.gum
\de salmon gum
\sd M Plants
\re salmon gum
\re gum (salmon)
\re Eucalyptus bigalerita
\va
\sy lunyja
\sc Eucalyptus bigalerita
\gr lunyja
\gg lunja
\so 050915ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc lunyja.jpg
\ee This is an important tree for Bilinarra people. A number exist opposite Gulygulya, the Badcold Dreaming site found along the Victoria River. This is a dangerous place which has a rock on the eastern side which is potentially deadly. Lunyja trees on the opposite bank can be used to cure people who come into contact with the rock. The timber also makes good firewood. Boomerangs called 'gurrubardu' may also be made from the hard wood. Sugarbag or 'namawurru' can be found in this tree. The bark is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as a wash to treat skin problems. 
\sn 1
\ge snappy.gum
\de snappy gum
\sd M Plants
\re snappy gum
\re gum (snappy)
\re Eucalyptus brevifolia
\va
\sy lunyja
\sc Eucalyptus brevifolia
\cf malangarna
\pc lunyja2.jpg
\ee The timber is good long lasting firewood. Boomerangs may be made from the hard wood. The bark can be used in bush medicine. It is chipped off and boiled in water and the liquid is used as a wash to treat skin problems and congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya'. A little can be drunk to treat 'gulygulya'. Sugarbag or namawurru can be found in this tree. The sugar-leaf, a sweet edible insect, collected from 'lunyja' is called 'malangarna'.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx wambana
\sf wambana_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spectacled.hare.wallaby
\de spectacled hare wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re spectacled hare wallaby
\re wallaby (spectacled hare)
\re Lagorchestes conspicillatus
\va
\sy
\sc Lagorchestes conspicillatus
\gr wanbawu (wallaby?)
\gg wampana
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- gurindji Dreaming story for this and purtujurru around Lajamanu country.
\nt
\pc wambana.jpg
\ee This short, solid wallaby has distinctive orange fur around its eyes. It sleeps in a tunnel in grass or under dense shade in the day and feeds at night. In the past they were eaten and the meat was tasty. They have not been seen as much in recent times but sometimes are seen near the lancewood or 'ganawuna' and bullwaddi or 'gamanyji' areas near Delamere, Top Springs (Yingawunarri) and Cattle Creek (Kunawa).
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx wangga
\sf wangga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge ceremony
\de dance and song style with didgeridoo from Ngarinyman and Ngaliwurru country (and originally Port Keats)
\sd C Language and Culture
\re ceremony
\va
\sy
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 051026mh
\cf
\nt Ceremony for boys' initiation from Ngarinyman and Ngaliwurru country.  Involves
both boys and girls dancing at the same time, girls mostly seated.  Mildred says
"Port Keats mob" are coming to do this for some of the boys at Pigeon Hole (early
November 2005), and it's easier than bandimi (the one they do here) since it doesn't
involve girls having to dance all night (prevents sore legs!). FM - not just boys initiation.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx waniyi
\sf 
\ps n
\ge grasshopper
\de yellow and black small grasshopper
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re grasshopper (yellow and black)
\re Orthoptera
\va
\sy
\sc Orthoptera
\re Caelifera
\sc Caelifera
\gr
\gg warniyi (little "warniriri" = small edible grasshopper)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_05ih:(14:35-15:55, 16:45-17:10, 18:00-18:40)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(1:45-2:45)
\ee This small grasshopper cannot fly and occurs in large numbers. They can be eaten after lightly roasting in a small grass fire.
\nt 060123: Elicited with picture of Australian plague locust.  Dreaming site Wave Hill
way, Dreaming for Billy Campbell mob.  People used to use this as bait for fishing, but
not eaten, still people might use this to catch catfish or barra.
\nt 060124: elicited with picture of a grasshopper, Ivy says the big grasshopper (probably
locust) is bilbiji (birlbirlji?). Also uses this for green grasshopper.  Orthographic note: 
spelling could be wanii, but some tokens Ivy clearly has -iyi.  Check retroflex
wa(r)niyi.
\nt LC-lots at Yarralin 25/01/08, hopping through the community. Sounded more like waani.
\dt 06/Jan/2022

\re
\va
\sy
\gr

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- check if true for Bilinarra; 
men wore them on hair belt to gain an advantage in a fight.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx wanyarri
\sf wanyarri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bauhina
\de bauhinia
\sd M Plants
\re bauhinia
\re Lysiphyllum cunninghamii
\va
\sy jingi
\sc Lysiphyllum cunninghamii
\gr wanyarri
\gg wanyarri, jingi
\xv Wanyarri-ngga baraj-ba-lu bunya nyila-ma girrawa-ma.
\xe They found that goanna under the bauhinia.
\rf I. Hector. 2005. Girrawa! Produced by J. Spence for DAC
\so I. Hector. 2002. Nyampa Nyawa Garndi. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc wanyarri.jpg
\cf ngabirlibirli
\ee The inner red bark makes good medicine. You can boil it and use the water as a wash and drink to treat headaches, colds called 'gulygulya' and skin sores called 'marndara'. You can also chew the leaves to treat colds. You can also find sugarbag called 'namawurru' in this tree. The red flowers can be sucked to get the sweet nectar. The seed pods are called 'ngabirlibirli'. You can burn the outer bark to make tobacco ashes called 'buna', and chew the leaves if you are thirsty. Chewing the leaves helps produce saliva or 'jawul' and stops the feeling of intense thirst.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx wanymirra
\sf wanymirra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge pencil.yam
\de pencil yam
\sd M Plants
\re yam (pencil)
\re pencil yam
\re Vigna lanceolata
\sy
\sc Vigna lanceolata
\gr warnmala
\gg wanymirra
\xv
\xe
\so 050427bb
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf wayida
\ee The tubers are similar to sweet potatoes. They can grow about as big as your hand. You dig them up and lightly roast them. The yam is fairly stringy and you need to chew it a lot. Some of the yams are spicy to taste and can make your stomach feel like it is burning. This yam is closely related to 'wayida', but it is larger and grows on different country. It has a different shaped yam that also tastes quite different.
\dt 30/Jul/2008

\lx -warla
\sf warla_CA.mp3
\ps suf
\ge FOC
\de focus marker. It is used to draw attention to something in the sentence or contrast it with something else. It is also used to mean to link two events which happen one after the other. It translates as 'then' in these cases.
\sd Y Word Endings
\re now
\re then
\sy -barla
\sy na
\gr
\gg -warla
\xv Ngayiny-ma marru-ma gambarrijang-ma. Nyawa-ma-rnalu yani gan.ga- ganimbarra. Gurlarra-rnalu yani. Janggarni-warla ngayi-ma wamala-warla.
\xe That was my home a long time ago. That was when we would go downstream. We went south. I was a big girl by then. 
\rf KJ: 1975: MCCONVELL_P08-014877: 6:20min
\sfx warla_KJ_eg1_ngayiny.mp3

\lx warlagarri
\sf warlagarri_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge supplejack
\de supplejack
\sd M Plants
\re supplejack
\re Ventilago viminalis
\va
\sy
\sc Ventilago viminalis
\gr
\gg warlakarri (Supplejack, used for making boomerangs)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050616ih
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc warlagarri.jpg
\nt growing at Gulija hill, used to make boomerang, good ngarlu (sugarbag).  NG dict
mentions form in entry for walwaya, but entry missing.
\nt LC- bb talked about carrying fire 080605
\ee This tree has very hard wood. The timber of large trees can be used to make boomerangs called 'gurrubardu'. The straight stems of young trees can be used to make digging-sticks called 'giyarri', fighting-sticks called 'guduru' and shields called 'mirda'. The wood can also be used to carve message-sticks. Dry stems and branches can be used to carry fire from one place to another. They can be lit at one end and will slowly smoulder along their length. Occasionally they will need to be blown on to keep them alight.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx warlagu
\sf warlagu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge dog
\de dog
\sd H Mammals
\dk dog
\re dog
\re Canis familiaris
\va
\sy guru
\sy wangani
\sc Canis familiaris
\gr warlagu
\gg warlaku
\xv Warlagu-lu garan-ba-nyunu mana.
\xe The dog is scratching itself.
\rf IH: FM: BIL03aud: 2003: 01:46min
\sfx warlagu_IH_eg1_warlagu.mp3
\xv Warlagu-lu bayarni-yi.
\xe The dog bit me.
\rf RNgrammar:PigeonHole:1990
\xv Nyila-ma warlagu-lu gayi barra gurrurij.
\xe That dog is chasing a car.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (4-113)
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(24:25, 24:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(22:50)
\pc dog.jpg
\ee Dogs are kept as pets and hunting companions. They are good at sniffing out where game animals are hiding. They are good pets and are a lot quieter than dingoes. They often receive the skin name of the owner's child. 
\nt
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\sc Aquila audax
\gr walarurru
\gg warlawurru
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_04ih:(20:40-21:35)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(7:55-8:40)
\pc eagle.jpg
\nt Used to eat in early days, caught by making
fire behind a hide (duba) same as for garrgany.
\nt Dreamtime gurindji story for warlawurru and jarlwa Bilinarra
too? Takes place at Long Reach
\nt One of the two moieties
\ee This is the biggest hunting bird. They can catch small kangaroos and wallabies and they also hunt for bush turkeys called 'jamud'. They are often seen high in the sky slowly circling looking for food, or on the road eating road kill. 'Warlawurruwuny' or 'lirragu' is also one of the two moieties that the skin groups are divided between.
\dt 28/Apr/2008

\lx warlayara
\sf warlaya_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge white.grass
\de white grass
\sd M Plants
\re white grass
\re grass (white)
\re Sehima nervosum
\sc Sehima nervosum
\ee This grass is used as medicine to treat babies. The grass is mixed with crushed ant bed and water on a surface that has been heated by a fire. This causes steam to rise and the baby is moved through this steam and allowed to lay upon the grass so that it is heated by the steam. This 'cooking' of the baby improves its health and allows to grow up strong mentally and physically. In the past, people put 'warlayara' in coolamons filled with water to stop the water splashing out.
\so Hector, Anzac RN90-005
\dt 13/Nov/2008

\lx warlujulurru
\sf warlujulurru_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge short.nose.catfish
\de short nose catfish or salmon catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (short nose)
\re short nose catfish
\re Neoarius graeffei
\va
\sy warlujurru
\sc Neoarius graeffei
\gr
\gg walujulurru (short-nose catfish)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so 050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(3:30-3:40, 4:45-6:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(30:30-31:05)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Salmon_Catfish.jpg
\cf nalij
\nt Caught at Mistake Crossing on 050518, included in pictures from that trip.  Sheila
glosses as 'big catfish', Ivy as 'small catfish'.  
\nt CHECK - Recording 050922 Mildred has 'walujurru', Ivy 'walujulurru'
\ee This is a catfish that has a shorter nose than other species. The flesh and fat can be eaten after roasting in hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'. It does not get as big as 'jalarlga'. When they are pulled on to land they often make a grunting noise. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison and can cause severe pain and swelling. You should break off the spines and burn them on the fire, throw them back in the water or put them in a safe place. If you step on the spine, you should slap the area with the tail of the fish. This stops the pain and swelling. You can also treat the area of the sting with urine from the catfish or place hot sand on it. The green slime from freshwater areas (nalij) can also be placed on the area to relieve pain.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx warlujurru
\sf warlujurru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge short.nose.catfish
\de short nose catfish or salmon catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (short nose)
\re short nose catfish
\re Neoarius graeffei
\va
\sy warlujulurru
\sc Neoarius graeffei
\gr
\gg walujulurru (short-nose catfish)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\ee This is a catfish that has a shorter nose than other species. The flesh and fat can be eaten after roasting in hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'. It does not get as big as 'jalarlga'. When they are pulled on to land they often make a grunting noise. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison and can cause severe pain and swelling. You should break off the spines and burn them on the fire, throw them back in the water or put them in a safe place. If you step on the spine, you should slap the area with the tail of the fish. This stops the pain and swelling. You can also treat the area of the sting with urine from the catfish or place hot sand on it. The green slime from freshwater areas (nalij) can also be placed on the area to relieve pain.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx warraaj
\sf warraaj_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spinifex.wax
\de spinifex wax
\sd M Plants
\re spinifex (wax)
\va
\sy
\sc
\gr warraaj (spinifex wax from malurna plant))
\gg warraaj (spinifex wax)
\so 050317ih
\so 051027mh
\cf mardumardu
\ce antbed
\nt LC- check if really the plant or just the wax.
\ee You can use this wax to attach a spear or axe head to the shaft. You hold the wax over the flames until it goes black and soft.
Then you beat it out, and repeat the process. You place the wax in the shaft and stick the head in. The whole joint is then tied up with 'gumbun' (animal tendon). When the wax hardens and the tendon dries, the result is a very hard joint.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx warrag
\sf warrag_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge catfish
\de any kind of catfish
\sd K Water Animals
\re catfish (any)
\va
\sy jalarlga
\sc
\gr warrag
\gg warrak, jarlarlka
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(29:10-29:15)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jalarlga.jpg
\ee Catfish are eaten but they must be caught carefully. The spines or prickles on the fins are dangerous. They contain poison and can cause severe pain and swelling. You should break off the spines and burn them on the fire, throw them back in the water or put them in a safe place. If you step on the spine, you should slap the area with the tail of the fish. This stops the pain and swelling. Baby catfish are called 'ngirnngirda'.
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx warrija
\sf warrija_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge crocodile
\de freshwater crocodile
\sd I Reptiles
\re crocodile (freshwater)
\re freshwater crocodile
\va
\sy gangarndayawung
\sy darrmard
\xv Nyamu-n-nga yan.gu bin.ga-gurra, bin.ga-gurra-ma, garu-walija, warrija-lu-ma-nyjurra-nga bayawu. 
\xe If you go to the river, a crocodile might bite you kids.
\rf IH: RN90-014a: 23:04min
\sfx nyjurra_IH_eg2_nyamu.mp3
\re Crocodylus johnstoni
\sc Crocodylus johnstoni
\gr warrija
\gg warrija, kangarntayawung, lirrayawung, nakakany, purruyurl (large ones)
\xv Warrija-lu bayarni-wuliny warlagu jiya.
\xe The crocodile killed a dog and a kangaroo.
\rf RN Sketch Grammar: 1990: (5:47)
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_02ih:(00:10-00:40, 7:35)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(14:55-16:05)
\pc freshwater_croc.jpg
\cf laging
\nt
\ee In the past the men used to hunt them with spears with stone points, and they were eaten more commonly than they are now. The tail meat is the tastiest part and is eaten in preference to the rest of the meat. To cook it, the stomach is opened by cutting from under the front leg, down the side and under the stomach and the intestines are removed from the gut cavity. This is then filled with heated rocks and the body and tail are then roasted in hot coals and ashes in a cooking process called 'wubgarra' or cooked in a ground oven called 'durdurl'. The meat is skinned before eating. The small hatchlings are called 'laging'. The mother crocodile sometimes takes these babies from the nest in the sand to the water by carrying them in her mouth. The eggs are also eaten after boiling in water or cooking in hot sand. The tracks of the mother are followed to the nest and the sand dug out and the eggs collected. The eggs are ready to be collected during the hot weather time when the jangarla tree produces its large white flowers. Another indication that the eggs are ready to be collected are when the march flies or 'burrju' start biting. Another way to tell the eggs are ready is when there is a cloudy look about the Southern Cross stars. The name 'gangarndayawung' refers to their big teeth.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx warrwa
\sf warrwa_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge soft.spinifex
\de soft variety of spinifex
\sd M Plants
\re spinifex (soft)
\re Triodia bitextura 
\va
\sc Triodia bitextura 
\va
\gr
\gg warrwa
\xv Nyila-ma-wula mana warrwa na darug-gu-rningan garu-walija-wu.
\xe Those two are getting grass for bathing the kids again.
\rf IH: FM: BIL05aud: 2003: 13:05min
\sfx warrwa_IH_eg1_nyila.mp3
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\cf jigala
\cf warraaj
\cf mirrgiliny
\ee Soft spinifex is used to treat diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. You collect it along with termite mound called 'mardumardu'. The termite mound is heated up and mixed with water and then the raw 'warrwa' is added. Children are then slathered with the mixture and given it to drink. The wax that is found at the base of the plant is called 'warraaj' or 'jigala'. You collect it, melt and pound it a number of times to create a strong glue used with kangaroo tendons called 'gambun' to bind spear or axe heads to their shafts.
\nt
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx warrwi
\sf warrwi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge sandpaper.fig
\de sandpaper fig
\sd M Plants
\re sandpaper fig
\re fig (sandpaper)
\re Ficus aculeata

\sc Ficus scobina
\gr warrayij, warrwi
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc warrwi.jpg
\nt
\ee The small fruit are eaten by birds and by some people, but not everyone likes to eat the fruit. The leaves are rough like sandpaper. You can boil them and use the water to wash itchy skin.

\lx wawurrungarna
\sf wawurrungarna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge curlew
\de bush stone curlew
\sd J Birds
\re curlew (stone)
\re stone curlew
\re Burhinus grallarius
\sy windigu
\sc Burhinus grallarius
\gr
\gg wintuk
\so JS051123BIL.KAT_07ih:(3:50-5:40, 14:35-15:35)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(32:20-33:05)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_06ih:(00:15-00:55)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Bush_Stone_Curlew.jpg
\ee These birds call out loudly in the night. They also call for rain to come in the dry cold weather. When you hear them calling with an echo it means that someone close to you has passed away. Pregnant women called 'ngadurr' must keep away from these birds. The birds walk along whistling, then fall over convulsing. If expectant mothers hear their whistling their babies will have fits after they're born. During the day the curlew stands still in thick bushy areas and hides. Its name 'wawurrungarna' refers to this; at night they move around hunting for food.
\nt 051123: elicited with pictures of bush thick-knee and little curlew, not eaten, sings out
at night
\nt 060124 picture of stone curlew: in JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih Ivy doesn't recognise this
bird and this word isn't given in recording, but it's at the beginning of
JS060124BIL.DAC_06ih.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx wawuya
\sf wawuya_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge body.lice
\de body lice
\sd A Body
\re body lice
\re lice (body)
\re Pediculus humanus
\sc Pediculus humanus
\ee These lice live on the skin. They cause severe itching. There is a Dreaming site for them near Nitjpurru (Pigeon Hole) called Wawuyalarni or Grey Billabong.
\nt

\lx wayida
\sf wayida_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge pencil.yam
\de pencil yam
\sd M Plants
\re pencil yam
\re yam (pencil)
\re Vigna lanceolata
\sy wanymirra
\sc Vigna lanceolata
\gr
\gg wayit
\xv Yana-rnawula wayida-wu gurrijgarra.
\xe The two of us are going to dig for yams.
\rf Ivy and Sheila Hector. 2006. Wanyjiga-warla-n yana? Produced by L. Campbell for DAC
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_04ih:(00:45)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_02ih:(8:45-9:55)
\pc wayida.jpg
\ee The tubers are similar to sweet potatoes. They can be about as big as your hand. You dig them up and lightly roast them. The yam is fairly stringy and you need to chew it a lot. Some of the yams are spicy to taste and can make your stomach feel like it is burning. This yam is closely related to 'wanymirra', but is smaller and grows on different country. It has a different shaped yam that also tastes quite different.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx wayiwarrang
\sf wayiwarrang_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge long-neck.turtle
\de long-neck turtle
\sd I Reptiles
\re long-neck turtle
\re turtle (long-neck)
\re Chelodina rugosa
\va
\sy
\sc Chelodina rugosa
\gr
\gg wayiwarrang
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc long_neck_turtle.jpg
\nt LC- Check if borrowed word
\ee These turtles have a long neck like a snake. They can be caught on hand-lines called 'wuyurrun', but are also found in the drying mud around billabongs called 'langgarna' when the water retreats in the dry season. They can be dug out of the mud with a crowbar. They are found more commonly in northern areas around Timber Creek, Bradshaw and Auvergne and less so in the southern areas.
\dt 04/Jun/2008

\lx wijalngarniny
\sf wijalngarniny_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge mussel
\de mussel
\sd K Water Animals
\re mussel (billabong)
\re Velesunio wilsonii
\va
\sy dugu
\sy naribu
\sc Velesunio wilsonii
\gr wijarlnganany, daga, narubu
\gg murrunkirn, narupu, turta, wijalngarniny
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so EC:IH:Animal Pictures:2001
\so Ethnobiology LC080604BIL.PHmhbbca
\cf jiwirrirri
\pc mussel.jpg
\ee This short, solid mussel is found in the mud at the edges of billabongs called 'langgarna'. They are roasted on hot coals and eaten. Mussels cannot be eaten by boys; men can only eat them after they have been initiated. The meat can also be boiled in water with a little salt and made into soup called 'yingalg' and this can be drunk to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' and diarrhoea called 'ngajgula'. The juice from mussels can also be used to treat ear aches and infections. It is dripped straight into the ear.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx windigu
\sf windigu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge curlew
\de bush stone curlew
\sd J Birds
\re curlew (stone)
\re stone curlew
\re Burhinus grallarius
\sy wawurrungarna
\sc Burhinus grallarius
\gr
\gg wintuk
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc Bush_Stone_Curlew.jpg
\ee These birds call out loudly in the night. They also call for rain to come in the dry cold weather. When you hear them calling with an echo it means that someone close to you has passed away. Pregnant women must keep away from these birds. The birds walk along whistling, then fall over convulsing. If expectant mothers hear their whistling their babies will have fits after they're born. During the day the curlew stands still in thick bushy areas and hides. Its other name 'wawurrungarna' refers to this; at night they move around hunting for food.
\nt
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx Windigunya
\sf Windigunya_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de group of bullwaddi trees. This is a Nangangari Dreaming place. It is the final place in the Bilinarra section of the Nangangari Dreaming track.  They left some jirri (love potion) here and then they went underground to Mudburra country.
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv Yalangurlu-ma-lu yani darab-ba-lu waninya yani-lu garrawarra na Mudburra kantri wel olabat kamat deya na.
\xe From there, [the Nangangari] went underground and then they went east to Mudburra country and emerged there.
\rf IH: FM: BIL04.track01.01aud: 2003: 08:15min
\sfx darab_IH_eg1_yala.mp3

\lx winggijwinggij
\sf winggijwinggij_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge cathormion
\de cathormion
\sd M Plants
\re cathormion
\re Cathormion umbellatum
\va
\sy
\sc Cathormion umbellatum
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc winggijwinggij.jpg
\ee This plant is a good shade tree as its thick canopy provides dense, cool shade.
\sn 2
\ge plant.sp
\de kind of plant
\sd M Plants
\re Phyllanthus reticulatus
\sc Phyllanthus reticulatus
\gr
\gg wingkijwingkij
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- check, same as sense 1?
\ee This plant grows in thickets near rivers and billabongs. These are good places to go fishing where it grows near the water. Turtles called 'guwarlambarla' and fish called 'yawu' like to eat the fruit when it falls in the water. The stems can be used as fire-sticks or bush matches to light fires using the traditional drilling method called 'binyinyib'.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx Winingili
\sf Winingili_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de tabletop shaped rock with grooves on the underside where the lizard camped. It also has old rock drawings. This is a Lardaj Dreaming place. 
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv Yalangurlu jawurrug waninya ganyjurra garan mani ngawa Winingili.

\lx wirarra
\sf wirarra_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge skink
\de skink or slippery lizard
\sd I Reptiles
\re skink
\re slippery lizard
\re lizard (slippery)
\re Ctenotus spp
\va
\sy ngabagardarn.gardarn
\sc Ctenotus spp
\gr
\gg wirarra, ngapakartarnkartarn
\xv
\xe
\pc Skink.jpg
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee This small lizard that can be described as 'girinygiriny' when it has slippery skin and then 'wirarra' when it grows legs. It eats insects and butterflies called 'marlimarli' and is active at dusk and dawn. It has no specific use and are generally left alone.

\gg wirnturruyawung, marranparla
\pc Buffalo.jpg
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee There are occasional wild buffalo still seen, but most were killed during the BTEC eradication scheme in the 1980s and 1990s. The meat is good to eat, especially from young ones. It has a strong taste. Buffalo are cranky and dangerous in the bush.

\xv Wudiyingib manda-yi yinggawurl wudu.
\xe Look for nits in my hair
\rf FM:PigeonHole:BB,MH:FM07_a064:25Jan08
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx wudu
\sf wudu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge lice
\de head lice, tick
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re tick
\re lice (head)
\sy dunji
\va uudu
\re Phthiraptera, Pediculus capitis
\sc Phthiraptera, Pediculus capitis
\gr wudu (louse)
\gg wutu (head louse, ticks)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_05ih:(18:45-20:35)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_06ih:(15:05-16:30)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_07ih:(17:00-19:00)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee These small insects live on humans. They cause severe itching in the hair and elsewhere on the body where they live. They are generally called 'uudu' and the eggs are called 'yinggiwarl'. Some of the bush medicine plants with a good smell can be used to treat lice and nits, these include 'lawa', 'dimarlan', 'manyanyi', 'gubuwubu' and 'yirrijgaji.
\cf yinggiwarl
\dt 29/Jul/2008

\lx wugardij
\sf wugardij_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge rock.wallaby
\de rock wallaby
\sd H Mammals
\re rock wallaby
\re wallaby (rock)
\re Petrogale brachyotis
\va
\sy
\sc Petrogale brachyotis
\gr
\gg wukartij
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc short_eared_rock_wallaby.jpg
\ee This small kangaroo lives in rocky areas. They often shelter in caves in the hot weather time. They are very timid and are not often seen. They hop around very quickly and are difficult to spear. In the past they were hunted by finding the paths they travel on and setting a hunter with a stick to wait. Other hunters would scare the rock wallaby so that it hopped down the track towards the other hunter who would hit it hard with the stick. They were then roasted and eaten, though there is not much meat as they are quite small.
\nt LC- this is different from rock kangaroo 'minawud'.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx wumarangarna
\sf wumarangarna_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge rock.kangaroo
\de rock kangaroo
\sd H Mammals
\re rock kangaroo
\re hill kangaroo
\re kangaroo (hill)
\re kangaroo (rock)
\re Macropus robustus
\va
\sy bamarrngarna
\sy minawud
\sy bunggiyid
\gr
\gg
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(4:30)
\sc Macropus robustus
\pc euro.jpg
\ee These kangaroos are often seen in hilly areas and are good to eat after roasting. They often have longish hair and can range in colour from dark grey to light grey to a bit reddish. This kangaroo is sometimes also called 'wumarangarna', which means rock-dweller and refers to its preferred habitat in rocky areas. The tendons, called 'gambun', from the tails are used to attach spear heads called 'yirlga' or axe heads called 'gurrwa' to shafts, and hooks called 'narra' to spear-throwers called 'warlmaya'. 
\pc short_eared_rock_wallaby.jpg
\nt could be other rock animal/things too?
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx wurrubuja
\sf wurrubuja_CA.mp3
\ps n
\sn 1
\ge kangaroo.grass
\de kangaroo grass
\sd M Plants
\re kangaroo grass
\re grass (kangaroo)
\re Chrysopogon fallax
\va
\sy
\sc Chrysopogon fallax
\gr
\gg
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee The stem base is eaten by kangaroos and wallabies. The sharp leaf edges can cut your feet when you walk through it, or your hands if you try to pull it out. The stem base and new shoots can also be used as medicine. The yellow root is dug up and cleaned off, then smashed up and boiled in water. The cooled liquid is drunk to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya.
\sn 2
\ge medicine.sedge
\de medicine sedge
\sd M Plants
\re sedge
\re Cyperus sp
\va
\sy
\sc Cyperus sp
\gr
\gg wurrupuja
\xv
\xe
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc wurrubuja.jpg
\ee The small underground tubers are used as medicine. They are chewed in the mouth and are similar to chewing gum as they last for a long time. They are not swallowed but just chewed. This is used to treat congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya' and general sickness called 'janga'. The small tubers are eaten by brolgas called 'gurrarndal' and kangaroos called 'jiya'.
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\gr lalga, larrga

\xv Wurruja yuga gambala-lu garu-walija-lu burdujburduj bardigi-mayin.

\sd I Reptiles
\re black whip snake
\re snake (black whip)
\re Demansia papuensis
\va
\sy
\sc Demansia papuensis
\gg
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so EC:IH:Animal Pictures:2001
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003

\nt LC-not mentioned in Ethnobiology draft 2007, try to confirm identity
\nt Ivy gave daburrng for whip snake (2007), but gurindji all identified tapurrng at spinifex snake, moon snake.
\ee Poisonous, though not deadly. There is a song that helps the pain and swelling.

\lx Yalga
\sf Yalga_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de extended area of hillside in the Victoria/Camfield River junction area where there are nodules of white stone on the hillside. It is near Bijaguny. This word means 'stone spearhead' in Gurindji
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so NLC: Bilinara (Coolibah-Wavehill Stock Route land Claim). May 1989. (Anzac Munganyi, Old Jimmy Mangayarri)
\so AAPA: Aboriginal Scared Sites within large vicinity of Pigeon Hole Outstation, 2003.
\gp 733000E, 8122000N
\nt CHECK pronunciation and place. Jaliwa and eaglehawk. Eaglehawk threw spears at Jalwa. 
Stone nodules are remains of Eaglehawk spears. 
Confirmed by Horace Warlman and Kathleen Juduwurr (FM08)
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\sf yalu-_CA.mp3

\de that one does it
\sd V Space and Time

\xe That man hit me with a stick.

\lx yangununggu
\sf yangununggu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge bush.potato
\de bush potato
\sd M Plants
\re bush potato
\re Ipomoea costata
\va
\sy bigurda
\sc Ipomoea costata
\xv
\xe
\rf
\pc bigurda.jpg
\ee This plant grows in red-plains country called 'wala' or 'jirlja' closer to Lajamanu, Limbunya, Mount Sanford and Kunawa (Cattle Creek). It has pretty pink flowers. The yams are dug up and eaten. They have an excellent taste and can often be collected in large amounts. The yams can be eaten lightly roasted or boiled. The root system of the plant is quite expansive and the potatoes are usually found quite far from the plant. The roots and bulbs crack the ground above them, these cracks can be followed to find large yams below. The ground around the plant can be tapped with a digging stick called a 'giyarri', if a hollow noise is heard, it indicates a large yam is below and it is a good place to dig.
\nt Rachel has yangumungku; FM changed
\dt 02/Jun/2008

\lx yanjurru
\sf yanjurru_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge smoke.tree
\de smoke tree, silver box
\sd M Plants
\re smoke tree
\re silver box
\re Eucalyptus pruinosa
\va
\sy jarnbij
\sc Eucalyptus pruinosa
\gr
\gg yanjurru, jarnbij (GUR dict coolibah)
\xv Warlagab yani-lu baraj bunya-lu garndi-ma yanjurru.
\xe They walked around and found a tree [called a] yanjurru.
\rf SH/MH: FM08_a093: 00:15min
\sfx yanjurru_SH_eg1_warlagab.mp3
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc jarnbij.jpg
\ee Stems and branches that have been hollowed by termites and are of the appropriate size can be made into didgeridoos. Sugarbag called 'namawurru' or 'ngarlu' can be found in this tree. Timber from young plants can be use to make fighting sticks called guduru or spear-throwers called 'warlmayi'. The bark is burnt to a fine white ash called 'buna' to mix with chewing tobacco called 'warlayarra' or 'ngunyju'.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx Yawarlwarl
\sf Yawarlwarl_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge placename
\de waterhole and stone in Victoria River and surrounding area. This is where Yawarlwarl the crested pigeon left the grindstone stolen from her sister Wanyil.
\sd O Place Names
\re
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so NLC: Bilinara (Coolibah-Wavehill Stock Route land Claim). May 1989. (Hector Wannyarri, Ivy Hector)
\gp
\nt CHECK pronunciation and place. Pigeon Dreaming? Pigeon carried grindstone here. NB name of pigeon
\dt 09/Apr/2008

\lx yawarlwarl
\sf yawarlwarl_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge crested.pigeon
\de crested pigeon
\sd J Birds
\re pigeon (crested)
\re crested pigeon
\re Ocyphaps lophotes
\va
\sy
\sc Ocyphaps lophotes
\gr yawarlwarl
\gg yawarlwarl
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so JS051123BIL.DAC_02ih:(6:10-8:40)
\so JS060123BIL.DAC_05ih:(13:30)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_05ih:(13:15-14:10)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt Check for Dreaming story with grinding stone (just gurindji?)
\ee These birds have a meaningful call. When they 'coo...coo...coo' it indicates someone from your family is coming to see you. They are also eaten. Yawarlwarl is also a character in a Dreamtime story. She lived with her sister Wanyil (Wallaby) at Kurlungurru (Riveren) which is in Nyininy country. The two sisters owned a grindstone called a 'yurrabi'. Wanyil was very careful with the grindstone and wouldn't let Yawarlwarl use it. But Wanyil would only half-grind the seed which annoyed Yawarlwarl. At one point Wanyil went to get some water and Yawarlwarl took the opportunity to steal the stone. She carried it off, camping overnight at Birlinggalurlungga. She then went on to Yawarlwarl where she placed the stone upright. You can still see the stone there now.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx yawayi
\sf yawayi_CA.mp3
\ps interj
\ge yes
\de yes
\sd X Exclamations
\re yes
\va yuu
\sy yuwayi
\gr yawayi, yuu, yuwayi
\gg yawayi, yuu, yuwayi
\xv
\xe
\rf
\nt
\dt 10/Jun/2008

\nt

\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc emu.jpg
\cf wininiwinini
\cf wanya
\nt Ivy and Barbara 051123:  Many of these found out bush, near Birliwabgarri, Police Hole (western edge of Bilinarra country).  People used to eat the eggs.  Used to catch them with spear or if you miss with your spear hit their legs with a boomerang to make it fall down.  To cook it, take out the guts and feathers, cook durdurl (ground oven) with hot stones inside the body as well as on top.
\nt 060124 confirmation of cooking method (use hot stones in a ground oven, put the
guts back in to cook them too), description of durdurl
\nt 060210 changed head to yibarrardu (from yibarradu) based on tokens in recording
from 060124, matches bith GU and NG.
\ee Emus are not seen much near Pigeon Hole community, but they are plentiful in some bush areas on Bilinarra country. Emus eat many of the bush tucker fruit that people also eat. They also eat many insects. In the early days people hunted them with spears called 'mirda' and boomerangs called 'gurrubardu'. If a spear missed, a boomerang would be thrown at the legs to make it fall down. Hunters may also wait for them at billabongs where they kneel to drink. They are easy targets then. When killed, emus are gutted and the innards called 'garnngirri'  or 'lubu' are throw away, but the 'durlang' (heart), 'marlumba' (liver) and 'wararr' (fat) can be put back in for cooking. The bird is then cooked in a ground oven using a method called 'durdurl', with hot stones called 'guruwarrany' placed inside the gut cavity, then covered with paperbark to keep the meat clean. The meat is dark and smells strong. You can also eat the eggs. Baby emus are called 'wininiwinini' and the feathers of an emu are called 'wanya'.
\dt 05/Jun/2008

\lx yilgiyang
\sf yilgiyang_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge leech
\de swamp leech
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re leech
\re Annelida
\va
\sy
\sc Annelida
\re Hirudinea
\sc Hirudinea
\gr yilgiying, yulgiying
\gg yilkiyang
\xv
\xe
\pc Leech.jpg
\ee These small worm-like animals live in water and wet areas. They attach to the skin and suck blood which is called 'gungulu'. When they are removed, the bleeding will not stop for a long period. There is a Dreaming site near Pigeon Hole of the same name and another called Bija.
\so RNwordlist:PigeonHole:1990
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt

\lx yinarrwa
\sf yinarrwa_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge barramundi
\de barramundi
\sd K Water Animals
\re barramundi
\re Lates calcarifer
\va
\sy
\sc Lates calcarifer
\gr yinarrwa
\gg yinarrwa, manyirrkirla, marna (small)
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_03ih:(16:20 - 16:40, 18:05)
\so JS050922BIL.DAC_04ih:(18:55)
\so JS060124BIL.DAC_04ih:(31:40-32:00)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc barramundi.jpg
\ee Barramundi can get large and are hard to catch as they fight hard to get off the line. They are common in billabongs and the big rivers. They are mostly caught using live bait on hand-lines called wuyurrun. The flesh can be eaten after roasting on hot coals, a cooking technique called 'wubgarra'.
\nt
\dt 28/Apr/2008

\lx yinggi
\sf yinggi_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge northern.kurrajong
\de northern kurrajong
\sd M Plants
\re northern kurrajong
\re kurrajong (northern)
\re Brachychiton diversifolius
\va
\sc Brachychiton diversifolius
\gr birdba
\gg yingki, yijingki
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc yinggi.jpg
\ee The seeds inside the fruit are edible. You need to roast the seeds to remove the small hairs from inside the fruit before eating them. You can also roast the swollen tap roots of young plants. The bark of young plants makes strong string. You can also attach spear heads to shafts with it, and hooks to spear-throwers. You can also tie up bundles of food, firewood or any items with the bark. You can also make medicine from the gum which you apply directly to sores and cuts. The inner bark makes good bandages. It has an open weave like a bandage.
\nt Yinggi is a large tree, the other kurrajongs (below) are much smaller plants.
\nt LC- same as 'yingi' listed in dict without source? Check in the yard!
\dt 28/Jul/2008

\lx yirirl
\sf yirirl_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge wattle
\de kind of wattle
\sd M Plants
\re wattle
\re Acacia ampliceps
\va
\sy
\sc Acacia ampliceps
\gr
\gg yirirl
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050607ih
\pc 
\ee This tree is a good indicator of underground water. It generally grows in creek beds and if a hole is dug near the base of the tree, water can be found.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx yirlirli
\sf yirlirli_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge white.apple
\de white apple
\sd M Plants
\re white apple
\re Syzygium eucalyptoides
\va
\sy
\sc Syzygium eucalyptoides
\gr
\gg yirirl
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so 050607ih
\pc yirlirli.jpg
\ee This small tree grows in creek beds and on river banks. The fruit may be eaten when ripe, pale pink to white. They are especially favoured by children. When the fruit fall in rivers and creeks, they are eaten by turtles called 'guwarlambarla', black bream called 'jamanmaya' and catfish called 'jalarlga'. The timber is good for cooking fish and turtles. The flowers are visited by native bees called 'lanu' or 'nama' who use the pollen and nectar for making honey.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx yirr
\sf yirr_CA.mp3
\ps cv
\ge pull
\de pull, drag
\sd U Holding and Taking
\re drag
\re pull
\va
\sy dardardab
\gr yirr (move out, pull out)
\gg yirr (pull in, pull out)
\so 050707bb,mh
\ee This is a Bilinarra word. The Gurindji word is 'dardardab'.
\nt BB and MH say 'dardardab' is really a Gurindji word
\se yirr mana
\de pull something
\xv Bayawu-nga wuyurrun-ma yawu-lu-ma yirr-ba-nga man.gu.
\xe The fish might bite the line and he might pull it in.
\rf I. Hector. 2007. Colouring in and Language book. Produced by I. Hector. 2007. Colouring in and Language book. Produced by J. Spence for DAC
\xv Nyila-ma yirr mana wirrgala-ma yuwani nyanyjarlng wirrgala-gari-nggurra janggarni-nggirri.
\xe She pulls out the hair string after joining it to another piece of string.
\rf SH: FM08_a091: 12:01min
\sfx yirr_SH_eg2_nyila.mp3
\xv Yirr-ba-nggu mani gardbi.
\xe He pulled your hair. 
\rf IH: RN90-014b: 02:09min
\sfx yirr_IH_eg3_yirr.mp3
\se yirr ganga
\de drag
\xv Yirr-ba-yi ganya, guya-ma-rna marni, "Yirr-warla na mani, heavy bugger. Warda, guwarlambarla janggarni!"
\xe It pulled on my fishing line, and I said, "It's really pulling now, it's a heavy bugger. Wow, big turtle!"
\rf CJ:Yarralin:KJ:Guwarlambarla:29July98
\se yirrgarra
\de pulling, dragging
\xv Wirrgala ganya dardardab yirrgarra.
\xe [The spider] was dragging the web.
\dt 29/Aug/2012

\lx yirrab
\sf yirrab_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ps n
\ge group
\de group, another lot
\sd D Things
\re group
\va
\xv Gambala-lu gilyarra bulugi yirrab-barni jumaji jarrwa nyila bulugi.
\xe They're only branding that group of cattle because they're a big group of cattle.

\lx yirrban
\sf yirrban_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge flying.termite
\de flying termite or flying ants
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re ant (flying)
\re flying termite
\re termite (flying)
\re flying ant
\re Isoptera spp
\va
\sy
\sc Isoptera spp
\sc Termitidae
\gr yirrban, yirrbany, min.gun, mun.gud, mun.gub, munygud
\gg yirrpan
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so FMnotes:PigeonHole:IH:2003
\so EC:IH:Animal Pictures:2001
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee These flying insects are common after rain in the wet season and are often attracted to outside lights in large numbers. They are a favoured food of porcupines (echidnas) called 'jungguwurru' and frill-necked lizards called 'ngarranginy' who hunt for them. The eggs are found in the ant-hills called 'mardumardu'. They look like rice and can be collected and eaten. The flying insects can also be eaten. They are simply caught in the hands and eaten raw.
\dt 07/Feb/2008

\lx -yirri

\ps case
\ge ALL
\de allative case marker. This ending is used to mark goals. It is not always used on place names.
\sd Y Word Endings
\re to
\va
\sy -nggurra, -jirri, -gurra

\lx yirrijgaji
\sf yirrijgaji_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge plant.species
\de kind of plant
\sd M Plants
\va
\sy
\re Dodonaea polyzyga
\sc Dodonaea polyzyga
\gr
\gg yirrijgaji
\xv
\xe
\rf
\so I. Hector. 2002. Bilinarra Bush Medicine. Produced by F. Meakins for DAC
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\pc yirrijgaji.jpg
\ee This plant is commonly found around Kalkaringi and on the VRD road.  
The leaves and branches are strong smelling. They are also very sticky which is why 'yirrijgaji' is sometimes called 'nanggaji' (something which is sticky). You can use the leaves and branches as medicine. You boil them up and use the mixture to treat skin sores called 'marndara', headaches called 'warrngun' and congestion (bad cold) called 'gulygulya'. Alternatively the leaves of 'lawa', 'yirrijgaji' and 'dimarlarn' can be layered into a fire pit which has burnt down. Children are held over the pit to inhale the smoke and allow it to waft over their skin. The timber can be used to make spear points because the wood is very hard.
\dt 09/Jun/2008

\lx -yu
\sf yu_CA.mp3
\ps case
\sn 1
\ge DAT
\de dative case ending. This is a new ending which is used instead of -wu after words ending in 'i'. It marks a recipient or a person who receives something. It also marks a person who is being talked to or looked for
\sd Y Word Endings
\dk bo, bla, blanga
\re for
\sy -gu, -wu
\xv
\xe
\rf
\sn 2
\ge DAT
\de about
\re about
\xv Nguyin gurrwara yuwani guli-wu.
\xe You blamed me for the fight.
\rf SH: FM08_a090: 31:43min
\sfx gurrwara_SH_eg1_ngu.mp3
\sn 3
\ge DAT
\de benefactive. This ending a person who benefits from another person's actions
\re
\xv
\xe
\sn 4
\ge DAT
\de possessive. This ending marks the person who owns something
\xv
\xe
\rf
\sn 5
\ge DAT
\de This ending marks a person who is a goal
\re 
\xv
\xe
\sn 6
\ge DAT
\de purposive. This ending marks the purpose of another action
\re
\xv Burdurr na yani, yaluwu na garndi-yu, dib-gu
\xe So he left in a huff to pull up that tree.
\rf IH Jungguwurru story
\sn 7
\ge DAT
\de purposive location. This ending marks a location and a purpose at the same time
\re
\xv
\xe
\rf
\nt

\lx Yugayawung
\sf Yugayawung_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge Mount.Sanford.station
\de Mount Sanford station
\sd O Place Names
\re Mount Sanford station
\sy Janybud
\xv

\dt 11/Aug/2008

\lx yuguwibgaji
\sf yuguwibgaji_SH.mp3
\ps n
\ge camel
\de camel
\sd H Mammals
\dk kamel
\re camel
\re Camelus dromedarius
\va
\sy
\sc Camelus dromedarius
\gr
\gg yukipkaji
\xv
\xe
\pc Camels.jpg
\so JS050921BIL.KAT_06ih:(22:10, 22:15)
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\ee In the past, they were used at some places, like Victoria River Downs Station and Jinparrak or Wave Hill Station, to carry heavy loads from the depot at Timber Creek, via Yugayawung or Mount Sanford and Bullita. They were very strong and could carry much heavier loads than donkeys and mules. Sometimes they were driven by Afghan cameleers called 'mudura' by the Gurindji who were 'whitefellas that couldn't speak English'. Camels used to have pegs put through their noses to lead them around. They can be very aggressive and cheeky or 'guliyan'. Two Afghan traders called Ajarraman and Walyji lived at Wave Hill settlement (now Kalkaringi) in the early days. They had a shop on the side of the hill opposite the site of the current shop. You can still see the remains of their shop. The Afghan who had a shop at Limbunya was called Palyung or Charlie. He had a Gurindji wife. Camels occur as feral animals further to the south in Bilinarra and Gurindji country; the meat can be eaten. They can go for long periods without drinking water.
\dt 12/Feb/2008

\lx yumbu
\sf yumbu_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge spider
\de spider
\sd L Insects and Spiders
\re spider
\re Arachnida
\sy darru
\sy garrada
\sc Arachnida
\gr darru, garra, marawun
\gg tarru, yumpu
\pc spider.jpg
\ee All spiders have the same name though many different types of spider are recognised and some are dangerous. Some of the larger spiders live in burrows in the ground. Others live in webs. Spider webs are used in certain ceremonies and have important Dreamtime stories associated with them. In Bilinarra country there is a place called Wuna where you can see flat river rocks with red striations. These striations were left by a 'darru' who dragged its web across the rock. This is the same place where the husbands of the Nangangari women made 'wirrgala' (hairstring belts).
\so Ethnobiology draft 2007
\nt LC- this is a lesser used synonym for darru.
\dt 11/Feb/2008

\lx yurlurriny
\sf yurlurriny_CA.mp3
\ps n
\ge death.adder
\de death adder
\sd I Reptiles
\re death adder
\re snake (death adder)
\re Acanthophis praelongus
\sy buljuny
\sy bulyguwuny
\sc Acanthophis praelongus
\pc death_adder.jpg
\ee This is a small snake that is very dangerous or 'guliyan'. It has a short prickle in the end of its tail. If it bites someone, they will be dead in a very short time. It lives in rocky areas, especially in caves called 'jarriny'. There is a song which stops the poison, and songs which clear the snakes away from camping areas. When they are killed they need to be chopped into pieces and burnt on a fire until they turn to ash, otherwise they can sing themselves back to health and kill you.
\dt 14/Oct/2009

\lx yuwayi

soft ground looking for food.
